title: An absolutely lovely journal!
text: This is an absolutely lovely journal. The leather case is very sturdy & high quality.  The binder rings are nice & heavy - not at all flimsy. I'm not worried that they are going to break.  The loose leaf paper that is included is a heavy weight, too. Heavier than the standard notebook paper that I purchase for my children.  This would make an excellent gift that any recipient would be thrilled to receive. I love that it comes in a box suitable for gifting!

title: Fun to Use!
text: I've been using chalkboard labels and adhesive chalkboard shapes for a few months. They are fun to use & reuse. This set has a great variety of shapes. They are easy to clean - just wipe off the chalk with a damp paper towel. The E-book has some tips and photo suggestions for using the labels. The liquid chalk marker was a nice bonus. As with most liquid chalk markers, it takes a few moments to prime.

title: Happy to find the ink for my printer!

I went to 3 different Wal-Marts the other day to pick this up & they were all out! Next time, I will start with Amazon! Some day, though, I hope to purchase a printer with longer lasting ink cartridges!

title: Great Value!
text: We use these for Dress Down Days at my daughter's school so administration & teachers can see who has paid their $1 to dress down and is not in uniform. One mom was going to go to Party City to pick up wristbands for the Golf Club's Dress Down Day fundraiser. On the Party City website, it's more than double the price for 250 wristbands and over $50 for the same quantity as this deal. The cost of the wristbands comes out of the club's profit, so these are such a better value for us! These last for the whole day without any problems. There is a nice selection of colors & they are comparable to similar items from other stores.

title: Buyer Beware
text: I give this printer one star because that's the lowest rating.  I have always been a fan of Epson, but this printer is a piece of junk. The first one I bought was good for one test print. Took it back to the store and got a replacement. I should have gotten a refund.  As soon as the return period ended, the new printer started acting up.  If I print a picture, it has lines running through it, and performing an ink test empties the cartridges.  If I tell it to print two pages, I'm lucky if I get one.  Paper jams are almost an everyday occurrence. And don't even think about sending a fax.  I don't use a cover sheet, just my weekly order.  My distributor tells me all he received was a cover sheet with no order.  Cover sheet?  I didn't use one!  No order?  That's the only thing I faxed!  I love my little Epson R280.  It's at least six years old and works like new.  I bought the all-in-one so I could get rid of some of my business machines.  Thank God I didn't get rid of them because I would be up the proverbial creek without a paddle if I had.  I think my WorkForce Pro is on permanent vacation. I absolutely, positively HATE this printer and will never buy another one.  If I ever buy an all-in-one again, I'm going with a different brand altogether.

I didn’t take it up with the company so I don’t have anything negative to say regarding them. They could have very well been helpful and sent me a corrected one. A preview would have been helpful. text: This pen arrived with a plastic cap on the clicker. You can't see this cap easily at all. I couldn't get it to click at all, and I was ready to send it back as defective. I kept trying to screw or unscrew the clicker, then all at once I felt the plastic cap move. It was then that I noticed the cap, removed it, and now the pen clicks just fine. They should either leave the cap off, or provide a note saying to remove it. It was not obvious at all.

title: MY GO-TO FOR EVERYTHING!
text:
I have spent so much money over the years on useless diaries and notebooks and have never found one that worked well for me until now. I am in love with these notebooks by Minimalism Art.
They are super sturdy and can take a bashing in your bag. I love the elastic to keep them shut when not in use and the ribbon bookmarker so you can find your page. The paper is great quality and I get no bleed through so I can write on both sides of the page. I use these as a journal, one as a daily diary, for my writing ideas and for my ink drawings. A fabulous little book and at the fraction of the price of others on the market. I will never use anything other than these!

title: Great product!

I love the weekly layout with appointment slots. It is ideal being able to scan the week ahead but also still have the room for more detail. The cover is sturdy and even by the end of the year it still looks brand new. Mine gets chucked in my bag, on my desk, travels with me and it holds up so well. I can't recommend this diary/planner enough.

text: I ordered these paper clips because I had purchased plastic covered paper clips in the past and like them far more than metal clips.  These paper clips are a pretty good bargain, but they are not quite as sturdy as the ones I purchased at Office Max several years ago. However, I am sure they will be fine for all ordinary purposes, and for the price, you get a good value. I also like the segmented case they arrived in; it will look attractive on my desk.

title: pens do not work
text: I am sorry to report that these pens do not work well.  I don't know if I happened to get old stock, or if this is an inherent defect, but it is unacceptably difficult to write with these pens. Specifically, very little ink comes out, and when you finally get them to write, they dry up quickly.  They are very cute to look at and very comfortable to hold--I think they are ergonomically designed--but if they don't work, all the rest does not matter.

title: A Contrarian View
text: Unlike virtually all the other reviewers of these pens, I am not happy.  For one thing, it is nearly impossible to get the ink to flow.  If I stopped writing for a few seconds, the ink seems to dry up and required a lot of doodling to restart.  I certainly hope that I just got an old set that was out of date, but I have no way of knowing this.  Paper Mate is usually a very reliable brand, and I have many excellent Paper Mate pens.  These pens are not among them, and if I had paid for them, I would be sending them back.

title: Great pen, but a bit pricey
text: This is a great pen.  It writes smoothly (in red ink) and does not smear (I tested it!). The best thing about it is the ergonomically engineered cushioning.  As a retired English teacher, I have written enough with red pens not to ever again use one that does not have cushioning.  The only issue I have with this pen is the cost, which I think is a bit high.  Still, the pen is excellent, and you will enjoy using it if you purchase it.

title: Good storage option
text: These envelopes are sturdy and large enough to hold about a quarter of a ream of paper.  The colors are somewhat muted, which is fine, and it is easy to tell one from another.  The closures are elastic, which I am fine with for now, but I like velcro better over the long run.  Eventually, the elastic will stretch out and become useless.  However, for now the elastic is taut, and this is really just a matter of personal preference.  The price is probably a bit more that most people would like to spend, but the convenience and speed of Amazon cannot be beat.

title: Almost a great gradebook.
text: My school has stopped providing us with grade and plan books.  While I have moved with the times and have a blended classroom, I am still old school enough to want physical gradebooks and planners.  Since I was paying for it myself I opted for a pretty cover.  It is convenient and I like that I have it all in one book. In the gradebook there are 50 rows to a page.  At first I didn't like this but with my smaller classes I found that i can skip a line between students allowing me to make more notations.  The rows are also shaded every two rows (2 rows white, 2 rows green) which makes it easier to distinguish entries.  Another nice feature is a 6th column at the end of each week. I use it to record daily vocab study on the website we use. The book itself is pretty sturdy and is holding up to the abuse of daily use and transport in my laptop bag. The gradebook pages are perforated at the outside edge which is typical of these books and is useful when you switch marking periods. The perforation is too close.  The pages tear easily when you flip pages.  I ended up using clear tape to secure the page so that I don't end up ripping out the student names. it bothers me enough that I'm not sure I would buy this again.  Others might not mind it so much.

title: Write well and erase cleanly.
text: Love these pens.  They write well and they erase cleanly.  I'm a teacher and use them for grading.  I like hat I can eras my marks if I make a mistake without affecting the student's writing.

Tried writing with it on a couple other paper surfaces too but the pen is now in the trash.  Hopefully the remaining two pens work but I’m already disappointed.

title: Buy the one with the document feeder for the same price
text:
Don't buy this. Get the same printer but with the document feeder (and fax) for the same price here:

https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00C6MNQ92?ref=emc_b_5_t

title: Had a MX850, now have the MX860
text:
I recently experienced an involuntary upgrade when my year-old Canon MX850 fell off a table and died. I looked at other printers but nothing else came close to this one's package of features, price and performance. Amazon's price when I ordered was $139. The next day it went on sale for $109. I called and Amazon gave me the lower price. Free shipping took two days. Gotta love Amazon.

PROS: Great document feeder w/full duplexing, no jams; very good black text in standard print mode; excellent and fast photos (using Canon photo paper); wireless works great and was easy to set up in both Vista and XP; lots of fax features; two paper inputs with auto select; five ink tanks; closed design looks good and keeps out dust; good driver software; 2.5-inch LCD; easy wireless duplex scanning straight to PDF; USB cable included (unlike the MX850).

CONS: Big and heavy; looong wait for the first page to print; drinks ink like most inkjets; duplex printing is slow because it stops to let the ink dry on the first side before printing the other (though unlike the MX850 wait time is now adjustable); the low ink warning will appear well before the ink tank is empty; after several months it started making squeaking sounds like it needs a good lubricating, but it still works fine.

Overall and for home office use you simply cannot beat it for the money. Just don't drop it.

title: Amazing feature set and good quality results
text:
Bought this on Newegg on special for $160 with free shipping. Ordered on Sunday night and had it on Tuesday. I usually love Amazon but in this case Newegg was much better. In sum, you really can't find a better combination of features and quality for the price. The only real complaint I have is that sometimes documents fed through the automatic document feeder aren't 100 percent straight (more like 98 percent straight, but this is only a problem sometimes).

PROS: Auto-duplexing for input and output; 35-page document feeder; great quality when using high print settings; good speed at all settings (unless it's 2-sided); two paper inputs allows you to keep two different papers in the printer at all times, or to just close the top feed if you want; fast and high quality faxing with lots of features (fax isn't just an afterthought in this machine); multiple ink tanks means no disposing of partially full ink cartridges; very good driver software gives you lots of printing options through your computer; many copy, fax and scan options built into the machine and accessible through nice rotating LCD screen; no paper jams yet (UPDATED: Still no jams after over three months of continuous use!).

CONS: It's BIG, as in seriously big and heavy too; like I said above, about one-third of the time documents fed through the document feeder are just the slightest bit off; duplex printing is slow because it stops for ten seconds to let the ink dry on one side before printing the other side; text printed at low quality can be fuzzy, definitely use high print quality for important documents; it's a little on the noisy side and even has a "quiet mode" that I haven't tried yet; after two weeks of use I had to run the "unclog nozzle" routine to make some black streaking go away (I realize that maintenance is needed sometimes but after just two weeks seems a bit soon); would be nice if it came with a USB cable; photo printing gobbles up ink.

Overall so far I'm quite satisfied, though if the document feeder issue gets worse before the one year warranty expires I'll send it to Canon for service. And if need be I can always place documents on the glass by hand. Without that issue I'd give it 5 stars.

(Note, after 13 months of use this printer fell off a table and stopped working. So be careful and don't drop your printer.)

title: Time and Feedback Will Tell
text:
The print is a little smaller than what I expected. Given the purpose for which one uses such a stamp, it is important that it be NOTICED. I think it will be OK, so long as any mail handler is paying attention. Don't get me wrong - the letters are not tiny, but you want to be sure to stamp in a very conspicuous place. Or places.My recipients will let me know over time.

The plastic casing holding the stamp itself seems a little flimsy, but maybe it is just the one I received. I have had other stampers for 40 years and they still work fine. I hope this one will join the crowd!

title: Compact and Does the Job!
text:
If you are looking for a small shredder for identity protection purposes, this shredder will suit your needs. It handles old bills and the like with due dispatch. It makes a bit of noise, but for the price I can live with that minor drawback. (Try not to shred with any light sleepers nearby.) It will take small paper clips and staples. Paper shreds to thin short strips (rather than long strips), making identification of the shredded material highly unlikely.

To lubricate, the manual says you can simply drizzle vegetable oil on a sheet of paper and run it through. I used oil supposedly designed for shredders and the device has been fine. I find that I need to empty the basket once a week. All in all, a good choice for the average household!

title: Nice planner, hardback. Well made.
text:
This is a hard back planner, with a lovely front cover that looks like beautiful hand painted flowers.
The colors I like.
Has a spiral binding.
This is not a real large planner, but not small it could fit in your purse or brief case.

There are tabs for each month to find easy for the calendar, although for me the square space for each
Day is too small for me. , although when the next month page starts for the next month there is another calendar page
For more writing for that day which is nice.

For me I like to have a calendar that shows the full month , and not have to go back and forth looking for the same month.
I guess it’s what you get use too.
Although this is nice planner for a women.

title: Soft cover , more for a young women.
text:
I don’t usually use a planner like this. I use a calendar with a large space to write my schedule.
This planner is a soft cover , and book, does not have the spiral pages, and it is rather large.
The pages are on thick paper, and this seems sturdy.

It gives you all holidays , dates and days.
You have a glance at a full page over view of a 2022 calendar.
Then the pages begin at the top which is called checking in from the month before. Lower on the page it says Wellness.
Next to it on the same page It says gratitude.
On the page next to it , it says This Month-get started- Quit-it, keep up , then notes at the bottom.
Next page starts the monthly calendar. It continues like this for the year, then has lined pages on the back for notes etc.

I personally think of this planner for a teenager, or for a young women!
I handed this planner to my grown son thinking he might like this for his personal planner, not for his business .
He handed it back and said thx, I don’t have time for this, and mention maybe his daughter would like it.

My husband looked at this planner which is not for his schedule at all and what he uses for his appointments.
That said, my younger daughter liked this and was glad to receive it.

title: Did not receive what I ordered!
text:

I ordered a plain roll of 220 stickers,and what I recieved is a roll of stickers that are All
Printed in Red, and White, and each sticker says, “Please handle with care - Fragile , Thank You”.
If these where plain stickers I could have used these, they peeled off easy from the roll.

title: Big block, not many post-its, all stick together! Don’t waste your money.

I now can see why not .

title: Easy to use, but ink does not last long!
text:
I'm giving Epson another chance . For under $100.00 good price.

I'm not real techie when it comes to printers. But this was easy to install.
Plug it in. Set date, put the ink in that comes with this.
This scans, prints, Fax.
I have not tried to fax with this.
You need a line land to use this.

I needed this printer for my home use..I print out recipes, and recites.
It scans papers. I scanned a magazine page and it printed.

First time I used it, It did Print with ease but was slow.
Ink was black, but the color was not very sharp, as I noticed when I printed out a recipe,
with a small colored picture of what the recipe looks like.
Already I'm thinking this is not going to print out a picture of a child very good, and it doesn't.

I had a Epson WF2540, that was totally worthless...I think after printing out about 6 pages it ran out of ink!
Bought new ink, the same thing happened.
So far with this Epson, when I printed the 3rd page, the black ink was lighter in color..

I let the printer sit for aday, when I printed out another page, the ink was dark black again.

Personally, my old HP printer was faster, and the ink lasted forever. the HP did a much better job then this Epson printer has done, but
so far better then my last Epson. Which I had for less then a year, and ran out of ink Very fast...

If I find the ink last longer, and it fax's with ease I will return with a up date.

title: Works better then we expected
text:
I live in the mountains in California, where the mountains are all around me, and reception on our cell phone was impossible in the house, till my son put in a verizon box to get Cell reception.
I have wondered if we did not have the Verizon box would this Panasonic even work with our cell phones!
A question I could not answer.

That said, My Husbands is hard of hearing. When he is on the Panasonic phone he can hear better then his cell,which is great...
The cell phone has to stay near the base of the plug-in Panasonic to work in the house.
When your on the panasonic It does Not cut off while talking as the Cell phone would do before in our home.

My Husband can hear better from the Panasonic then his cell phone. Although the sound is not as loud as our other cordless phones in our home.
Also The speaker is not as loud as our other cordless phones.
Other people that use this phone think the sound is fine.

I live on a few acres, and take this phone outside and walk around with it. So far it has worked well.Not sure if it goes farther then our regular cordless does!

I can be talking on the land line phone, and he can also use it for his cell phone at the same time.
Not sure if call waiting works while on the phone and the cell panasonic at the same time!

I had to turn off the panasonic answering machine, as it picked up the call on the first ring, and it would go to message right away.
Now the old cordless phone picks up messages on the 4th ring.
I have 4 other cordless phones, and two other plug in's landlines, plus these two Panasonic phones in our home and they all work well together.

Connecting the phone to our home and the cell was not too much trouble.
This phone is good looking and easy to handle.

We like this phone and would buy it again.

title: Staples 210 Sheets of 20-Pound Printer Paper With Minimal Effort
text:
This AMAZONBASICS EFFORTLESS HEAVY-DUTY STAPLER (210 Sheets) really will staple a block of 210 sheets of 20-pound printer paper with minimal effort. However, it staples cleanly (without bending or distorting the staple) only about 25% of the time. (And of course it’s quite difficult to remove a bent staple that’s gone through 180-plus sheets of paper.)

To some extent, the staples are to blame. The stapler comes with a box of 5/16” staples (the maximum length). These may not be as sharp as they need to be, to staple big blocks of paper. Better quality staples will probably improve the stapler’s performance.

The stapler seems to give the best results when the handle is pressed down with a slow, steady pressure. The staples load through an opening at the rear. You pull on the black plastic that is located just below the screws on the handle--the black plastic is attached to a spring-loaded rod that pushes the staples forward as they’re used.

The staple-pusher mechanism seems a bit flimsy. It’s impossible to say whether this will stand up to regular use. The rest of the stapler is quite sturdy in its construction.

The stapler has a chart attached to the base that tells you which size staples you need for your stapling job, depending on how many sheets you need to staple. The stapler has a strike plate that rotates to properly bend the ends of the shorter staples used for fewer sheets of paper.

title: Overpriced, Overpackaged Planner With Decorative Stickers, Colored Pens
text:
This STMT DIY AGENDA SET (by Horizon Group USA; Planner/Organizer/Diary with Debossed & Regular Stickers, Sticky Notes & Glitter Tape. Gel Pens & Paper Clips) consists of a thin spiral notebook with cheap cardboard covers (floral-printed), and cheap filler paper (35 total filler pages). There are three types of filler paper--blank calendar pages (you fill in the dates), wide-ruled pages, and dotted sketch pages.

In addition, there is a small sheet of colored stickers for the months, two small sheets for the alphabet, and two sheets for events (e.g., party, birthday) and reminders (e.g., don’t forget). There are a few embossed lightweight cardboard stickers (star, diamond, flower, etc.). There is a small roll of fuchsia glitter tape. There are four fuchsia-colored paper clips. There are three ballpoint pens (neon orange, neon pink, blue). And there is a small pad of lavender sticky notes shaped like an arrow.

You get all this for a little less than $24 on Amazon! In my opinion, this “agenda set” is grossly overpriced for what it is. The box is a masterpiece of deceptive packaging--it is 2 inches deep, with the thickest item being the notebook (½ inch thick, including the spiral binding). Everything is laid out on a single layer atop a clear plastic insert, and the presentation makes it look like there are many more decorative items than there actually are.

The best thing about this set is that ballpoint pen ink doesn’t bleed through the filler paper pages.

title: Costly “Printer Stand” With Highly Misleading Ad Photos
text:
One star for this IPARTS EXPERT DESKTOP PRINTER STAND (with 4 Rolling Wheels), because of the highly misleading advertising photos on the Amazon product page. This is NOT a wheeled printer stand that you place on the floor next to a desk. Instead, it is a small DESKTOP ORGANIZER STAND with wheels. It is very expensive (about $46 on Amazon) for something you place atop a desk to hold a very small printer and make space underneath.

By adding wheels to this desktop organizer, the seller can photograph it in a way that makes it look like furniture--like a full-size printer stand. In the product page photo, the “plant” alongside the organizer is actually a bunch of flowers in a vase of water. It gives you no idea of the actual size of the organizer.

The price is also in line with the price of a budget-priced printer stand. (Yes, the product page text cautions you to measure your printer before ordering, but that doesn’t excuse the intentionally misleading photos.)

The wheels help create the deception in the photos. Why would anyone want wheels on a DESKTOP organizer? Few desktops have space for rolling anything around, let alone a heavy item like a printer. Should the wheels go past the edge of the desk, they will tip the printer onto the floor. (This is a real possibility, because the wheel locks do NOT prevent the stand from rolling on a smooth surface.)

ASSEMBLY. The organizer stand comes with an alternate set of pads that you can use instead of the wheels. It is easy to assemble, using the included Allen wrench, until you come to the wheels. (On my stand, the holes for the screws were drilled correctly and the screws went in straight.)

The wheels screw into the holes in the metal parts, but you need a slender wrench of the correct size (not included) to accomplish this. The pads can be screwed in by hand. My assembly instructions consisted of a single letter-sized page which said nothing about how to add either the pads or wheels. (I’d suggest putting the wheels with the locks at the front, where you can reach the locks.)

PRINTER SIZE. The organizer will hold an EPSON WF-2530 all-in-one printer, which is advertised as the Epson Workforce printer with the smallest footprint. The organizer is hopelessly too small for my larger Epson and Canon printers, which are the ones heavy enough to benefit from placement on a wheeled printer stand.

See my photos to get some idea of the size of the stand. The letter-sized assembly instructions are shown atop the wooden parts. The big Quaker Oats box (42 oz.) is included for scale. The large hardcover cookbook pretty much covers the lower shelf; the book only fits when laid on its side.

title: Slow, But Good for Shredding Junk Mail; Has Tiny Footprint
text:
There are many different AmazonBasics shredders, but what distinguishes this AMAZONBASICS 12-SHEET CROSS-CUT JUNK MAIL, CD, AND CREDIT CARD SHREDDER (with Pullout Basket) is the tiny footprint. The shredder is only 12” wide and 9-1/2” deep, so it easily fits on top of a low bookshelf, credenza, or filing cabinet. It can even fit on a desktop, if you’re a “clean desk” type who doesn’t need much desktop workspace.

The small size comes at a cost, though. The junk-mail shredder is much slower than my wonderful [[ASIN:B00D7H8XB6 AmazonBasics 12-Sheet High-Security Micro-Cut Shredder]]; and the small pull-out basket fills up very, very quickly. The basket is fairly easy to empty into a large wastebasket; but if you overfill it, you’ll have lots of shredded paper bits to clean up.

The cross-cut blades cut the paper into strips that are 3/16” wide and 1” long, which offers pretty good protection from snoops. However, my micro-cut shredder makes strips that are 3/16” wide and 5/8” long, which offers much more security.

The manual doesn’t say how long you can run this junk-mail shredder before it will turn off and require a 45-minute cooldown. Probably it will run for several minutes. In my experience, if you pause frequently between batches of documents, you will never encounter the need for a long cooldown.

I ordered this shredder because I wanted a small shredder dedicated to junk mail, and it fills this need perfectly. However, I won’t be using it for large batches of documents, because it’s too slow. When I have a major shredding task--as when I’m cleaning out file cabinet drawers--I will be using the big micro-cut shredder.

title: Appear to Be Standard Tank-Style Permanent Markers
text:
These BIC INTENSITY PERMANENT MARKERS (Tank style, Chisel Tip; Box of 36 Black Markers) don’t seem “special” to me--they seem like standard tank-style permanent markers. When the markers are brand new, the lines drawn by the chisel tips aren’t particularly fine.The chisel tips are firm to begin with, but will soften with use, so the lines will eventually be even less fine.

The product page states that these markers will write on nearly every surface--I have no reason to think that the claim is untrue. In my experience, all tank-style permanent markers write on most surfaces (regardless of the brand). That’s why you have to be extra careful with permanent markers, so you don’t mark clothing, your desktop, or something else that you don’t intend to mark.

BIC is generally a brand that I trust when purchasing pens, dry-erase markers, and permanent markers. I definitely buy BIC products, regardless of price, rather than similar generic products that are offered by unknown manufacturers.

title: Pale Gold-Toned Ink Nearly Vanishes in Artificial Light
text:
I love the cover design and layout of this compact ASHLEY G FOR BLUE SKY 2019-2020 ACADEMIC YEAR WEEKLY & MONTHLY PLANNER (Flexible Cover, Twin-Wire Binding, 5" x 8", Painterly Stripe). However, I hate that the inside pages are printed with gold-toned ink that nearly disappears in indoor artificial light.

The pale ink makes it hard to quickly read the dates on the tabbed two-page calendar spreads. On the weekly pages, you have to look closely to see the date and day of the week, and the dotted lines that substitute for solid-ruled lines in the daily spaces practically vanish.

This design is impractical for a school-year diary of important dates, regardless of whether you are a student or a teacher/professor. It’s just too easy to write events down on the wrong calendar day or weekday. The elegant design is nice, but it’s inappropriate for an academic planner.

title: Too Wide to Fit Desk’s Hanging File Drawer, Lateral File Cabinet Drawers
text:
This C-LINE 13-POCKET EXPANDING FILE WITH HANGING TABS (Bright Blue, 8-1/2" x 11" (58215)) is a nice, durable, plastic expansion file. However, it is ⅜” wider than a standard Pendaflex hanging folder (the paper portion) so it doesn’t fit in my desk’s hanging file drawer, or in my lateral file cabinet drawers. (It is 12⅛” wide, which is wider than the space between the hanging file support rods.)

The idea is clever. The expanding file has four pull-out plastic tabs at the top, so that you can store it as a hanging file, but pull it out and use it (with the tabs pushed in, out of the way) at your desk like a regular expansion file. Unfortunately, the good idea is badly executed.

title: Hard-to-See, Pale Colors; Clumsy to Write With
text:
These KINGART DRY ERASE MARKER PENS (945-36; 36 Chisel Tip Non-Toxic Pens in 12 Colors) were disappointing to me in three ways: (1) the colors are very pale when applied to my cheap metal whiteboard calendar, (2) the fine edge of the tip doesn’t apply color evenly and the wide edge is clumsy to write with, and (3) the package has 3 sets of the same 12 colors (as stated in the description, but I stupidly expected 36 colors).

These dry erase markers may work better with other whiteboards. From experience, I know that different marker brands work better or worse with specific whiteboards. (I own whiteboards from several different manufacturers.) However, I’m disinclined to use these dry erase markers on the wall calendar as intended, because the markings can’t be read clearly from a few feet away. (Unlike the markings from the black Quartet markers that I’ve been using for date numbers and appointments; in photo, see black numbers and "Darlene".)

The 36 markers come in a clear, flexible-plastic retail box that can be retained for storage. They erase very easily.

title: Blue Inserts Leave Fine Scratches on Whiteboard
text:
In my experience, Quartet makes the very best whiteboard markers and products, but it missed the mark with this QUARTET WHITEBOARD/DRY ERASE BOARD ERASER (6" x 2-3/8", (DFEB5)). The big eraser has a hard felt surface with two blue “scratchee” inserts that extend above the felt surface by about ¼”. Unfortunately, the inserts leave behind very fine scratches on the surface of my cheap magnetic whiteboard calendar.

I solved the problem by pulling the blue inserts out of the eraser. I can still use the eraser, and it stays handy in the excellent magnetic eraser holder that comes with it. The magnetic holder sticks very firmly to the wall calendar, and it doesn’t slide anywhere.

title: Fun Set of Permanent Marker Pens in Different Colors
text:
Who doesn’t love colored pen and pencil sets? These SHARPIE PERMANENT MARKERS, AARON JUDGE SPECIAL EDITION (Fine Point, Assorted Colors, 24 Count) are fun to look at, and fun to draw or mark with. Just remember that these are PERMANENT markers--if you get the ink on your clothing or a desktop, it won’t come out.

I use these for labeling file folders, storage tubs, and cardboard boxes. They aren’t good for coloring books, because the colors bleed through the thin paper. The colors often bleed through coated papers, too (as in Post-Its or file folders).

Happily, my set of “Aaron Judge” Sharpies didn’t have any dried out markers. (Markers do dry out, though, so don’t expect them to last forever--even if they’re unopened.) Unhappily, my set had only 23 different colors. There were two bright blue markers, instead of one bright blue and one bright green marker.

The Sharpie Uncap the Possibilities prize sweepstakes offer that comes with the “Aaron Judge” set appears to be open through March 31, 2019.

title: Well-Designed Weekly Planner Starts With July 2018, Has Pinky-Beige Pages
text:
This AT-A-GLANCE 2018-2019 ACADEMIC YEAR WEEKLY & MONTHLY PLANNER (Large, 8-1/2 x 11, “Garden Party” (150-905A)) is strictly for the current academic year. It runs from July 2018 through June 2019, with NO bonus pages to take you to the end of 2019.

The planner has the mix of daily diary pages that really works for me. There are tabbed 2-page spreads in calendar format for every month, and 2-page spreads for every week with plenty of lines for writing down appointments, etc. There are small year-at-a-glance calendars (2018, 2019, 2020) printed at the front. Holidays are shown on the monthly spreads, but NOT on the weekly spreads.

Note that the pages of this planner are NOT white, but a sort of pinky-beige. This may be easier on the eyes, but makes the dates and days a little harder to read than I like. (There are many similar At-a-Glance planners available with white pages.)

I’ve used these big planners with letter-sized pages for a few years now. I note down tasks/appointments that I need to complete each day, and check them off when they’re done. That way I have a record of when I last fertilized the garden plants, serviced the car, etc.

At-a-Glance makes little improvements in these planners in most years. This one has a new plastic pocket (double-sided) for holding note slips, letters, clippings, etc. It also has new paper that resists ink bleed from ballpoints and gel pens.

title: “Printing” Is Limited to LCD Display; Manual Uses Miniscule Type
text:
This SHARP EL-1901 PAPERLESS PRINTING CALCULATOR (with Check and Correct, 12-Digit LCD) is a powerful, versatile desk calculator, but using it isn’t at all intuitive. For me, the learning curve was quite steep, because I needed a strong magnifying glass to comfortably read the accompanying Manual.

You must read the manual to understand the button sequences required for different types of calculations; yet the Manual is printed in positively miniscule type. (The online Manual available at Sharp’s website is exactly the same as the two-sheet, double-sided Manual that comes with the calculator. I will need to use a copier to enlarge sections of this Manual for regular reference.)

The key to using the calculator is the C/CE key, which gets you out of whatever special mode (e.g., Correct, GT) you may have landed in. It’s also good to know that the scroll buttons put you into Check mode, and the Correct button puts you into a submode of Check. Getting totals or performing computations may require use of both the = button and the * button.

In short, this is a calculator intended for a regular, heavy user—someone who won’t forget the correct button sequences. It’s very easy to get erroneous calculations if you don’t know exactly what you’re doing.

Probably the thing that I dislike most about this calculator is that it’s advertised as a “printing” calculator. The only “printing” that you get is the readout on the upper LCD screen. The readout is nice—you can check your list of entries, and correct any that have errors without having to re-enter the full list. However, there is no way to get a paper printout of the list. The calculator does NOT have a USB cable port or wireless capability that would enable printing from a computer’s printer, so the calculator doesn’t do traditional paper-and-ink printing.

title: Works to Re-Attach Air Fresheners to Garbage Cans
text:
This SAUNDERS UHU TAC HOME DECO REUSABLE PUTTY (2.1 oz (60g), 32 pads (48710)) is useful to have on hand for attaching lightweight items to all sorts of surfaces. It’s definitely reusable, and it comes off smooth surfaces without leaving marks. (I’d recommend testing it in an unobtrusive area before using it on a painted wall, but would expect it to come off without pulling off a layer of paint.)

My favorite use is for re-attaching [[ASIN:B00AN5L8FS Air Wick Stick-Ups]] to the inside of my garbage can. I have to remove the Stick-Ups when I roll the can to the curb for pickup, or they’ll fall out with the trash when the can is emptied. This reusable putty makes it easy to pull them off and stick them back on.

The main key to success is to use enough putty pads to handle the weight of your object. This UHU TAC product is intended to hold items up to 4.4 lbs. “under optimal conditions”. For slightly heavier objects, try [[ASIN:B0085T0G2K UHU TAC PROPOWER]].

title: Fancy Case for Standard Parker Ballpoint Pen Refill
text:
This PARKER URBAN BALLPOINT PEN (Premium Ebony Metal Chiseled; with Medium Point Black Ink Refill (1975430)) is a beautiful ballpoint pen, packaged in an attractive presentation box--but it's nothing more than a fancy case for a standard Parker ballpoint pen ink refill (see, e.g., [[ASIN:B00AR9WKN4 Parker-Point-Refills-Medium-Black]]).

If you love the "Urban" pen's looks, or if you want to gift someone with an expensive (about $47 on Amazon) ballpoint pen, then this is a good choice. However, as a writing instrument, it performs exactly the same as any other ballpoint pen with the same Parker refill. The pen's weighted, black-lacquer-and-chrome barrel is nice, and it feels good in the hand, but the pen tip size and ink flow are determined by the refill you choose.

title: Great Dispenser, Great Concept; But No "Permanent Bond"
text:
This TOMBOW MONO ADHESIVE+ (62165) item consists of a well-designed glue-tape dispenser containing a replaceable "permanent bond" glue cartridge. The Tombow dispenser has made me a convert to glue tape. Glue tape is far superior to the inexpensive glue sticks I've been using for attaching labels to letters and filing folders. Glue tape goes on smoothly, in a thin layer, precisely where I want it, and presumably won't dry out like the clumsy glue sticks.

The dispenser has a plastic flap that flips down when you want to glue something; the flap flips up to protect the glue side of the tape when the dispenser is stored in a drawer, box, purse, or carryall. The used tape rolls up automatically inside the tape cartridge. A switch on the back of the dispenser opens and closes for cartridge replacement and secure, locked-in cartridge replacement.

The pre-installed Tombow cartridge seems to contain a substantial amount of tape, so the dispenser shouldn't need constant refilling. The replacement cartridges (Tombow Mono Permanent Adhesive Refills, 3 Pack (62207)), currently about $7 on Amazon) are fairly inexpensive.

However, the Tombow "permanent bond" adhesive does NOT provide a permanent bond. I tested the bond by gluing two standard Post-It notes together. The bond certainly was stronger than the weak, removable bond of a Post-It (and is probably much stronger than the bond of Tombow removable adhesive). However, the two Post-Its peeled apart easily, with no tearing of the paper, in multiple tests--even in a test where I pressed on the paper for a maximum bond, and waited 15 minutes. (The adhesive is not supposed to require drying time.)

The "permanent bond" is probably strong enough to hold photos and papers in albums and scrapbooks. Because the adhesive is advertised as "acid free", it's probably a good choice for those purposes.

However, the "permanent bond" is not nearly as strong as Elmer's glue. I really like this glue tape's non-messy, controlled application, but I don't trust the "permanent bond" for securing mailing labels (which I will continue to cover with clear shipping tape). I rate this product at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Big, Impressive Card Needs Extra First-Class Postage
text:
This BIRTHDAY WISHES BIRTHDAY CARD WITH FOIL is a generic card that's suitable for anyone's birthday. Maybe it's slightly better for women, because of the two "diamonds" that are glued onto the stylized flower design, near the top. The flower design itself, done in copper foil, is raised from the card surface. The copper foil contrasts nicely with the silver background.

This is a big, impressive card that you might want to keep on hand for an unexpected birthday. It comes with a plain white envelope, and is "printed on sustainably sourced paper". At 1.3 ounces, this card will take two stamps for mailing; however, the envelope (6-1/8" high by 9-1/4" wide) falls within the size limits for machine-sorted mail (and thus doesn't qualify for an "oversized mail" surcharge).

Because this card is heavy enough to require extra postage for mailing, I rate it at 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Great Idea; Would Be Better If Made With Heavier Plastic
text:
These flexible plastic AVERY TABBED SNAP-IN BOOKMARK DIVIDERS are a great idea. They easily snap onto the rings of a standard three-ring binder, so you can bookmark sections of, or specific pages in, a filled ring binder. The colorful designs incorporated in the bookmarks are cheerful, and the designs are sufficiently memorable that you can find a particular place without reading the labels on the bookmark tabs. (These come with a page of printable labels for the tabs.)

However, if your ring binder isn't very full, the bookmarks will snap OUT almost as easily as they snap IN. (Mine actually fell off the rings of an empty binder when I closed the binder.) I would like to see these snap-in bookmarks manufactured in heavier plastic, which I think would cure the snap-out problem, and make them just about perfect for my needs. Because the bookmarks snap out too easily, I rate them at only 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Outperformed by AmazonBasics 12-Sheet Micro-Cut Shredder
text:
My neighborhood has scavengers who regularly rummage through garbage and recycle bins, looking for credit card bills or anything else they might use for identity theft. Being a little paranoid, I'm always looking for an affordable shredder that will cut household mail, credit cards, CDs, and documents into tinier pieces than I'm getting with my current shredders.

I ordered this SENTINEL PRO FMC120P MICRO-CUT SHREDDER in hopes that it would shred more finely than my excellent [[ASIN:B00D7H8XB6 AmazonBasics 12-Sheet High-Security Micro-Cut Shredder]] . Unfortunately, the two micro-cut shredders perform about the same with paper, and this Sentinel shredder does a much worse job with plastics like CDs (see my customer photos). It just cuts the CDs into big pieces.

The Sentinel shredder doesn't feel quite as sturdy as the AmazonBasics shredder. The two shredders make about the same amount of noise. The AmazonBasics shredder is a little faster. The Sentinel shredder has a larger bin (7.7 gallons as against 6.6 gallons). Both shredders have forward and reverse switches for clearing jams. The Sentinel shredder has a light that comes on when the bin is full. Both shredders handle a maximum 12 sheets at once; both can shred staples, although both user manuals recommend against shredding staples, paperclips, or anything with adhesive, if you want to prolong the shredder's life.

My true workhorse shredder is an old Fellowes PS-14C crosscut model (no longer sold) that handles 14 sheets at once. It has a powerful motor, and cuts through CDs, staples, paperclips, and folded mail with ease. Its only flaw is that it doesn't shred as finely as I would like it to.

Overall, this Sentinel Pro Micro-Cut Shredder is a decent machine, and worth purchasing if you can get a good deal on it. However, because it does such a poor job on plastics, and is generally outperformed by the AmazonBasics shredder, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale.)

title: Accurate Electronic Scale; AccuPost Software Could Be Better
text:
This ACCUPOST PP-110 DESKTOP POSTAL SCALE with USB cable and 10-lb. load capacity weighs in 1/8-oz. increments, and seems to be quite accurate for its entire range. I tested it with letters weighing less than half an ounce or only a few ounces, and compared the weights to those registered by an [[ASIN:B002UEZ2FC Ozeri Professional Digital Kitchen Food Scale]]. Both scales gave the same results. (This scale replaces my old Pelouze 5-lb. mechanical spring scale, which weighed in 1/2-oz. increments, and wasn't at all accurate for lightweight letters.)

I also tested this scale with two 5-lb. bags of sugar, which weighed a total of 10 lbs. 1-1/4 oz. The results were generally consistent, although a single bag sometimes registered at 5 lbs. 3/4 oz. (instead of 5 lbs. 5/8 oz.)--probably because the extra packaging weight was very close to 3/4 oz. This scale also weighs in grams and kilograms.

I was a little disappointed to learn that the software doesn't automatically calculate the postage that needs to be added to the letter or package. (I was hoping for software that would let me download postage rate changes to my computer, and then would compute postage amounts automatically whenever I weighed something.) Instead, you must (1) visit the appropriate USPS, UPS, or FedEx web site, (2) find the appropriate page for calculating postage or shipping, and (3) paste in the weight. If you're using the MSIE browser, the software will send the weight directly to the calculation page (no pasting required), but this is probably not worth the effort of plugging in the USB cable and getting the weight to display on your computer screen.

The software was hard to find--the link in the user's manual didn't work, and the download link on the AccuPost home page didn't work for Windows 7. Eventually I found a working download link on the AccuPost 10 lb. scale product page in the AccuPost Online Store. The Win7 software requires Microsoft NET Framework 4, a free download. The software itself is a bit glitchy (doesn't always respond if it's been open for a while), but it usually works okay to show and paste in weights, handle the "tare" and "hold" buttons, and turn the scale on and off.

The scale comes with a power adapter, which is great to have if you do a lot of mailing. Since I don't, I opted to use 3 AA batteries (not included) to power the scale. The software works with either the power adaptor or the battery option (unplug the power adaptor first). Because my postal scale is located on a table some 6-8 feet from my computer, I used an [[ASIN:B001TH7GUU AmazonBasics USB Extension Cable]] to successfully supplement the included 40-inch USB cable.

The "tare" feature works flawlessly: you can add an item, such as an empty container, then hit "tare" to return the weight to zero so that you can put something in the container to find its weight separately. The "hold" feature allows you to hold the weight display when you are weighing something large that overlaps the display--you hit the button and wait for the two beeps, then when you remove the large item the weight will still be showing. The extra-large numbers in the display are another excellent feature.

I like this electronic postal scale a lot, and find that it does everything that's reasonably expected of a postal scale. However, because of the slightly glitchy and mildly disappointing software, I rate it at 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: 100% Jam Proof Feature Works Too Well!
text:
You'd better believe the product description for this FELLOWS POWERSHRED 73Ci 100% JAM PROOF 12-SHEET CROSS-CUT SHREDDER. The shredder is indeed 100% jam proof, and it will accept 12 sheets, tops. In fact, these are the features that I like the least.

This shredder has a sensor with a lighted display that shows Red (too many sheets inserted), Yellow (productivity is optimized), or Green (more sheets can be inserted). If the sensor starts with Red, the shredder won't start. If you insert flat sheets of paper, it will shred them quickly (though it will sometimes accept only 11 sheets). With ordinary paper loads, the shredder will run continuously for 10 minutes of shredding.

However, if you insert unopened junk mail--which usually has lightweight card stock and paper inserts, in addition to regular letter paper--the shredder will start, but will halt with an overload soon after it begins to shred. (Presumably the sensor sees the load differently once the layers are separated a little.) This isn't really a problem, because the shredder will reverse and advance, reverse and advance, until it clears the jam all by itself. However, the jam-proof feature slows the shredding process, because the shredder doesn't operate continuously. (I'll admit that I'm hard on shredders, because I find it entertaining to try to get the maximum load in each shredder pass, and to try to get the shredding done in the shortest possible time.)

A nice feature of this FELLOWES 73Ci shredder is that it has both an on-off switch (at the back), and a lighted "on" panel (at the front). You must touch the front panel to instantly light the display and start the shredder. After 2 minutes of nonoperation, the lighted display automatically goes to sleep mode, which shuts down the shredder. This display feature, along with the 12-sheet sensor that prevents needless paper jams, saves on energy. Other nice features are the display lights that show when the bin is full or open, and the shredder's "SafeSense" technology that halts the shredder when hands touch the paper opening.

However, all of these electronic sensors and jam-clearing features come at a price: the powered shredder "lid" that fits on top of the bin support is very heavy. It is much heavier than the "lid" on my older 18-sheet Fellowes PS-14Cs cross-cut shredder, which also has the "SafeSense" technology (but not the sheet sensor or the sleep mode). The two shredders cut identically-sized pieces that measure 1/4" by 1-1/2". I actually like the older model better, because of the greater sheet capacity that makes shredding junk mail a breeze.

The FELLOWES 73Ci shredder's weight is offset by the fact that the bin (and "lid") support is equipped with casters. Casters mean that the shredder is easily moved, and easy to shift around when the bin needs emptying. The shredder blades are easy to maintain, needing only a little oil after each binful, squirted across the shredder opening.

This is actually my fifth Fellowes shredder. I broke the first two, purchased many years ago when shredders first appeared in the office supply chain stores (e.g., Home Depot, Staples). I overloaded and jammed them, and ruined the motors. My third Fellowes shredder, a strip-cut model, performed admirably for many years--despite my continuing overload abuse. It was finally replaced with this cross-cut shredder. I donated the strip-cut shredder to Goodwill, and I hope it will continue to shred away for someone else who finds strip-cut shredding adequate. My fourth Fellowes shredder, the 18-sheet cross-cut shredder already mentioned, is still in use in my home office, after 3-4 years of operation and some overload abuse.

Because the FELLOWS POWERSHRED 79Ci 100% JAM PROOF 12-SHEET shredder won't operate continuously when I shred unopened junk mail, I give it only 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale). If you have light shredding needs, then this shredder is a great choice, because a cross-cut shredder gives good security, and is cheaper to buy and maintain than a diamond-cut shredder. If you have moderate shredding needs, then you should probably consider a Fellowes shredder with a larger sheet capacity, such as the [[ASIN:B000YGO7HW Fellowes 3229901 PowerShred 99Ci 17 Sheet Cross-Cut Shredder]] (slightly more expensive, with many similar features including jam-proof technology, but lacking the energy-saving feature).

title: Jam-Free, But Stapling Takes More Effort
text:
When I saw these at a local Staples store, the promise of "jam free" stapling was irresistible. I purchased a box, which cost about a dollar more than a box of my usual Swingline S.F.4 chisel point staples. Both boxes appeared to be about the same size, although the Optima box has 3750 staples, and the S.F.4 box has 5000 staples.

The Optima staples do seem to be jam free, but stapling with them requires a lot more effort than stapling with S.F.4 staples. Probably the Optima staples are stuck together with special glue that prevents jamming, but doesn't want to let go. I used the Optima staples in a [[ASIN:B00006XY3P Swingline Compact Commercial Stapler (S7071101R)]], which is a terrific little desktop stapler. Maybe the Optima staples take less stapling effort when they're used in a larger stapler specifically designed for Optima staples.

For the future, I'm definitely sticking with the [[ASIN:B003RL7RRS Swingline S.F. 4 Premium Chisel Point Staples]]. The S.F.4 staples rarely jam, the sharp tips easily penetrate multiple sheets of paper, and they cost quite a bit less per box and per staple.

title: Great card for the price
text: A great card for the price! It's about a third if the cost of other pop-up cards and well made. Tx u.

title: Very small
text: Appears much larger in ad than it is in reality

title: Flat as a pancake
text: Goes flat as a pancake in less than 30 seconds

title: A million parts, an hour of labor to assemble ...
text: A million parts, an hour of labor to assemble and finally done. Tgw drawers do not have stops so you have to be very careful opening them or they will fly onto the floor. Will function for what I need it but these problems should have been pointed out.

title: Better than nothing.
text: Requires a few passes to cover well. But it’s better than nothing. Needed something to top up my same day delivery, and found this. Glad to have a bit of mail identity protection.

title: Look worn along edges
text: I know these are new, but they appear used. I was planning on placing gift cards in them and giving as gifts. I’m embarrassed that the edges look like they’ve been in and out of a wallet for a year. I cannot tell how the RFID aspect works yet, I’ll check back in at another point soon.

title: Heavy duty...but too heavy for me.
text: It looks nicely made, but it is 2 inches too wide and too heavy (over 7 pounds) to be used in my theater recliner seats 💺. I’ll have to return it and look for something else. The only assembly need is unwrapping the little piece of wood (pencil holder) and placing the pegs into the tray.

title: Black pens work well. Color pens not so much.
text: The black pens work well - good and dark, erase well, I like being able to switch between the chisel and finer tips. But the red and blue pens are very light and not seen well from a distance. They just don't seem practical or very usable. If you only need the black pens, this set is fine. But if you need colored pens for contrast, you might want to find a different set.

title: Wasn't able to achieve kiss cut on Cricut.
text: If you're going to print then do your own cutting with scissors, this paper is ok. The colors print adequately and dry quickly. But I wasted more than half the pack and an entire afternoon trying to achieve a kiss cut on planner stickers with my Cricut. No setting I tried worked - not printable vinyl, not regular vinyl, not sticky paper or washi tape (those had been suggested in some forums online), not even paper. Some settings cut all the way through - which, if that's what you're looking for, would work. (That didn't work well for me, since I was trying to cut about 60 small stickers, which was time consuming to then remove from the mat.) Some settings did a terrible in-between, which basically ripped up the paper and left a ton of stuff for me to peel off the mat. All I wanted was a nice sheet of stickers, kiss cut so I could peel them away from the sheet as needed. No settings I tried would work, and I figured my time was worth going out and buying an actual pack of Cricut printable vinyl to work like I wanted it to. ps: if you've been able to achieve a kiss cut on Cricut with a setting I haven't mentioned here, I'd love to know!

title: Great with 110 lb cardstock.
text: This printer has some quirks that keep me from giving it a 5-star review. First of all, the design is rather clunky - the way the paper tray comes out and the display screen panel lifts up does not feel very streamlined, and takes more space than expected on a desk. It was also very temperamental when trying to connect to wifi the first time. I'll need to go into my settings, but it also seems like the default is to shut off while not in use, then requiring that I "register" my paper type every single time I use the printer. Despite all this, I got this printer in the hopes it would do one thing that many other mid-level printers do not: seamlessly print on 110 lb cardstock. And I'm happy to say this printer is a CHAMP at doing that, using the rear paper feed. I use 110 lb cardstock often for my craft business, and economy & mid-level printers typically chew it up getting caught on the rollers. Larger, more expensive printers are better suited for it, but are just not affordable for me. The rear paper feed does the trick here, and the print quality is great.

title: Could be more user-friendly, but still a solid, versatile machine.
text:
The printer comes boxed very carefully, and has a number of little safeguards in the machine that need to be removed before use. Getting the machine plugged in, all the parts moving, etc, was simple enough, and I thought the ink process was particularly interesting. The screen guides you through inserting each cartridge, with a carousel-type of thing that forwards to each slot for the different colors of ink. It took another 10 minutes for the machine to clean the printer heads, align the ink, etc, which seemed a bit excessive. Will it do that each time I change the ink?

Getting the printer to work wirelessly with our computers was a little more complicated, and required the disk on both PCs. The disc installs the machine as both a scanner *and* a printer, with software to control the settings of the scanner function. Although it took some time, the printer is now working well on the network with our computers. Printing is fast and the quality looks good. The copier works as expected. The scanner has a few options for output - scan to PC, scan to email, scan to USB, etc. I've been working through all of them, and while they are great features, I will say it's not nearly as intuitive as my HP Envy printer. It's just a clunkier process, though still useful.

The machine itself is larger than most, but still reasonable for desk-top use. The ink is affordable to replace, which is good, since we have four kids in school who will be using it often for papers and such. It'll take me forever to remember it's not a touch screen, but I'll survive. (but honestly - why not a touch screen??) Overall, though I think some of the processes could be more streamlined and user-friendly, this is a solid machine for a variety of moderate to heavy home uses.

title: Better for small business than a home office.
text: I wanted to love this printer, and for the price (and it being a Samsung), I really thought I would. BUT...not so much. It's HUGE, far too large for typical home/family desk use, and was incredibly heavy to move from place to place until we found an appropriate spot for it. Our unit didn't come with a set-up CD, so we labored through some frustration trying to get it set up on our wireless and for use with our two desktop computers. The connectivity has been ok so far, and the printing is lightning fast. The on-board screen is not all that intuitive, which has made using its other functions (scanning, copying, etc) not as quick or easy. The unit comes with your first set of toner cartridges, but we were astounded at the price to replace them once we're through with these. Perhaps I am just the wrong customer for this kind of printer - we need it primarily for home office use, but it seems perhaps more suited for a small business. And for a home office, we have used and loved far cheaper printers (especially the HP Envy) that still have all the multi-function capabilities, including the cloud/mobile printing, but are far more user-friendly. We'll stick with those instead!

title: Pens
text: Perfect example of “you get what you pay for”. Less than a half even worked.  No worth returning.

title: Calculator
text: Simple but efficient. Great value and easy to use.

title: Super little printer
text: This most affordable small size printer is A #1.  Highly recommend.

title: Printer won't recognize after firmware update.
text:
We've purchased this product 4x. First 2 worked great. Second 2 sets, Epson.6100 will not.recognize as full after newest firmware update- started with Magenta.

Hours spent troubleshooting machine did nothing to resolve issue, has to be ink cartridge chip coding issue.

title: Versatile, Mobile, Extra workspace
text:
So, I work out of a computer armoire at home for extra physical security of my modem, as I dont have an entire spare room for an office ... but I wanted/needed more space. Of course, I wanted something versatile and mobile as well.
This does item does the trick.

title: Palm-a -Saurus
text: It was cool 100 years ago.

title: Keep It In Your Wallet or Purse Cuz It Might Work!
text: I guess it works. Haven't been RF burglarized (I think...) but ...... how do you tell?

title: The Sharpie as Root of Life
text: You can write right. You can write left. You can write up. You can write down. There is no limit to what the Sharpie can do! And if it says RED -- you can be sure your writing will be RED!!! What more could you want?!?!

title: Shredder Essentials? HAHAHA
text:
Two sheets made it strain a bit. I wouldn't try 6. Put a defunct credit card in and the fun began!!! It jammed and got about 1/3 of the credit card in before stopping entirely. I had to pull a partially shredded card out and decided to just forget cards in the future.

Tried to use this demon machine again and sparks, pops and smoke flew out the back! One sheet of paper and now the machine will not stop. Forward or reverse. It runs continually now. I've unplugged it and will only TRY to use it again for paper and have to plug it in, put switch to 'run' and turn off and unplug when finished.

Emailed customer service and have yet to receive a response.

DO NOT BUY THIS TRASH. SPEND A COUPLE OF EXTRA BUCKS AND BUY A REAL SHREDDER -- NOT A FIRE HAZARD!!!

title: Four Stars
text: Pretty good little paper shredder for the price. Effective and light weight.

title: It is what I wanted
text: I would have given this a higher rating but they forgot some of the hardware.  Amazon is unable to send missing parts.  It was ez to assemble.  Amazon did give me a credit.

title: made for a man with a skinny butt
text: This is made for a man with a skinny butt. It feels awkward, uncomfortable and if you have a butt your butt cheeks hang over the sides. Which leaves marks and will pinch

title: NOT for low vision
text:
I have low vision and worked hard to make these work for me. A complete waste of hours and hours of my time. The instructions even on the website leave out things you have to do to install a directory let alone how to access it in an easy way.
The screen letters are very hard to see even with my 10 X loupe. The keys do not light up brightly.
After days and days of trying I am returning them.

title: Beautiful but a little difficult
text: Love this bouquet but it's a bit  difficult to get it to setup.  Love the overall idea and quality.  Pretty flowers.

title: Totally rigid
text: I obviously didn't like this one bit because I returned it immediately!  Looking for comfort, got a booster seat!

title: Ink leaked all over the place
text: Once I cleaned off all the ink from my hands, dress, and the surrounding area, the cartridges did what they were expected to do.  Probably won't order remanufactured ink cartridges again.

title: Useful to keep all your passwords together
text:
This is a useful book for those who like to write down their passwords and other important information. There are a couple extra pages in the front for contacts (2 pages) and software licenses (1 page), and ISP/wifi info (1 page).

The cover feels nice and the elastic band is useful for keeping it closed. There is also a little "envelope" pocket on the back cover, but I'm not sure what to put in there. Maybe business cards? TBD. But a nice touch, I suppose.

title: Decent printer…if you can get it set up
text:
I had quite a bit of trouble getting this installed. It comes with a USB stick with drivers and an app, which is nice. Installing the drivers for this printer somehow messed with the drivers of my regular printer, which was frustrating. I had to uninstall and reinstall this printer first and then my regular printer. It sounds straightforward, but there was a bit of troubleshooting involved before I figured it all out.

All that said, once you get it set up and working, it's great. It prints really fast, which I wasn't expecting as this is my first thermal label printer. The printing is clear and high quality. I was between giving this 3 stars and 4 stars, but once I got it going, I didn't have any problems. So 4 stars it is.

**Importantly: this doesn't come with any label paper, so be sure to get your own.

title: Simple but nice
text:
As a tip: I got this card to give on Valentine's day, but unfortunately it came bent--so leave time to get another one just in case!

In terms of the card itself, it's good. A little simple. The design on the front and the inside leaves a little to be desired, but I do appreciate that there isn't a lot of text inside so that I can write my own note. The card itself is on the smaller size; approximately the size of a standard pen. Not my favorite, but also not the worst.

title: A joy to write with! And it hasn't leaked!
text:
This is a high quality fountain pen. I've tried some of the cheaper ones (Pilot Metropolitan, Pilot Varsity), and while they were good, this is leaps beyond. The pen is a little heavy, which I appreciate, but not so heavy that is interferes with writing.

The ink flow is constant, and maybe a little thick. I'd guess that it's around a 0.8 or 0.9. The pen also comes with 3 ink cartridges (2 black and 1 blue) and an ink converter. One I was a little confused on how to install the ink, but you just need to push the cartridge down (harder than I expected) into the feed.

On my particular pen, one of the 2 feed pieces broke off, but I was still able to get the ink cartridge installed. Fortunately I haven't had any leaks (a problem I've had in the past), but will keep an eye on it.

Everything comes packaged in a nice black storage box, which is a nice touch.

title: Good Gel Pens! But doesn't dethrone the champ
text:
My go-to gel pen is the Sarasa Clip 0.7 Retractable. It's the gold standard for me. So naturally, I was excited to see how they compare. And they compare pretty well. Both pens write very smoothly and unless you are a very discerning user of pens, you probably wouldn't notice the difference in a blind test.

I'll discuss some of the differences between these and the Sarasa pens below. Overall, my critiques are minor.

First, it's the construction of the pen. These pens feel less polished--a little cheaper. The barrel is larger and not tapered anywhere, and the shirt clip feels like a solid block of plastic, whereas the Sarasa has a bit of a taper and is more molded. Next, it’s the smoothness of the pen. While both these and the Sarasa are very smooth, when you use them back-to-back (as I did to test these), the Sarasa is noticeably smoother. Also, the black ink in these pens fades a little and doesn't stay as black as the Sarasas.

title: A nice notebook that shows too many fingerprints….
text:
This is a good notebook. Quality construction, 100 gsm paper, a nice closing band and bookmark.

What bothers me about this notebook is that it is a fingerprint magnet. The pics don't quite capture the extent of it, but there are fingerprints all over. It's possible it wouldn't be as visible with another color, but on the blue, the fingerprints/oil are quite visible.

There is a name page at the front and the paper in the book is all uniform and clean (i.e., no smudged dots that I saw).

title: It will staple what it says. The first one ...
text: It will staple what it says. The first one I ordered after a week of use the black guard that hooks to the front of the staple cradle fell off. Sent it back for a replacement and about 2 weeks the same thing happened!! So now when you have to fill it hopefully you have a small screwdriver to pry it out. Not going to bother returning it again because fear it will happen a 3rd time

title: Nice set for price
text: This was a gift and when it arrived one of the pencils was broken.  Ordered the second set and it was delivered without any damage.  The person who received them was very pleased with the quality and usability.

title: Cover color is not as vibrant a “Sky Blue” as I expected; pages are darker; binder is non-standard
text: The current price of $9.99 is competitive for a diary notebook like this. I like the design and the fact that the pages can be removed and replaced. I also like the cord closure with a leaf emblem. What I do not like is that the notebook cover is a lot less vibrant than pictured on the Amazon site. Also, I thought the pages were going to be lighter but they are darker than I expected. The paper is easy to write on though. This is a non-standard six-ring binder, so special paper will have to be purchased when a replacement is needed.  Had I known the color was not as pictured and the paper was darker than pictured, I would not have ordered this. Other than this, it is very functional and although the cover is not leather, it is attractive and sturdy.

title: Large footrest; can be used to rock back and forth
text:
This footrest is larger than I expected and actually works well to raise my feet under my desk during long bouts of sitting. As long as my chair is not low to the ground it works well. There are nubs on one side that feel great on bare feet or feet with socks on. If I put the round side down, I can use it as a rocking footrest.

The cover can be unzipped and washed.

Note if one has enough room, this can be used to prop the feet up when on the toilet. It can also be used to lean against the lumbar region, although it is a bit large for that.

The current price of $39.99 is a bit pricey but is still comparable to what is on the market today.

title: Works as designed & comes with touchless keychain tool
text:
There is one padded and nicely sewn shopping cart handle cover in this package along with a touchless keychain tool.

The handle cover will fit most shopping carts and is wide enough for protection. It is Velcroed in place as can be seen in my photos. The photos show this installed on a BJs cart. Note that it is easy to forget this on the cart, however. I like how it keeps an icy handle away from my hands in the winter.

The touchless keychain tool has a rubberized tip to punch numbers on a keypad, etc. and keep one's hands away from touching things. It also has an indentation that enables certain bathroom handles to be lifted without touching them.

In my opinion, this will contaminate their hands after using these items just by removing the handle cover or holding the keychain tool. However, if this gives one peace of mind, then it is worth it. I personally like it to cover cold shopping cart handles.

The current price of $7.99 is reasonable for this.

title: Scale not sensitive enough to register letters; 2 half-dead AAA batteries & Type C USB cable incl
text:
In the box is the scale with the reader attached via a cord, an instruction sheet, two half-dead AAA batteries, a USB Type C cable (if one does not want to use the batteries), a tape measure, two screws with plastic mollies, and a paper nail guide if securing this. Although this says it is a postal scale, it is really for packages because it does not register letters. I even tried weighing a full cup of coffee and the scale stayed at zero whether I had it on kg or lb and oz.

There is a TARE button to zero out the scale in case a container is used and I only want to weigh what's inside the container. There is also a hold button to hold the weight on the screen temporarily. There are also three units of measurement - kilogram, pounds, and pounds and ounces. I cannot attest to the accuracy of this scale but it seems to be correct because my cat is the 8+ pounds specified.

In summary, I think this is a good package weighing postal scale that is simple to operate and has all the features needed to weigh large items like boxes and luggage, supposedly up to 440 pounds. It could probably even weigh a human. Also, the current price of $44.99 ($49.99 minus $5) is competitively priced.

title: Roll organizer for foil, wax paper, & plastic wrap but awkward to thread; magnets weak
text:
This organizer holds three rolls and has three rods inside. I use it for my foil, plastic wrap, and wax paper. The design is nice and it has three holes on the back for hanging this on the wall. Three screws with plastic mollies are included. There are stickers provided if one wants to name their compartments but I find that is not needed. The cutters work well.

There are only two negatives with this. First, the magnets are not strong at all. If I accidently turn this the wrong way, the door opens up. Second, the rolls are initially difficult to feed through the holes--particularly the foil. I actually had to use a tweezer to pick the ends of the rolls through. This is going to be typical of all roll organizers like this. However, what is not typical is that this only has one door for all compartments and that means all three rolls have to be fed through every time one roll is changed. I have another organizer similar to this that does not have rods inside and it is easy to use because each compartment can be changed separately.

The current price of $25.19 is competitively priced.

title: Good protection for little fingers; versatile; pricey
text: This is one of those simple but nifty inventions that make me say to myself "Why didn't I think of that." There are four foam door stoppers in this package. Each one has a little wedge that can be used to stick the entire door stop to the wall to act as a foam bumper to prevent a door handle from hitting the wall. This is also great to keep spaces between the doors. All I had to do was remove the wedge and slip the foam around the door (see photo).  These are excellent for protection from closing little fingers in doors. However, the current price of $8.99 ($9.99 minus 10%) is a bit too pricey for this as it comes to $2.25 per stopper. I do not feel this should be priced at more than $6 as I doubt it takes more than $2 to make the entire set.

title: Huge, sturdy book stand but cannot hold super large books; plastic holders weakest point
text:
This book stand is huge compared to two others I purchased a while ago. I have a  plastic book stand [[ASIN:B005IV6U0U like this one]] and a decorative vintage-looking metal bookstand similar to [[ASIN:B07L4D3THG this one]]. However, none of them satisfy every book scenario and size, which is why I ordered this.

This stand is excellent and has a very large footprint but does not support large books that are large like this [[ASIN:0764557343 Professional Chef]] book or an unabridged dictionary. With these enormous books--books over 800 pages, the stand collapses even if tightened (see photo) and the book tilts the stand to the point that it is falling over while collapsed (see photo).

However, these do hold most books including small ones. They also hold small computers, like my 14" LG. The only negative I found is that the plastic holders in front feel like they can easily break. It is also hard to seat those arms into position. Nevertheless, this stand is excellent even though it is not perfect. Everything is well made except for the plastic holders which feel cheap.

It also comes with an instruction pamphlet and instructions on how to adjust the friction hinge with the supplied wrench to loosen or tighten the unit. The current price of $39.50 is expensive but competitively priced. Note that the "findthisbest" website rates this book stand in the 11th place out of 22 book stands they rated in their "Best Adjustable Desktop Book Stands" article.

title: These markers do not glide well and are too dry
text: I should have known better than to order these for the current low price of $2.99. There are six highlighters in six muted colors in this package. They work like regular highlighters similar to Sharpies in that they do not cover the text being highlighted. However, these do not glide on easily and they are very dry. To me, they are almost ready to throw out straight out of the box. These will only last a few uses before I have to get rid of them. I am disappointed in the quality.

title: Totally does not work & they shipped 3 of the same size
text:
[[VIDEOID:859525fbffa5aab65b86b6747e35198]] This seemed like a great idea so I ordered a set of three that are supposed to come in three different sizes of small, medium, and large. Instead, I received three of the same size. This is total garbage. These do not work. In the photo, they have this placed in the centerfold of the book. I should have known better than to order these. Buyer BEWARE. At the current price of $12.98, this is an expensive mistake. This is another item for the garbage.

Note that these can be used to slip one's finger through the hole (if it fits the thumb), to hold the book open while reading. However, that is not what this is advertised as. Also, I can hold a book with my hands and have no desire to have something on my thumb when reading as that will hurt after extended periods of reading.

title: Attractive COVID vaccination card protector with hole for lanyard or clip (NOT INCLUDED)
text: This card is designed specifically for a vaccination card. It fits my COVID vaccination card perfectly. The green holder is super attractive but is a bit large to fit in a wallet. I put this in my wallet but it is one that should be used with a lanyard or some sort of clip and hung around one's neck or clipped to one's outfit. Note that no lanyard or clip are included.
