I like the rubber ring where the pen sits on fingers - so much more comfortable.  super easy to use and so far - it is a pleasure to use: ink flow easily, no leakage detected and nice to see the option of different color ink.  I only wished they provided a refillable ink plunger so I can minimize the plastic utilization.

title: love these folders to help my disorganized paper state!
text: I need as much help with my paperwork organization. I have over 15 years of paper work to go through and these folders are supposed to help me organize year and types of paperwork that I strip need to keep.  Although eventually I hope to start scanning them.  Until then, I need folders that will force me to start filling paperwork away as they come through the front door.  These are simple and well made folders that can hold up to large volume of paper - folding spine.  Love the color option to help identify the categories.

title: great for managing anxiety and depression
text: The layout of the journal is great and I love the goals section to motivate and to start someone on the path of achieving their goals.  Definitely useful for those who are dealing with anxiety and depression as it helps to break down any projects and prioritize the important tasks.  There is ample space for each day to do a list.  The paper quality is good that you can use ink pens.  The main thing I didnt love about this journal is the hardcover - just made it more bulky than necessary.

title: functional and good value.
text: It is not a high end product like other known brands - thinner and slight rough feel.  But I love it as it works for what I need them for, which is related to learning music theory - or any study cards.  It is thinner than other brands - so thick felt pens might bleed to other side - use accordingly.  for value - it is great.

title: plenty of space for planning/to-do lists
text: love the weekly planner and given the dimensions - there is plenty of space to detail appointments, to-do lists, etc.  the quality of the paper is good too and if you like ink or thick felt pen to write - there is not too much bleeding onto the next page. I prefer to write in pencil and erasing does not damage the paper.  I use these planners as part of cognitive behavior therapy - really helps to manage anxiety and much better than using digital calendars.

title: good upgrade from epson home and wish there were more improvements
text:
We have a number of Epson home printers and this is the first one that has ink tank and geared towards small businesses.
This is an upgrade from our Epson home printer and the upgrades that we liked included:
1. the scanning is now just one button [not 2!], no longer need a CD to load the software - access via internet;
2. the print quality is noticeably better and faster;
3. the print from the ipads, android, IOS was easy and seamless! you do need to leave the printer in 'sleep' mode, otherwise you would need to switch the printer on;
4. the scanning [above 250 bpi] is good, but i preferred the 600 bpi option as it gave the cleanest scan, and it did not take a long time to scan the page. I also liked the fact the scan options can be saved for different purposes. I have one for my recipes saved from magazine and it can be in color/black and white and various paper sizes that cover Us, UK, mexico!;
5. very easy to empty the ink into the tank, and the connections are different for each color so there is no possibility of putting the wrong ink color in the tank! good design. the tank is easy to see the level of each ink color. We haven't see the ink being sold yet, and curious to see the price and whether the back ink will be sold separately as week, as we print more in black&white; and
6. set up was easy and straight forward.

what we dont like:
1. even in the older home model the paper tray would come out automatically and retract after printing. The print tray is manual, and we ended up leaving it 50% pulled out and it worked to keep the paper from falling onto the floor;
2, the screen went smaller! not that you can't still use the touch screen, but still - not that expensive to have a larger screen to make the touch more comfortable.
3, for a small business focused printer - it would be good to see a double sided scanner feed option. the feeder only allowed one sided scanning and printing. despite there is option for two sided printing option - only possible if you are using the manual scanning screen option.

we didnt try the fax option, but we look forward to see the ink saving. This is a good upgrade for home use as well as fro small business use. The price of this printer is really covering the ink cost, whilst a nice upgrade from our Epson home printer. Funny, this printer is super light versus our home printer.

title: brings me joy
text: even with all the electronics I still like to hand write all my lists.  A week is covered on two sides of this book and I am using it to document my piano practice.  it is a lovely folio, and there are 2 ribbon placement markers.  I just love the feel, color and pattern: it gives me joy as I document my practice.  The book can be removed and be replaced: hence the polio can be repurposed.  Definitely good quality that I can use this folio for many years; I didnt wan something that was flimsy and a throw away.

title: Great scanner, the hinge accommodates for very thick text books.
text:
Why buy a single scanner rather than a combo scanner and printer? I have to scan scores from big and thick music piano books. And this scanner has a hinge that allows for easy and flat scan. I love it! The software also allows you to scan more than one page at a time, again great for music scores. I also wanted a portable scanner to scan family albums than are with other family members. This scanner is so light, I am surprised. The scanner also allows you to scan to print, which is great feature.
The one star off is beca use we are having problems getting the buttons to work on the scanner. The software was easy to install on our HP laptop. Yes, the HP is using the 8.1 latest sofware. We believe the value of the scanner is good for what we want to use it for.

title: Small footprint and packed with functionalities: great for home use in apartment.  Can use with Android tablet, as well as Apple
text:
over the years we have had many brands that include Hp Envy, Cannon for home use. We are quite surprised how compact this Epson Expression printer is by both size and buckets of functionalities. The foot print is small in terms of both height and foot print. this is really essential for us in apartment living as we are always looking for ways to be more efficient with our space.

so, in terms of ease of use for those, who like me wants everything to work first time!. I was surprised how easy it was to install the software onto our main computer [Apple Mac]. no hiccups there.

the next biggest use is printing. What I loved was that there seems to be no set up at the appliance end. i.e. I printed from both my iPad and android tablet: both recognized it and printed with ease. this was from pdfs and photos and web sites.

scanning to the computer had an initial hiccup in recognizing the computer, but you can scan to multiple devices like a thumb drive, which is what I ended up doing. the scan quality was pretty good for color.

love the multi-feed for this little printer, and i was surpassed by the quietness in which it printed and nothing shook as it did its job.

The touch screen is really easy to use and not complicated. and you can always hit the home icon to get back to the start.

we tested a color photo, it was okay, but we prefer using a dedicated single photo printer; as when you pack to much in a printer, something has to give a little; even though technology has improved so much in the home printer space.

For general home use. we loved this new compact printer. and the price is very reasonable for all the functionalities. As people has mentioned before, it is the cost of the ink that makes usage expensive.

title: Nada, the green plastic mount was off putting,
text: Love the idea, but I don't love how it looks..a tacky green mount.  However, I like the white plastic cards that work well.  I use the white cards for reminders for me, which I use magnetic mounts.  Shame.

title: The brand looks different
text: They keep changing their looks!  So I had to scribble quite a bit to see if it is the same pen that I loved...sort of, and need a work in before the ink flowed smoothly.

title: 10 ft square and small bubbles
text: I was a little surprised that it was actually 10feet square in total size and small bubbles.  I guess at that price, I should have known better.  Description needs to be mproved on this item.

title: Works for vents that pulls air out (bathrooms and kitchen)
text:
This product worked great for vents that pull air OUT of the room: bathrooms and kitchens. We live in a co-op and we have hurricane charlie in our bathrooms, that not only is it noisy when the vent is on during the day, the pull of the air pressure also pulls a lot of dust into the bathrooms. So I am constantly wipping down everything - hard work. The strips are easy to cut to size and it allowed me to regulate the amount of air being pulled out of the room: now I get the ventilation I need without all the dust being pulled into the room. When the vent is switched off in the evening .. the magnetic piece held up the strip very well - I did not need to worry of it falling off.

We will now paint the strip to match the color of the bathrooms so it is not so noticable!

title: Great gift
text: Great product

title: Good
text: Good 😌

title: Great value
text: Great chair

title: Ok
text:
Ok pens
Big Atlantis brand are still my Favorite

title: Beautiful
text:
Loved these cards but $5.50 a piece they were pricey !
I would’ve love to get a box of 20, but I can’t spend $100

title: Awesome
text: Heavy & super looking

title: Won’t buy again
text: Broke cheaply made

title: Very disappointed!
text: Every single one of these leak at the bottom corners and now useless. I had not used them yet. Too late to return as well.

title: Way too heavy for me
text: These are soooo heavy that I can't even imagine carrying my keys on one of them.  Heavy and clunky.  I was not pleased and ended up returning them.  Which was an easy process and the seller was quite gracious.

title: 1 week in
text: We had this for a week before the cloth "hinge"(I'm not sure what to call it) came off. It doesn't even look like it was torn, it just came off and I can't get it back on. What a bummer.

title: Came torn
text: Not worth the money -- will be returning.

title: Zero Stars
text: The entire box arrived with the ink level at half gone. Low odor is a joke!!! Instant headache when I pulled the cap off. The teacher would be upset if I sent these in. Wish zero stars was available!

title: Pens came w no magnets
text: Cute, but the pens came with the magnets missing.  I expected a new undamaged item.

title: Fake reviews. This item is a P.O.S.
text: This P.O.S. jams up every other envelope. These have to be fake reviews. Theres no way this many people think this P.O.S. is worth the money. I would not and will recommend or buy any more amazon branded garbage.

title: Nice set. The darker colors are really dark
text: Nice set.  The darker colors are really dark. 4 stars because there's a few colors I don't like.  Could of been a few more brite colors.

title: Doesn't show what type of puppy is in each picture.
text: Doesn't say what kind of puppies they are.  Would be be 4 stars if it said that.

title: Super Cute!
text: Perfect gift for that dog lover!

title: Sad that the eraser will not stay out of the chamber
text: The eraser will NOT stay put!  It keeps dropping back into the plastic chamber that holds it, and I have to keep clicking to get it back out!

title: Easier than wedge
text: As a teacher I’m opening and closing my door constantly. I like this better than the typical wedge. Easier to use and stays put!

title: Too large envelopes make the set seem cheap
text: Cards were nice, but envelopes were huge! They look cheap because of that. I tried to return, but it cost half the price to send them back - very disappointed!!

title: Too small to read in a classroom :(
text: Too small to read in a classroom.

title: Tapevconstantly broke and then you would have to find the ...
text: Tapevconstantly broke and then you would have to find the broken end would just had stuck to the row to start over it. I think the tape was too thin

title: Works good
text: Works good but isn’t very thick so it’s not a high quality but does the job for the price.

title: Worthless
text: What a waste of money. When you take the cap off the glue starts oozing out. When I tried to apply it it quit coming out and I could not get any more so that I could do the job. It's like they sent a mostly empty bottle of glue.

title: What a waste of money
text: I was barely able to get some glue out of the bottle to glue something and that was it. All four bottles wouldn't dispense the glue. Total waste of money.

title: OK only
text: Beautiful color but kind of cheap in the end.  I bought two of these but after less than six months, it's probably time for a new chair.

title: Get another chair
text: You get what you pay for....and a little less.  The sides are sight and the hydraulics begin to break after a while.  Beautiful color, however!

title: My markers didn't work.
text: Markers were dried out and didn't show up. Tried to return and not returnable. Very disappointed.

title: Okay
text: This sticker paper worked all right. It printed well, but it didn’t cut well for things that had a lot of tiny little pieces. It cut better and bigger, less Detailed pieces.

title: Not Super Sharp Images
text: This sticker paper is pretty good. The matter finish absorbs the ink a little, so the image isn't as sharp on this paper as it is on other papers. But overall, a pretty decent sticker paper.

title: Too Short
text: These are just too short. They need to be slightly longer to fit the hand better. As they are, they’re just not super usable. The thickness is perfect. The triangular shape is good. But they start out an inch too short for a comfortable grip— even in a kid’s hand.

title: Better Quality
text: We loved the idea of pencils that lasted! These are better quality than the ones we tried previously, though still not super great quality. But these, at least, all hold together. The bottoms are an eraser, even though it doesn’t look like it. Zero sharpening!  A no mess pencil!

title: They Changed The Holidays
text:
Happy Planner always annoys me with their calendar start days. On the month view, the week starts on Sunday. But on the week view, they start the week on Monday. That always drives me a little batty. They never put all of anyone’s holidays on the calendar either. If you’re Jewish, some of those holidays are there and others aren’t. If you’re Christian, some of the holidays are marked, some are not. They have added more secular holidays to this newest version, but not all of them. I wish they’d stop adding holidays at all and let me add those I celebrate.
I love the snap on covers. You can easily change the cover without getting a whole new planner.
Don’t want an 18 month planner? Just remove the months you don’t want. Love the way you can customize the pages. Love the dividers. The rings can also be reused year to year.

title: Great In Theory
text: My kids were super excited about these! And they are great in theory, but these seem a little poorly made. On a couple of them, the nibs broke or fell off on the first use. For others, they’ve held up great and are just as sharp as when we got them. So they’re a little hit or miss there. The end is an eraser.

title: Tons of Pens
text: I love the stand. It makes it so easy to keep everything organized. The pens were hit or miss though. Some were extremely smooth and perfect. Others were very scratchy and skipped.

title: Smell Is Off
text: Like most smell products, they don’t all smell exactly as they should. Some smell a little gross. But overall, they work. Decent gel pens. Kids love them.

title: Wires Messed Up
text: When this arrived, the wire binding was already messed up. They are a clamp style wire binding, not a continual spiral. They just aren't great quality. The cover is a frosted clear plastic. The actual paper is okay. Not super thick, but adequate.

title: Linen Notebook
text: I'm a notebook lover, but this one just doesn't do it for me. It is just not as nice in person as it looks online. Compared to the name brand versions, this one just looks and feels much cheaper. It is a perfectly usable notebook. It isn't a bad notebook. But it just isn't a great notebook.

title: Notebooks
text: These little faux leather notebooks are cute. They work well and they look nice. They aren't the highest quality. They're definitely a step down from the name brand bullet journals, but they do work fine. The button clasp is a cute detail, but a little impractical while writing.

title: Dotted Notebooks
text: These notebooks have a frosted clear cover that is plastic. The paper is on the thin side and cream. The dots are quite dark. Most pens (including those it came with) ghost through the pages. They work best with pencil. They also don't come with the elastics attached-- you have to attach them, but that is super easy. The elastics are also very tight. Overall, it is a fine notebook, but there is nothing really special or exceptional about it. If you like dark dots-- you'll like this notebook quite a bit.

title: Cute Planner
text: This planner doesn’t hit all my planner hopes, but it is a good basic planner that doesn’t cost an arm and a leg. It definitely works and has lots of functional options. But it is fine.

title: They Work
text: These notebooks are pretty mediocre. They are, in no way, even close to comparable to the big brands of similar style. They just look cheap next to those notebooks. They're thinner than those, too. Not quite as many pages per book. They work. But they aren't the best quality.

title: Not Great
text: These pencil sharpeners are not great. They eat through batteries and don't give a smooth point. They also stop with slightly too much pressure, so they've been less than ideal for kids to use.

title: Works great!
text: It works great and feels good, and I appreciate the tear-off corners. Those along with the two place-marking ribbons are great features. The "vegan leather" cover, though, is a bit think and soft.

title: A Couple Weird Colors
text: This set looks exactly like the Zebra Mildliners. The pens are very similar, and I even like the design of these more than the Zebra pens. They'd be completely perfect, if a few of the colors weren't weird. The bright coral color was fine on the chisel tip end, but the fine point end was a dark gray color mixed with the bright coral. It has a cool effect, but definitely was not the color it should have been. If there weren't issues like that on a couple of the markers, this product would be better than the name brand, in my opinion. But with the inconsistency of color, I'd probably stick with the name brand.

title: Such Random Stickers
text: I love stickers. This set is just such a random assortment. I end up having to flip through all of them looking for that one sticker I knew came in this set. It is like you purchased someone else's leftover stickers or something. They're even random in the finish. Some are on clear paper, some are on standard white paper. I do like them. They are all pretty small so they tend to work well on calendars and planners.

title: Very Flimsy
text: This chore chart is cute and I love that it has all the little magnets with different colors for different kids. However, the chart itself is the same thickness as the other magnets. You can put it on a magnetic whiteboard for more stability. But if you just hang it by itself, it moves and bends and the magnets fall off of it. It really works better stuck to a whiteboard or fridge.

title: Pencil Sharpener
text: I’ve been trying to figure out why this pencil sharpener is so expensive. It does seem so significantly superior to all other electric pencil sharpeners. Does it work? Well, yes it does. Is it somehow magically so much better? Not that I can tell. It still has the problems of a mechanical pencil sharpener. The pencil sharpening mechanism is deeper, meaning shorter pencils become trash. It does have an automatic stop, but that never works with colored pencils. It does have a large shavings area, so you have to empty it less often. The sharpening hole isn’t big enough to accommodate more than a standard sized pencil. The point on the pencil isn’t better than other sharpeners. I still have issues with lead breaking with this one. It is as loud as electric pencil sharpeners usually are. It works. It is fine. I just can’t figure out why it would be any better than cheaper versions.

title: Okay Notebook
text: These travelers notebook inserts are blank. The paper isn’t particularly good. It is on the thin side. It feels about like regular printer paper. So, if you are just going to write in them with a pencil or ballpoint pen, they’re fine. If you are hoping to do art or write with a fountain pen or something fancy— these will likely make you mad. They ghost most pens. They bleed through most markers and paint instantly. These are definitely not for painting or markers! They’d be okay for collage style journaling or writing in (as long as it isn’t wetter ink products).

title: Not Very Sustained
text: These bells are hard to get a sustained “ding” on. We use them for quiz games, and if you smack it like a buzzer, it just “clinks” against the side. To get it to “ding” you have to gently tap the top, and then let go immediately. The little mechanism inside is more of a lever, than a bell I would say. So it doesn’t “ding” easily.

title: Poor Quality
text: My 9 year old always uses pencil grips. He has a hard time holding a pencil properly (ADHD). He loved having a variety of grips to choose from. Any of them work well for him. He just needs a physical reminder of how to hold the pencil. But these are much more cheaply made than other grips we have had. They work fine, but if you have a sensory seeking kid— they don’t last long!

title: Plastic
text: The top of this is not wood. It is plastic molded to look like wood. The stuffing is also pretty low. I didn’t find it to be a good height or really able to adjust well because of how the filling is done and distributed. The cup holder is the size of a can. So it won’t hold a coffee cup, which is what I usually have at my side. All in all, this just isn’t the best lap desk. I have had others that are much better. It works okay. But the surface isn’t smooth, so it isn’t great for writing. It doesn’t adjust to fit you super well.

title: Not The Same as The Standard
text: These are quite nice. But they aren't quite the same as my gold standard. They do have a pen loop, which I loved. The paper is decent. Pages are not numbered. No table of contents page. There is a pocket inside the back cover. It does have two ribbon markers, but they are thinner than I usually have. They work fine, though. The front page sticks a bit. It comes close to lying flat. All in all, a decent notebook.

title: Circles
text: I don’t know what magic I thought was going to happen with this. You can draw circles with it. You can draw small circles and medium circles. It is just a little bit of a fancy circle stencil. I’d prefer a compass for accurate angles. But for circles, this does work well. The circles just can’t be very big.

title: English Typos
text: These notebooks are of mediocre quality. The paper is on the thin side. They do not compare to name brand notebooks of this size. They also have serious English issues. One notebook says, "You must take your place in the circle of lifr." (You can't see the typo in the photo because the elastic strap is covering the mistaken r. Even if they had managed to spell "life" correctly, that is a very grim saying to put on a notebook. Hardly inspirational. Maybe funny if you meant it to be inspirational. One notebooks reads like a fortune cookie and says, "Sometimes empty page presents more possibilities." Probably best to skip these. Unless, of course, you're looking for a gag gift.

title: Highlighters
text: These highlighters are very vivid. They apply easily. We do have some issues with them bleeding through as they do put down a lot of ink. The purple and blue are also a bit dark for highlighting purposes. They do lighten up a little as they dry, but they're still too dark for my liking.

title: Lots of Malfunctioning
text: These pencils look nice, however, there are a few problems with them. They don't come with much lead. They erasers bend and break when trying to erase with them. They're just not firm enough or too long or something. We also have had a lot of problems with them suddenly spitting out the lead or the lead not holding properly while writing. I won't be rebuying these.

title: Came Broken
text: The back piece came broken. The instructions are very basic, but you can figure it out. Our confusion, I think, was because the back piece was broken so it looked like we had 5 shelves and 1 random plank. The shelves just slide in. The top tray holds with magnets. While that is clever, where mine is sitting, every time someone bumps it, the top bumps off because the magnets aren't very strong. It is also really big. The shelves are too narrow to label.  I'd be happier with it if it wasn't broken.

title: Super Thin
text: I really like this paper for teaching handwriting to kids. I like loose paper more than the notebooks because kids tend to want to destroy mistakes. Really, my only complaint about this paper is the thickness. It is super thin, so it tears really easily. Since it is made for small children, this is clearly a problem. It doesn't erase well, either-- because of the thinness. The paper is also about 1/2" too tall for my three-hole punch.

title: What Happened?
text: These pens used to be so awesome. The pen itself still has the same weight and feel, but the ink is completely substandard. It isn’t very pigmented and doesn’t come out of the pen very smoothly. It makes you feel like you need to bear down more to get it to write better— but that doesn’t help. It just writes very faded and not smoothly at all.

title: Super Thin
text: This paper is so super thin. It is obnoxious. It is difficult to erase because the paper is so thin. I'm also not a fan of it coming glued into a pad. I really would have preferred it to be loose.

title: Not As Great
text: I usually buy the At-A-Glance desk calendar for our family calendar. Since 2020 made me scribble out practically everything on the 2020 calendar, I thought it was awesome to have a school year version so I could go ahead and start over. This is much smaller than the one I usually buy. It is large, but not the biggest available. The paper is on the thin side, so I can't write on it with a Sharpie. One of the corner holders was missing when it arrived. The back isn't very thick. It just overall felt much cheaper than others I have used in the past.

title: Gel Highlighter
text: I'm not a fan of gel highlighters. I want to like them. I try to like them. They don't show through thin Bible paper. I'm just not a fan of how it crumbles when you highlight with it. It isn't smooth and even when writing. It goes on with chunks like cheap crayons. I've tried various angles and pressure-- but it never goes on smooth.

title: Terrible Cards
text: These are terrible flash cards. They aren’t cards at all. They aren’t even as thick as cardstock. They feel like a cross between regular paper and construction paper. If you’re only going to write on them once and then put them away, sure they’ll work. If you actually use them to look through, they’re never going to hold up.

title: Gets Stuck
text: I like the idea of this clipboard. However, this one gets stuck when opening. It just seems to catch and rub in places. It isn’t super smooth in opening or using.

title: Print Your Own
text: I prefer the lanyard style name tags to these magnetic ones. The magnets do keep people from having to put a pin or adhesive on their clothing. However, some fabrics (like sweaters and sports coats) were a bit thick for the magnets. They held well on t-shirts and button-up shirts. Overall, though, I'd choose the lanyard style over these.

title: Giant Calendar
text: This calendar is excellent for long term planning sessions. When thinking through planning the whole year, especially in a meeting setting, this calendar is great. However, for everyday use, I'm just not a big fan. It would be good in a classroom, but it is really not the best for keeping track of things on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis. It is just awesome for long term planning sessions.

title: Pencils
text: These pencils are not sharpened. They are just basic pencils. These used to be nicer. The wood is a little tougher and more difficult to sharpen than they used to be. It just feels like they’ve gone down in quality. They’re usable. They’re fine. They work. They just don’t seem as high quality as they used to.

title: Not Durable
text: These pencils are a great price. I like the amount you get. The quality, well, these seem a little more prone to having issues than other mechanical pencils at their price point. They look higher end, but the break pretty easily. They also have tiny erasers. These aren’t the best for younger kids.

title: Cute Calendar
text: I love the size and look of this planner. The paper is really nice. The set up of this calendar is a bit weird. All of the monthly spreads are up front. All of the weekly spreads are in the back. I actually like that set up, so it isn’t a problem, but it is unusual. The weekly are two weeks per spread, one week per page. My real problem is layout. The weeks on the monthly spreads begin properly on Sundays. Then you turn to the weekly spreads and suddenly weeks begin on Monday. I’m a firmly Sunday week start person, so Monday week starts are a complete dealbreaker for me.

title: Pretty
text: This glass dip pen is so lovely. I love the way it puts ink on paper. I mostly use it for drawing because you do have to dip it into the ink pretty often. The only thing I dislike is how difficult it is to clean the ink from the tiny grooves toward the tip.

title: Thin Paper
text: This is a very basic calendar. It is full sized. The paper is really thin and my pens ghost and bleed pretty badly. The monthly view has weeks beginning on Sunday. Weekly views begin on Monday. I hate that. There are also half the space for Saturday and Sunday, which is unfortunate for me since those are the busiest days of my week. There are no notes sections for the week either.

title: Thin Paper
text: This is a pretty basic planner. Not a lot of bells and whistles. The paper is a little on the thin side. Also, the monthly calendar has weeks that begin on Sunday, but the weekly view begins the week on Monday. I hate it when calendars do that. There is also half the space available for Saturday and Sunday, which is unfortunate since those are my busiest days of the week.

title: Fun, But Not Fantastic
text: This pen has a very wide nib. It comes with a disposable ink cartridge with black ink. It is a little on the scratchy side, which makes the writing a little less smooth. This would be great to learn with, but it isn't going to give you nice, smooth results. Your lines will be a little bumpy and scratchy. It isn't a bad pen, it just has limitations. If you're just wanting a calligraphy pen to play around with, this pen is great. If you're more serious about your lettering, you'll likely be disappointed.

title: Invisible Mess
text: These do work. They have a glow in the dark ink that you can only see with the special light. However, one of the pens (who knows which one) busted while in shipping and everything was covered in invisible ink. You can feel it on you, but can only see it with the light. It is like an old episode of Room Raiders trying to figure out what you got invisible ink on before you realized you were smearing invisible fluorescent fluid on everything in sight. The kids do like them. I'm not liking having to check for invisible graffiti.

title: Not for Cardstock
text: Printer works well on standard paper. Card stock is another issue entirely- it isn’t good on card stock. But it prints very quickly on standard paper.

title: Leather Folder
text: This folder is really pretty. However, the leather is so stiff- it makes this a little bit difficult to use. Cards are a tight fit, so it is hard to get business cards to fit. I think it isn’t as useful as it could be because the pockets are tight with really stiff leather. But the folder looks super nice.

title: Not My Favorite
text: I think I am just not a fan of this style of correction tape. The white strips tend to run off the side of the applicator if you aren’t being super slow and super careful. They are also pretty thin, so I find for my “normal” sized writing, the strip doesn’t cover it. I’ve also had some issues with the white strip moving after I have applied it. Like, shifting around.

title: Hard To Use
text:
I'm a planner junky. This planner has some good parts, but some glaring flaws. The good first:
I like the amount of space in each day. You have two columns on a page. You can either plan for two people (or split your work and personal planning in a side by side manner) for 12 hours (beginning at 7). OR you could plan out the entire 24 hours, using one column for day hours and the other for night hours. Each daily page has a small calendar at a glance at the top of the page for the current month, previous month, and next month. The days are numbered with the current day of the year and how many days are left in the year (3/363, 151/214, 289/76, etc.) This does contain the entire year. The last pages is a three year at a glance calendar. It does list holidays on the pages. It does lay completely flat when open.
Now, the glaring problems. There are no tabs, so finding a given month to jot something on the calendar isn't quick. Sundays do not get a full day. The bottom of Saturday is cut short at 11 hours instead of 12 hour and you get 4 blank lines for Sunday. If you have busy weekends, this may not work at all. (Which is pretty much where I found myself.) There are no transitions between months. No monthly calendar at all. There is only a tiny space (2 lines) to write non- time specific items. You could put washi tape over all the times and just write in whatever you want. My other issue is the inconsistency in the start of the year and end of the year. The calendar starts on January 1st. Which is a Tuesday. No Sunday and Monday for that week is included. You just start your new calendar on Tuesday. But it doesn't end the same way. You would think if they chose to stick to only 2019, the calendar would also end on a Tuesday, December 31st, right? Nope. It ends on January 3rd, which is a Friday. It didn't even finish that week. Just added three extra days at random. That completely bothers me.

title: Big & Lined
text: I had the unlined version for 2018, and I think I prefer the unlined version. It gives me more freedom to write in all the things I need to write in. The lines kind of dictate how large I'll write and how much I can fit in. I hang mine on the wall. I love the plain paper that lets me write with any pen, pencil, or marker. It is very plain, so your plans and writing stand out. No frills. Just a big calendar with plenty of space to write down what you need to write down.

title: Flimsy
text: I’m a calendar junkie. I cannot resist a well made calendar. This one is not too impressive. The pages are thin and glossy. There is no cover or back to hold it more sturdily. It has a piece of cardboard in the package, but it is not attached to the calendar. The boxes are pretty small and the glossy paper limits your pen options. There is a pocket on each month, which I like, but due to the flimsiness of the entire calendar, you can’t put much in the pocket. The wall hanger portion like to move around and will fall out of the coil if you are not careful. The paper really needs to be thicker for this style to work. It really needs to be thicker to be a wall calendar. The colors are nice, but the flimsy paper makes it unusable for me.

title: Cute Set
text: This set has several Journaling items. You have some washi Tape, stickers, die cuts, paper clips, and book marks along with a journal and a pen. The supplies themselves are pretty sub par. You definitely get better quality buying each item individually at a craft store. But as a set, this is cute. Plus the box is a storage box for stationary items. As a gift, it is really cute. My 12 year old loved it. It is definitely more geared toward tweens and young teens.

title: Poorly Planned
text:
I am a planner lover. This planner is such a let down. I’ll walk you through it, but this is not ever a planner I would recommend.
This is a premade planner that is undated. All the pages have a set function, but you fill in the dates for yourself. The cover is hardback with a leatherlike feel. It has three bookmarks sewn into the binding. It is bigger than a standard size bullet journal, but more narrow than an Erin Condren style planner.
The elastic band to hold the planner shut is far too tight. It is very difficult to get it around the planner brand new. As my planners fill up, they bulk up. This elastic has no hope of being at all useful for long. And it really is difficult to get it around the planner.
The cover of the planner is marked. It has a tree and says “productivity planner”. I would like the cover blank or with just the tree.
Each section of the planner (monthly, weekly, and daily) is in its own section. It is not lined up with the month, weeks, and days together for the month. You’ll have three separate places in the planner to flip. This isn’t a problem for me, I actually set my bullet journal up in a similar way.
There are twelve monthly spreads, 2 pages per month. A typical monthly calendar layout with weeks beginning on Sunday. There is a side bar for notes. Across the bottom of each month, you have 4 boxes with numbered entries. There are 5 numbered lines for : goals, priorities, accomplishments, and knowledge gained. You could put washi tape over the headers and make these fit your life better.
Then you reach the weekly section. Only 23 weekly spreads. Not sure how that math works out. The weekly spreads have specific boxes on a two page spread. You have room for 5 successes and 5 improvements each week. A small box with new skills to acquire. A small box to focus on. You have a very specific list of plans for your week: about me, work, family & friends, and relationship. Then you have five project boxes to fill in. And five goals for the week.
Then you get to your daily pages. No, there are not enough for the entire year. There are enough (plus a couple extra) for those 23 weeks if you only fill them out Monday to Friday. Each two page daily spread has a schedule for the day where you write in the time and task. There is a small space for a daily to-donlist and a small box where you write in why today is special. So specific. You also list your top five priorities of the day, your affirmations, and what you are grateful for.
At the end you have a few pages of mind maps and vision boards. This planner is so specific, while leaving you to fill in the dates. I feel like it is trying to be the Passion Planner, but it isn’t the Passion Planner. It is also poorly planned. Either give me 52 weekly spreads OR 365 daily spreads. Don’t give me an inadequate number of both.
The paper is fine. A little on the thin side for a planner, so ghosting and bleed through can definitely be a problem.

title: Field Notebook
text: This field notebook is not typical field book size. When I think field book, my brain says 3x5. This book is 5x8. The cover is nice and durable. Cardstock, but with a nice texture and finish that keeps it looking pretty good. It has math helps and notes inside the front covers. I don’t use my field books for actual engineering purposes, so all of that is a waste for me. The paper is a nice thickness. I had minimal ghosting and no bleed through, even when using a Sharpie. One side of the page is little rectangular boxes. The other side is larger. So, each two page spread, you get both. Really, my only complaint is that this book hates being open. It doesn’t lay flat. It takes a lot of bending and breaking the cover in to get it to open well enough to use the whole page well. And then once you get the cover broken in, it doesn’t like fully closing. The pages are sewn together, though the cover is glued on. So the pages don’t fall out with all the breaking in.

title: Guided Math Workshop
text: This book is intended for classroom use. I am a homeschool mom, not a teacher. This book is reproducible for classroom use. This is a system to model math in a classroom setting. You can adapt this for homeschool. There are worksheets that are used in conjunction with a rotation through math stations. The worksheets don't give very much practice. I don't find this to be meaty enough to be a math curriculum by itself. However, it is too much to be a supplement. In a classroom setting, I can see it working. But it the homeschool setting, it just doesn't have much of a use unless you do a "school at home" approach to your homeschool, which I do not.

title: Math Workshop 5
text:
I am a homeschool mom, so I am often on the lookout for educational helps. This workbook is allowed to be reproduced in the classroom setting. The “workshop” set up is intended for classroom group work done through stations.
Each section has a an essential question, a math warm-up, a mini-lesson, “math talk” (questions to ask about solving problems), and a journaling question. You then have guided math questions and worksheets- one worksheet is recommended, one is on level but branching out a bit, and one worksheet is enrichment. All answers are in the back of the workbook.
As a homeschooler, this could be used as enrichment. You could simply take the worksheets or hands on activities and use those to supplement curriculum you’re already using. You could also use the entire model as complete curriculum. The workshop model would work just fine for one kid just like it would for 20. It is going to be pretty teacher intensive and they aren’t going to be able to complete this as a curriculum completely independently. You would still need to give the mini-lessons. But some kids do better with having someone show them and walk through it with them. You can also fold the entire thing in with your current curriculum, using this to beef up a curriculum that has a few more holes.
This book covers:
Operations (PEMDAS) and Algebraic Thinking
Number Operations in Base Ten
Number and Operations of Fractions
Measurement and Data
Geometry
There are also a few extras in the back for games you could play for a number of different skills.

title: Mediocre Set
text:
I have several hand lettering pens from various brands. This set is not my favorite. The instructional sheet is much less than helpful. I have taken a couple lettering classes and read quite a few lettering books, and these instructions sound like someone who never hand lettered anything wrote them. They tell you your paper options are wide ruled paper or grid dot paper, noting nothing about paper texture and if rough or smooth paper will work best with their markers. Just throw the instructions away.
The large black permanent marker isn’t quite black enough. One side of it has a massive chisel tip, the other side a very small marker tip. There is no normal size tip. You get jumbo or small. These all bleed through paper. Even with a light touch, the ghosting is really bad. The sides of the marker are also not labeled, so you just have to open both ends to find the tip you were looking for.
The chisel tip marker is more like a calligraphy marker. It also isn’t very black and bleeds through paper.
The 05 Fine Tip pen is similar to a micron, but the Prismacolor 05 is larger than my micron 05. It is closer to the micron 08 tip. It also bleeds through. The black on it, I think is the exact same, but looks a bit better because of the smaller size.
The brush tip is a small felt brush tip. It is not very firm at all. And it bleeds through.
The two pencils are fine, I guess. They come unsharpened. The eraser is good.
Overall the set isn’t bad, it just isn’t great. There are great products out there, these are just mediocre art supplies.

title: Good Pen
text: I really like the pen. It writes well. It is a great size point. The felt tip doesn’t feather or fall easily. My only complaint is the pen color and the ink color do not match. I would honestly rather then ink match the pen. The pen is a deep burgundy. The ink is a bright red.

title: Works Well
text: My boys love this desk. It really works well for fidgety kids who end up on the floor trying to do their school work. However, I have a couple issues with the desk. It is one solid piece. It does not fold up. It does not store in any simple or easy way. It is just there and big when not in use. Also, the table top isn't weight bearing. I'm always worrying they'll try to lay across it or sit on it in their wallowing. I'm just always reminding them not to sit or lay on the top.

title: Okay Tabs for Study or Temporary Marking
text:
I'm a school supplies fanatic. I buy and use way more stickers and tabs than a grown adult probably should. These tabs are just okay. First, the holes don't line up for my FiloFax style planner. They are 3 ring binder, mini 3 ring binder placement. So, the clip and go insn't really the case for me. The tabs themselves are really thick cardstock-like material. That makes them very easy to write on with no smearing and you can use any pen or pencil for the job. But that also means they aren't waterproof and they don't hold up extremely well for long term use. Short term, they are fine and good. The sticker part is clear, but more of a frosty matte clear. You can definitely still see it over the page, but you can read the words under it if you need to. They peel off easily and are repositionable up to a certain point. Putting them in is definitely not permanent. The sticker part of the tab is really thick and not very bendable.
You get 8 of each color of the large tabs. And 10 of each color of the small tabs.

title: Reliable Pens
text: While I like these pens, I'm not going to lie and say they are the best. They are reliable, like the Bib Crystal pen. This medium point is pretty big (1.0). The ink isn't as saturated in color as nicer pens. On paper it looks like a cheap ball point pen in color. But it is clickable, which I like. The entire outside is plastic. The grip is slightly textured, which is usually comfortable for me. (Unless I happen to quickly grab it wrong, then it isn't so comfortable.) The pens are really basic, but reliable pens.

title: Thin
text: These cards are good. They are lined on one side, blank on the other. I like the texture of the card surface, it is a little rough. The only real problem I have with the cards is that they are on the thin side. Certain pens and markers show right through because of the thinness. And they don't hold up extremely well. For my uses, they are okay, but for many, the flimsiness would be a deal breaker for these. They aren't as thick as standard cardstock, but a little heavier weight than regular paper.

title: Just Okay
text: I'm slightly obsessed with notebooks, but this one just did not meet my high expectations. The color is nice. The gold accent on the front is a nice touch. The paper is fine. It is slightly thicker than standard notebook paper, but pretty rough in feel. Not like the super nice buttery feel of nicer pressed paper. Grey lined front and back with no margin lines. The date oval only appears on the right hand pages (the front of each page). My main complaint is the finish on the cover. It looks nice and feels nice until it gets the slightest bit beat up. It just marks up way too easily. I would also like the notebook to be a bit longer and have a satin bookmark ribbon (which would be simple with the binding style). There is also nowhere to place any identification on the notebook. No place in the front cover for this book belongs to. That isn't the biggest deal. I just made a clear sticker with my name for the inside of the front cover. Honestly, I would just expect more from a notebook at this price point.

title: Not The Best
text:
I like the colors. The pink, yellow, and lime green are more of a highlighter type color. Definitely a little difficult to see. The box is super handy. Just pop the top back and you have all the colors at your fingertips. The pens are a rounded triangle, so they only fit in the box a certain way, which keeps them nice and tidy. However, there are a few things I dislike about these pens.
(1) They bleed through most paper. It isn't so bad on my Erin Condren planner. But in my journal or Bible, it is pretty significant.
(2) They are not smooth. The ink goes from barely flowing to overflowing. You have to go back over some areas. Just not the best.
(3) My black one kind of exploded ink everywhere and I had to toss it. I have no idea how it even happened. It was in the box with all the others. I opened it one day and there was black in all inside the lid and all over it. It was just a mess.
I think I am just going to go back to my felt tip pens for now.

title: Works Well
text: This is a really good size bulletin board. I also like that it isn't cork, so it doesn't fall apart. It was very easy to hang, and large enough that stuff on it isn't cramped. However, the board is dense and a little difficult to get push pins into. Not exactly a problem, since I'd rather have that than have the pins falling out. My other issue is that it looks very commercial. It looks like it belongs on the wall of a cubicle, not on the wall of my homeschool room. So, aesthetically, it is a little lacking. But functionally, it works really well, so I am happy.

title: It Works
text:
This pencil sharpener isn't impressive or fancy. It is a very simple electric sharpener. It sharpens pencils (and the instructions are very clear that it ONLY sharpens pencils. No crayons, chalk, or anything other than a pencil.)

It takes about 20 pencils sharpened to fill the shavings chamber. Definitely not for classroom or high usage.

The automatic stop function isn't really an automatic stop. It says the change in the motor will let you know it is done. It only does this on standard #2 pencils. If you're sharpening something with softer lead or colored pencils, it will just go and go and go- eating your pencil. So don't wait for the motor change on anything but a #2. It also sharpens really rough on some pencils and super smooth on others. It was super smooth when sharpening Smencils (pencils that smell made out of layers of recycled paper) but ridiculously rough on Crayola colored pencils. (But decently smooth on Crazy Art colored pencils.)

It is pretty loud. It also moves. The little gripper feet on the bottom do nothing to hold it in place. You still need to place your free hand on the sharpener to hold it in place while sharpening. You also have to grip the pencil being sharpened pretty tightly so it doesn't spin in the sharpener.

After sharpening about 50 pencils, it started squeaking slightly when you remove the pencil and the motor is stopping.

It makes teeny tiny little shavings that are obnoxious to clean up and have a tendency to "stick" to the end of the pencil, so you are constantly dealing with lead dust on the pencil end. Sharpens pencils to a finer point than I prefer (but all X-Acto sharpeners have done this for me). It is just a personal preference thing, though.

WIth the "energy efficient DC adaptor", I though, for whatever reason, that the adaptor was optional and the sharpener could be run on batteries. It can't. It just plugs in.

If you just need an occasional use pencil only sharpener, this will meet you needs. If you use a pencil sharpener a lot, this one won't make you very happy.

Edited!: My toddler shoved a crayon into the pencil sharpener. Which is usually the death of a sharpener. However, I was able to push the crayon through and basically sharpen the whole thing down to remove it and the sharpener is still going! So, that alone changes my review from 3 to 4 stars.

title: Interesting Sharpener
text:
[[VIDEOID:7d5c66cd01f1c0feb0aac3ed8627bc20]] As you can hear, the sharpener is a bit loud. And as you can see, it takes about 15 seconds to completely sharpen a pencil (from new to sharp). Pencils that are already sharpened to some degree don't take as long. (The "shh" "shh" sound toward the end of the video isn't the sharpener, it is my 4 year "shushing" himself because I was making a video.)

You just feed the pencil into the sharpener and it takes care of the rest. You are supposed to take your hands off the pencil, which my kids find difficult to remember. (Even if they do like to watch the "magic sharpener.") As you can see in the video, the pencil is ejected when it is finished sharpening.

The tray for the shavings is tiny. Less than 10 pencils and it is full. That is a bit annoying. If you let it get over full you'll have 2 problems to deal with. (1) The pencils will have little wooden bits left on them. (2) The tray will be extremely difficult to remove and will create quite the mess.

It sharpens pencils to a pretty severe point. (I happen to prefer a smaller point, but that is just personal preference.)

I was able to sharpen regular wood hexagon pencils, wooden round pencils, wooden round pencils with plastic coating, wood round pencils with glitter coating, colored pencils, and smencils (made of recycled newspaper) without any problems. All in all a sufficient sharpener for home use.

title: Huge!
text: This pencil sharpener is much larger in person than it looks on the internet. It has a pretty standard length cord. The suction cups on the bottom are tiny. They don't really anchor the sharpener, but the do keep it from running away while you're sharpening. The pencil shavings tray is huge! I was able to sharpen 50 pencils and the tray still wasn't full! I like the automatic stop, though the motor doesn't stop, it just stops sharpening. That feature keeps kids from being able to feed their entire pencil through the sharpener. It is a pretty deep sharpener, so once pencils get short, they can't be put in this sharpener anymore. I've sharpened colored pencils, regular hexagon shaped pencils, novelty pencils, glitter pencils, and fabric pencils and have not had the sharpener jam up once. It has sharpened every kind of pencil with the same ease and the same results. I wouldn't say this motor is quiet. No, it doesn't sound like a helicopter landing, but it isn't quiet. It also sharpens pencils to a very severe point. I prefer a smaller, less angled point, but that is really a personal preference, not necessarily a design issue. All in all, it is a nice, big sharpener that can sharpen any kind of pencil.

title: NOT NANO TAPE! NOT NANO TAPE!
text: NOT NANO TAPE! IT'S DOUBLE SIDED TAPE FULL OF ADHESIVE RESIDUE!  RIP OFF! RIP OFF! RIP OFF!

title: Works great, but doesn't stay closed.
text: My only gripe with this stapler (and maybe I just got a defective one) is that the lid will not connect and stay locked. So, if I wanted to take it with me somewhere, I would either have to remove the staples, and put them back in the box or ina zippy bag. Otherwise, the staples can fall out. Other than that, it seems to work well,  and is a perfect size for my needs. And the fact that they had one in purple was awesome! If not for the bad lid, I would have given it 5 stars.

title: The most AGGRAVATING Velcro I have ever purchased!
text: The Velcro itself works well. My aggravation is to how incredibly difficult it is to pull the plastic backing off. There's nothing to grab onto to pull, and the glue is so strong, I had to use a box cutter to score the middle of my piece, then roll the Velcro back and forth, just to get an edge up. Then I had to use my tweezers to SLOWLY pull the backing off. I appreciate the effort in making a strong grip, but this was a ridiculous waste of time; all for a one inch piece of Velcro. Would not recommend!

title: Holds quite a few posters, a bit floppy
text: The storage bags do hold quite a few of my school posters, and it is nice that I can see what is inside. However, they are a bit flimsy and tend to curl or flop, whether they are hung or stood in an appropriately narrow spot in the closet. They do the job, just not as sturdy as I had hoped.

title: Disappointing longevity for an Amazon product
text: This shredder has nicely worked for a while. But now it stays on in auto mode. Constantly. Does not turn off unless I manually turn it off. I have hardly used the machine in the time I have had it - maybe 1-2 times a month. I did not use it for CD's or even credit cards. I think I have had to empty it 3 times since we got it. So it should not be worn out. Even a "Basic" shredder should last more than a few years with little use. Maybe that's why it is no longer available. Disappointing for an Amazon product.

title: These are useful to cut apart or leave whole to hang items
text: These are useful to cut apart or leave whole to hang items. The sticky side peels easily and sticks well to the surface of a poster or other item to hang. The magnets are not as strong as some others I've had, hence the 4 star rating.

title: Fine for classroom use.
text: They work just fine for classroom use. They do NOT tear as easily as the more expensive ones. Well worth the price for my uses, might be troublesome for real raffles or drawings.

title: Be Prepared
text: Be prepared. Sometimes it works fine, and sometimes it doesn't. While you can't beat the price, you take the chance that one or two of the cartridges will not work or will be of poor quality. I have ordered the remanufactured ink a few times, and there is usually one cartridge that does not work- it has been black for me. I have never had that problem with the Epson brand. And I do not mean the printer will not accept it - I just press OK for it to accept the non Epson cartridge- but the print quality is poor, even after checking the alignment, cleaning the heads, etc. Half of the page does not print at all. It is the chance you take when you buy the off brand, so be prepared with back up cartridges in case one doesn't work.

title: Really tiny and shiny
text: Not great but will find a use for them.

title: Not that sturdy.
text: Lighter weight than I expected.  Should have paid more and gone to Staples.

title: Not the Vellum I thought!
text: Apparently I do not know the difference between clear vellum and vellum coated for mixed media.  Didn’t need more cards but guess you live and learn🤨

title: Came Damaged!
text: Came damaged, packaging was just a bag for a paperboard item.  Not good!  Too bad I really liked it.

title: You get what you pay for.
text: For the price this is a nice little cart. Got it to organize pet stuff in one place, nothing to heavy as it is plastic.

title: Three Stars
text: Only got 11 of the 12 ordered. Somebody must have needed a pen!

title: A bit on the cheesy side of Christmas
text: Nice enough idea, but kind of cheesy follow through.  Not nearly as classy as other special Christmas cards I've given to my better half (by far!), although she received it with her usual grace and good cheer.  Can't really recommend it though.

title: A touch of class Christmas cards
text: Beautiful.  Classy.  Bought them to use for a number of our friends and family this Christmas season.  My better half (by far) loves them.  And if she's happy, well, you know yours truly is.  Happy Holidays everybody!

title: Birthday card for my wife was a big hit
text: Arrived on-time and in perfect condition.  Card was for my wife's b'day, and she loved it.  What more can I say?  A big hit with her!

title: 'Friends' birthday card for an old friend
text: Not unlike previous Seinfeld cards I purchased, I bought this 'Friends' card for a long-time 'Friends' fan's birthday.  She loves the show (I don't).  Went over well, she really liked it.  Would use it again for others, for sure.  Recommended for fans of the sitcom.

title: Anther Seinfeld birthday card
text: Seinfeld birthday card # 2.  Gave it (with a gift, of course) to an old friend and contemporary who absolutely loves Jerry and Co.  Went over very well, a big hit.  Would use it again for other Seinfeld fan friends in my circle of friends.  Cheerfully recommended.

title: She loved it!
text: Easter card for my better half by far.  She loved it.  I'm happy.  Thanks!

title: She loved it.
text: This year's St. Valentine's Day card for my good wife.  She loved it, along with all the other goodies.  'Nuff said.

title: She loved it!
text: Ordered as a Christmas card for my wife.  She loved it.  Matter of fact, it's still on our mantlepiece!

title: Rockwell calendar rocks!
text: Purchased as a gift for my wife ((for her office at school).  She was very happy with it.  Arrived on-time and in perfect condition.

title: From OK to Poor
text: Upgrade to version 5 is a kluge and so is using this system now. It is a system resources hog, the interface is wacky, and it uses the worst activation process I have seen. They must be very proud of this software to make activation user hostile.

title: Odd selection
text: Strange that Amazon only carries medium point with one odd color (red). I don't want red, so this refil assortment is actually 25% higher per useful refill than anything else. Medium point does not last as long a fine point.

title: Had a week 3 of them have broken already.
text:
Cute but not worth money 3 have already broken within a week
Of having.

title: Four Stars
text: Nice little rack. Not very tall but serves its purpose

title: One Star
text: No idea what this is cause I never ordered iy

title: Cute & broken
text: Horrible. Stapler broke writhing 20 times. Do not purchase

title: Ok for the money
text: Thought there would be more in the pack. Picture is misleading.

title: Looks like Van Gogh
text: Fine. Nice.

title: Tough to get coins in but sturdy
text: I like the sturdiness of this but it was very difficult to get the coins in properly. Might be my old fingers though but overall it did it's job.

title: Decent Padded Envelopes
text: These are a very nice size for shipping trading cards.  The padding is decent but will require a stiff insert. I like the color and design and should go through these pretty quickly.  They are not the most rugged I've seen, but they will do the job.  Very happy with them.

title: Seems to work pretty well
text: I think I can say that there is a different quality to the prints.  They seem a little less fully melted to the page than the original toner, but definitely not nearly enough of a difference to be worried, especially at the price difference.  We got reviewer cartridges a while ago and finally gave up on waiting for the HP one to run out.  We put in the new cartridge and did not get any errors or have any issues seating the cartridge.  It may "squeak" a little more when printing, but again, we might be nitpicking too much.  All in all, it pretty much works the same.

title: Seems to work pretty good
text: I think I can say that there is a different quality to the prints.  They seem a little less fully melted to the page than the original toner, but definitely not nearly enough of a difference to be worried, especially at the price difference.  We got reviewer cartridges a while ago and finally gave up on waiting for the HP one to run out.  We put in the new cartridge and did not get any errors or have any issues seating the cartridge.  It may "squeak" a little more when printing, but again, we might be nitpicking too much.  All in all, it pretty much works the same.

title: Fun Recording of our Travels
text:
I like this little scratch off map for several reasons. First is because it is so little. I had been keeping a small printed out map of all the states my girlfriend and I have traveled to together which was nice for setting trips and memories. I liked the idea of the scratch off maps, but had no desire to put a full poster sized map on the wall much less find a place to store it. this one at 11x17 fits into one of my old art portfolios where it can lay flat and I know where it is.

I also like that it came with a couple of scratching tools. We had fun marking off the states we have visited and remembering hikes and museums and shared experiences. It also pointed out that we have no plans to go anywhere new. We are only returning to states we have seen so it should inspire a new get away.

The cons are that it still isn't something I would put on the wall. Also the scratch off stuff is a little obnoxious and we accidentally put a scratch in Kansas, but all in all, it is a fun memento.

title: Great Looking, Light Weight Bulletin Board
text: I was looking for a bulletin board for my office and this one is absolutely beautiful.  I love the classy gray felt and I'm very happy with the size of the board over all at 3' by 4'.  It is perfect for the space I was looking for and the fact that it is feather light is a plus that it is easy to hang in the drywall.  The down side is that it is very lightly constructed and very thin.  It is easy for longer tacks to go right through the board.  But it is working for what I wanted and the price is not outrageous at $45, but not super cheap either.  I'm glad I got it.

title: Lightweight Feel, but Good Cuts
text: This does not have the feel of a rugged tool, but it does seem very effective and cutting and scoring paper.  I have to admit that I don't have much hope for a long run with this.  The plastic is light and seems a little cheap, but the feel of the blade cutting through the paper is satisfying, clean and easy to use.  I love how easy it is to line up pages and cut squarely.  But again, I just don't think it has a the power to cut through many pages at once or over the years.  But for what it is, I'm impressed with its functionality.

title: Great for Graphic Project Work
text: I use a lot of loose leaf graph paper for sketching out page designs for book and web sites and thought this would be nearly perfect for allowing me to have graph paper on one side and place for notes on the other.  And I was right.  I really like the idea of this design for my graphic layout.  The paper is decent, I'm only giving four stars because my pages looked a little beaten up despite being plastic wrapped and appearing to have come through shipping undamaged.  But when I unwrapped the paper, many of the pages had small bends. Otherwise, a lot to like here.

title: Decent Sticky Notes
text:
I got a reviewer sample of these pads and they do everything I would hope from a sticky pad. I immediately put them into use at my work desk to organize piles of hardware for repair. The adhesive held well and released well, the paper took ink well and had bright colors for color coding.

The one criticism I have is that each pad is individually wrapped then overwrapped which seems like a waste of packaging. But perhaps that makes sense in warmer, humid climates. Here it just seems like a waste of plastic.

title: Received Wrong Product, Perhaps for Best
text: Rather than the cork board/whiteboard combo, I got just a whiteboard.  To be honest, I had fretted over the combo because I thought each half might be too small.  Also, I was a little concerned about other reviews showing issues.  Turns out, the full sized white board was the way to go.  It came undamaged and appears to be decently constructed.  I will have to order a cork board separately, but I think I'm going to be happier with two full sized boards.  We had it received and mounted on the wall in about 20 minutes and it works well.

title: A Very Good Staff Paper Notebook
text: This is a very nice notebook for music students.  We have several kids in band right now and we actually had been printing out staff paper from time to time for projects they had.  This is absolutely perfect (although we may need to order more so all three can have one.) The paper is decently thick and as a notebook it should hold up to the abuse of a middle school backpack.  The price seems reasonable for a unique product like this.  But mostly we just like it because it is perfect for the need we have.

title: A Decent, but not quite Sharpie quality marker set.
text:
This is a great selection of colors, although definitely a step below Sharpies for quality. The tips seem to break apart with too much force in a way that I don't see with Sharpies. They still work, but the fineness of the lines is affected. Otherwise I really do like these markers and I have used them several times with my kids for various art projects. I love that small box they come in despite the fact that it was plain cardboard. It is a wonderfully small packing size and has gone into our road trip bag.

A decent marker set for a reasonable price.

title: Nice Idea, wish the dry erase worked better
text:
We were looking to get these as gifts for our kids' coaches as a thank you gifts. Glad we got one before purchasing this one en masse. It concept it is great and we are still looking for a solution like this for thanking the coaches, but this one falls short in a couple areas. While it feels like it is constructed well enough this does not seem to be the same material that our white board is made out of. First, the dry erase pen does not erase well (or work particularly well.) We used both the included pen and some of our dry erase pens and it does not wipe off easily or cleanly. I almost want to put a plastic sheet on it to keep the surface clean. Second, some of the field outline is peeling or scraping off.

This board is fine, but I think there is a better manufactured product out there.

title: Nice Naturally Decorated 17 month Calendar
text:
I was looking for a calendar to schedule my "wasted time" or non money making/bucket list project and the cover sentiment fills the bill pretty well. Love that It starts with August 2017 but makes it kind of timely to get it sooner than later. The biggest failing I see in it is that the individual day boxes are small and they do not give much room for notes. The design is nice and matches my natural history project.

There are a couple of blank pages in the back, one page labeled birthdays/addresses one labeled notes and a dozen perforated strips labeled as notes. So there is room for notes, but not much. I like this very much visually but I could use a little more flexible notes space. All in all a nice calendar.

title: Great Portability, Not Overly Strong
text:
I like this tripod for what it is. It is a very portable sign holder that can easily hold a foam core sign or other, extremely light signage or art. But there are some trade offs made by choosing light weight portability.

For one this is not a heavy use product. I would not expect the tent pole bungy technology to survive a lot of abuse, However it is very handy and mades for easy set up and it breaks down to a very nice, packable size.Also the tripod is a little tippy and easily knocked over due to the lack of cross supports which were probably left out for portability.

I wouldn't push this tripod with anything weighty. I have not had problems with the adjustable brackets, but again I am not using anything other than foam core signage. I would think that weight would risk slippage of the brackets and possible twisting of the legs.

Pros
+ easily packed
+ Easy set up.

Cons
- Light weight
- Tippy
- Low holding strength.

Summary.
This really is a nice solution if you are looking for an easy to pack light weight sign holder. If you have more demanding requirements I would go up a step, but at the expense of losing and quick set up and lightweight, tight packing.

title: A Decent Box
text:
I got a chance to test this box out during a move and I can say that it lived up to all the functionality that you could expect from a box. It is not a premium box by any means but decent quality, perhaps a little less rugged than would be ideal. For me it ended up holding clothes. The box is big enough that if you were to put books or dishes into it, it would end up pretty heavy, and I don't know that the cardboard is substantial enough for heavy loads. Also with books it would have pushed the limits of most people's backs.

We did fill out the room information on the side, although for most boxes we used we got away with just a quick kitchen or bedroom scrawled on the side which was fine. But it was a nice touch.

Summary: The price is good for the amount of boxes that come in a bundle, but due to size they were limited to certain lighter, packable things. But for things like clothes, it worked great for me.
