title: Decent Pens; Writing is a Little Dry
text:
I selected this set of markers for a few different reasons. I have had good fortune with the brand, and I like the variety of colors. I also like the fact that they're retractable. I had high hopes for these and they mostly have met my expectations, though there's room for a little improvement.

There are 36 pens in the box I received and there's a good variety of colors. Each came with a little rubber plug over the tip to keep the pen from drying out, and that's a good thing. When using these, I put the plug right back in when I'm done, though I am not so sure how much that helps.

The clicker works as expected on each and this has one very specific benefit for me - I like that I can lay the pen down and not worry about it staining anything on which it sits. I have had other felt-tip pens stain textiles on multiple occasions from my carelessness, and these pens already help me with that.

I have one complaint with these pens. For felt pens, they seem to be quite dry. They do write, and they certainly are not dried out already, but they write like pens that have been 75% used already. Time will tell how long they'll last - I am hoping the drier writing means they will last longer from using less fluid?

These are decent art pens with a good variety of colors and thoughtful design. I am still deciding if I am happy with them but so far they're working for me. I just wish they wrote a little more boldly.

title: Difficult to Peel
text:
This is my second pass at this review. I originally wrote this one thinking that these weren’t stickers at all and that what I had received was just paper pictures that required a glue stick to adhere to anything. It turns out that this was incorrect - these are in fact stickers, but they’re difficult to peel. As such I have rewritten this review to be fair.

I received a pack of 100 individual stickers, packaged in two separate baggies. These are small and individually cut so they’re not like sheets of stickers you normally buy in a craft store that have a paper backing and are easy to peel. They’re colorful, and each sticker is unique. Most have a Christian message, some even with Scripture references, while some are more targeted toward Catholics in particular and a smaller number are just inspirational.

I have two issues with these. First, these are not at all easy to peel. I honestly did not think they were stickers at all because I was unable to peel any of them. My wife was able to peel one with some persistence. Once peeled, they adhere well and they should have no trouble with peeling at the edges, at least for a while. The second issue is the product description. These are listed as vinyl stickers, and I am not so sure that these are actually vinyl. They’re not paper as I originally thought, but I believe they’re very thin plastic. Either way, they’re waterproof.

My initial assessment of these was wrong. These are stickers as advertised, but they’re not easy to peel and I am not convinced they’re vinyl as advertised (though that’s a minor point). If you can get past the difficulty in removing the backing, these are decent stickers.

title: Decent Pens; Expensive and Video Does Not Match Product
text:
I have used gel pens for several years and I prefer them because they don’t generally skip or smudge as easily as ink pens (though that’s a generality, not an absolute). I have also worked with Zebra mechanical pencils and have had very good success with them. So, I was pleased to get my hands on a set of these metallic gel pens, thinking they would be equally as good as some of the other gel pen brands I have used. They’re good but I have a couple of comments about them.

The pens themselves are fine-point pens which suits me just fine. I prefer fine-tip pens as I usually write small. The gel comes out smooth and less smudgy as expected which is a good thing. They feel decent in my hands though like with most pens I am not used to writing for extended periods of time so I have trouble with fatigue when using them. These are no better comfort-wise than other gel pens I have used but they’re no worse either.

The colors are not as vibrant as I had hoped, though the product packaging says these are best on dark paper. On white paper they wash out a bit.

The product page here shows a video of someone using highlighters and double-tipped pens, and these do not match the product attached to this listing. This is a posting issue, not a product issue, but it is sufficient to potentially cause some confusion. Be aware that what’s in the video is not what you’re getting.

Price-wise, these are mildly expensive. As I write this, the $18 price tag works out to $2/pen which is a little steep when considering unit pricing.

I do like these pens, though there are marketing issues that I think take away from an otherwise good product. These are good and I can recommend them based on experience; however, pay attention to the unit pricing and be aware that the video here does not match the product.

title: Lower-End Quality, Not Ideal for All Uses
text:
I selected these cards for labeling packing boxes, an ongoing task in my house. My wife was excited to work with these and so far she likes them though I see some issues with the quality.

I'll get right to the point on these - these are not the highest quality cards. If you are working with markers or pens that saturate the paper when you write, these will allow bleed-through. The card stock used is not the best quality and is not thick or sturdy so if you need cards that have some heft or are sturdy, these will definitely disappoint. For our purposes, these are just fine, but if you're thinking flash cards or small handwritten signs, these are not the best choice.

These are ok. For my particular case these work just fine, but many others will find them to be just too thin and flimsy for a lot of uses.

title: Monthly Calendar Poorly Designed
text:
Organization is always a challenge in our house and figuring who is where, at what time, doing what, is a bit of a moving target. We’ve gotten by with writing on a wall calendar but this gets messy quickly, especially when the schedules change. This system of rewriteable boards has helped, but it there is some room for improvement.

The most interesting component of this set for us is the monthly planner. It allows for writing out appointments, dates, reminders and other tidbits of information that can be erased and rewritten when no longer relevant. However, there is an issue we found with this calendar right away. The planner has exactly 30 squares for days, the first being on a Sunday and the last being a Monday. So, as I write this, it is January 2022, and the first day of the month is Saturday. Unless we’re willing to erase that day and rewrite the calendar, we will run out of room on January 24. We can add lines to add 5 more days in the notes area, but the first added day is taken up with a big “NOTES:” label that takes away valuable writing space. This was not thought through too well.

The shopping list and to-do list are both handy for keeping track of things to pick up before the full grocery list is made and for errands to run/tasks to complete, respectively. They’re smaller than the main calendar and the chore chart, so they have a little more versatility at the expense of writing room.

The conversion chart is especially handy for the kitchen.

The chore chart is the same size as the calendar and it competes for room on the refrigerator, so a little planning of how to arrange these two is required. This particular chart would have been handy when my kids were younger...

This is not a bad set, but the calendar leaves something to be desired. It doesn’t have enough room for a whole month in some cases, and working around this can be a challenge though it is usable. It should have been planned out a little better.

title: Good Value Pack of Pens
text:
We go through a lot of pens in my house (my wife is a list-maker) so I look for economical packs of pens like these to keep us well stocked. I received the 18-pack of blue medium-point pens and so far they've been good pens. I wouldn't call them perfect, but they're a good value for what you get.

As I write this these pens are priced just below $0.60/pen, and that's a very good deal. That alone is a good enough reason to look at these as an option for bulk pens.

In use, there work reasonably well. I have had a couple of duds that have quit on us before the ink is gone, but most of them seem to be decent and work well. We have not run through the whole pack, of course, but we have had more work properly than haven't. Writing is smooth with no skips and relatively little globbing. We haven't had any of them leak, either.

Overall, these are good pens and they seem to work well. The best feature is the pricing for this pack which makes them very much worth a look if you are looking for bulk pens.

title: Tend to Skip
text:
I love gel pens and I use different color pens in the office for work. I did not select these for work, though; I have other projects that can benefit from colored pens. These seemed like a good fit for recipe labels as well as gift packages. So far, I have been right, though they have their issues.

These are not the typical gel pens you'll find between the check-out in the grocery store. Instead of colorful pens in red, green and blue, these write in gold, silver and white. These are fine colors for things with dark or black backgrounds like labels and some gift cards. I typically don't use these kinds of colors, but then again I have not had access to them.

These are fine-point pens, and I think this might be part of the problem that others have seen with them. These have a tendency to start writing and then stop. I don't know if the particulates in the tips jam the ball or if there's something about the gel itself that makes these skip, but it's a definite issue. I have been able to get them writing again, usually by carefully applying a little heat to the tips though this is risky.

When they write properly they write very smoothly.

These are hit-or-miss pens. The colors are fun and they definitely have their use when working on dark backgrounds. On the other hand, they have a tendency to skip which means either working a lot more slowly or putting up with spotty writing.

title: Simple and Functional Cart; Good in its Price Range
text:
We have needed a rolling laptop cart for some time and this one seemed to be a good fit for our needs. It’s not especially expensive so I didn’t have high expectations, though I did figure it to be up to the task for which we needed it. Though this isn’t a high end cart and there are better choices out there, those choices cost quite a bit more; in it’s price range, this one is just fine.

The cart came disassembled as expected. It took about 15 minutes to put together after unboxing, and it required no tools beyond what was in the package. The exact number of parts were included – no more and no less. When finished, the cart looks exactly like it does in the product listing photos.

The cart is very balanced and has no trouble handling a laptop or even working as a small table while packing a suitcase on it (though I do not recommend this in most situations). It is lightweight and I can carry it around one-handed when I want to move it between floors of the house.

The downside of this cart is that it doesn’t pull close enough if there is no gap under where you’re seated when working with it. Our couch has maybe a one-inch gap between the floor and the upholstered wood, and as such the cart pulls up close but still far enough away that we have to sit on the edge of the couch seat to use it as a laptop cart.

The upshot is that this is a very affordable cart. It sells for $50 as I write this, which is quite reasonable.

The vertical adjustment is fairly easy and straightforward. It can be lowered enough to work for a child and tall enough to almost work as a standing desk, and the adjustment takes seconds..

I am not unhappy with this cart. It’s a good one and I am getting use out of it already. I do wish there was a way to get it to come closer to the couch, but to have that either as an adjustable sliding desk or have it on longer arms would change the cost as well as the balance and weight.

title: Jaws Grip Well. Magnets No So Much.
text:
My wife has complained for a while that we’ve used a large number of clothes pins in the kitchen for closing up bags of chips and popcorn. This collection of bag clips seemed like an ideal solution. It’s a good solution though not perfect, the main issue being the weak magnets.

These are brightly colored clips and there are 15 in the set – and every one of them has a unique color. Though this is a colorful set as such, the colors don’t serve too much purpose other than aesthetic appeal. That is, there’s no way to label these without adding a glob of tape. That’s not a criticism in the least, but using a specific color for a specific purpose will take an understanding among members of the household.

Even though these have a small area of contact between the jaws, these grip well and we’ve had no trouble with these keeping even larger bags closed (when we fold or roll the bag decently, of course). These are fine clips for the main purpose they serve.

Where these fail is in the magnets that are supposed to make them suitable for tacking things to a metal surface. The magnets are weak, enough so that much more than a sheet of paper makes these slide down a refrigerator door if there’s nothing in the way to stop them.

These are good bag clips and they work well as bag clips. For holding things to metal surfaces these are less useful because of the relatively weak magnets.

title: Decent White Board, but Room for Improvement
text:
My wife is a teacher and has need of things like this whiteboard in the classroom so I selected this with her in mind. There are some really nice features about this board that make is a useful too, but there are also some things about it that could use some more thought.

The whole comes requiring assembly. Other than the tools included in the package there is no need for additional tools to assemble the board. Assembly took 15-20 minutes and the instructions were fairly clear and easy to follow. It’s easy enough to put together that I was able to do it without needing assistance.

The board has a nice, smooth writing surface without any scratches or damage which is a big plus. Included is a magnetic square that is also suitable for dry erase work, and this is handy when you need to either expand your writing a little or you need to cover up and keep writing. It’s not an expensive thing to add either so it’s a thoughtful inclusion. Also included is a paper flip chart which attaches to the front of the board.

All this is well and good but I found a few things that could use some improvement. First, the instructions are not complete. When I was done assembling the board, there was no information on how to attach the flip chart to the front of the board, and though the included clips made it semi-obvious what needed to happen there was no instruction on how to actually attach the clips. I assume I did it right, but I don’t know. Another issue is that the assembly is not completely stable and it does not roll smoothly, especially on carpet though not on hard flooring either. (To be clear, it feels a lot more stable on hard floors, but it is still somewhat top-heavy.) Whenever I move it I feel I have to steady it or it could topple.

The last issue I found is more of a design decision. When all put together, the board stands vertical, meaning the long edge is vertical and the short edge is horizontal. There’s no way to rotate the board. I understand that rotating it would mess up the flip chart, but it would be very useful to be able to use the board as wide and short rather than tall and narrow when the flip chart is not attached.

This is not a bad board at all and it has some very nice features, but there are some things that could be improved.

title: Nice Hand-Made Journal
text:
I have been a journaler for years though most of my writing is done on the computer. I have used paper journals, though, and I prefer leather-bound ones to cardboard-covered. I was interested in this journal and I am mostly pleased with it though there is some room for improvement.

The cover is pressed leather and is very pretty, and the outside of the cover looks pristine. Inside, the leather looks hand-cut and is uneven. It isn’t a problem but it shows that the journal is hand-crafted.

The paper is interesting to me. I have made paper by hand, and it has a very rough feel to it and is speckled with imperfections. The paper in this journal has the same qualities of hand-made paper. While it does make this journal feel more “rustic”, it does mean the paper is harder to write on. It’s workable but it does mean that more care and effort is required when writing. There are things that can be done to smooth the paper out a bit, and this doesn’t appear to have been done in the production process.

This is a nice little journal but unless you’re willing to accept its imperfections and prefer a more “commercial” journal it will disappoint. The paper is slightly rough, and the cover shows signs of hand craftmanship, both of which are not necessarily bad things unless you’re more interested in the actual writing process.

title: Not a Fan
text:
I selected these pencils for my wife who needs pencils for working with children. I will state up front that I have not worked regularly with wooden pencils in years and prefer metal mechanical pencils but I was willing to give them a try. Honestly, I am not a fan.

We do have other traditional pencils in the house and I use those only occasionally. Some of them are new, some old, but all feel the same in my hand. These new BIC pencils just feel “off”. I can’t really put my finger on it, but they seem almost slippery and I have to hold them funny to keep a firm grip. They look like regular wooden pencils, and they’re weighted about the same. They even seem to be the same size (width). But, the hand feel is different somehow.

I think the core is different too. They do write but I have to really bear down to get them to write dark enough to match that from a standard #2 pencil. I have no idea why. It may be that because I have a hard time gripping these pencils that I can’t hold them firmly enough to write properly?

One of the selling points of these pencils is that the leads are hard to break. When I received my pack of 24, all of the pencils in the pack were pre-sharpened, but one of the pencils had no tip. The tip on that one was broken off completely and had settled elsewhere in the package, meaning it probably was not broken when it was packaged. That’s not a good testament to being hard to break.

These pencils are all right, but I would not purchase these in favor of cheaper wooden pencils. They don’t feel right in my hand and if they can be broken in a sealed package it makes me question the claim of being harder to break.

title: Damaged Prior to Shipment?
text:
I bought a nice whiteboard when I was in college to get me through my math and physics classes, and that board served me well long after I graduated - until I got married and my school teacher wife needed it more than I did. I have been wanting a replacement for a while, and this looked like a good one. One very interesting negative about it though - the frame was damaged, though the packing box was not, evidence that the board was damaged before it shipped.

This is a big, sturdy board with a heavy aluminum frame and plastic bumpers. it’s a generous 3’x4’ which is larger than what is typically needed in a home environment, though it is approximately the same size as the one I bought in college. However, this one is much thicker and heavier than the old one I bought, and the frame will keep it from warping.

On two of the edges there are sliding hanging hooks so that the board can be hung either on a short edge or a long edge and because the hooks slide along the frame there is some versatility in how the board can be mounted on the wall. I like this configuration better than having the hooks attached permanently in the frame at fixed places.

The board comes with 12 colorful magnets, 2 magnetic erasers, a small set of markers and a mountable shelf for the markers and erasers. The magnets are bigger than they look in the product description’s pictures, roughly the size of quarters. To be honest, I will not need the magnets at all, though my wife always needs more so they will be used elsewhere.

My one complaint with this board - and it’s a serious one - is that the board came out of the box slightly damaged. One of the aluminum frame edges was bent, not in a way that impacts the usability (and not one of the edges with the hooks), but it is noticeable. The board’s frame is damaged, but the packing box was not. This means that the board was damaged when it went into the box. Does it really matter? In my specific case, no, it doesn’t affect me. But, does the severity of damage mitigate shipping anyway? Would you buy a brand-new car off the lot with a noticeably dented door?

My rating of this product would have been much higher had the frame not been damaged in such a way that was evident it went into the packing box already damaged. If you choose this particular whiteboard, inspect it carefully when it arrives.

title: Simple and Pretty; On the Small Side
text:
I selected this set of Christmas cards with the intent of using them, this season. They’re pretty and they have pretty designs. My main complaint with them is the size, which is a little on the small side for full Christmas cards.

The designs on these cards are simple and cheerful. They use winter colors – blue, gold, silver and white – and do not use a whole lot of words, letting the artwork be the star of each design. These cards have nothing written inside, leaving plenty of room for your own messages. They come with the envelopes necessary to send them off (expected but worth mentioning anyway).

Another reviewer here commented that these are more the size of thank-you notes, and that is very much true. These are quite small. I could see these in use as cards you’d leave at a place setting at a holiday dinner instead of sending out as to everyone at Christmas time.

These are nice Christmas cards, if a little small. Maybe note-card size is suitable to you, but they’re a bit smaller than the average Christmas card.

title: Cheap Pens but They Do Write Nicely
text:
I like colorful and bright pens, and these definitely qualify. I took them to the office as they are very distinguishable from the other pens available (so I can definitely identify these as mine). I like the colors, but honestly these are very low-quality pens.

This pack of pens comes in a set of 8, and each is a different color. These are fine for drawing and marking, though the black, blue and red are the only ones really appropriate for the office in most cases. They write fairly smoothly though I have one that leaks and I end up with ink on my hands if I’m not careful.

The real issue with these is that they’re cheap. They break easily (don’t put them in a back pocket) and when they do they’re just not useful at all anymore - especially if they leak too.

I wanted to like these and I gave them a fair shot. I’ve used pens that are cheaper and did not work as well, but then again I have used some that are a lot better too.

title: Unnecessary and Awkward to Use
text:
I have been a Wacom Intuos user for years and I have been very pleased with mine. I was excited about getting the opportunity to work with this digital notebook, based on my experience with other Wacom products. I will confess to being disappointed with this device. It seems like an interesting idea on the surface, but the reality is that it’s not all than convenient.

The concept is great - write on the pad, upload your drawing to the cloud, then pull it down to other devices so you can work with it everywhere. The potential is there to bridge between paper note taking and writing on a digital tablet like an iPad. However, the implementation is awkward and not at all ideal.

The folio needs to be charged and it comes with a pen that the folio recognizes. This is not at all unexpected. It comes with a pad of paper in it which is good. Tying the package together is an app that needs to be downloaded to an Android or iOS phone (so, if you are a Windows phone user or want to use it with your Windows desktop/laptop, you’re out of luck). I downloaded the app to my iPhone and had no problem tying to the device to the app.

My first discovery was a good one (I think). I tried writing on the pad without opening the pen and extending the ball and it would not work until I actually extended the pen so it would actually write. That’s great for use but it makes testing more difficult. It wasn’t made for the testers so there’s not really a reason to complain; this is just a data point.

The app tells you when the folio is ready to receive input. I found that I needed to fiddle with the app and the folio before it was ready to receive, and this is counter-intuitive. If the folio is on, it should start to receive as soon as it’s opened, though I understand that the app needs to be running (background should be fine in my opinion). I wasn’t able to get the folio to recognize that I was on a new sheet without twiddling some more and that’s not helpful. Forget to tell it that you’re starting another page and suddenly you have two pages one top of one another in the app.

My main complaint is that OCR is not automatic - you get to pay for it separately on a monthly basis. There might be a free trial, but if you have spent that much for a device it should have OCR either included or for a nominal one-time fee ($20-$30 seems reasonable to me). Without OCR - what distinguishes this unit from a phone camera and a regular pad of paper? Other than saving to PDF instead of JPG, not much.

This is an expensive unit for what you get and it doesn’t work as smoothly as it could or should. I am having difficulty recommending it when I can accomplish the same thing with a pad of paper and my cell phone without spending any more money.

title: Premium Paper at a Premium Price
text:
For years I have used 24-lb. paper with my inkjet printers. I prefer it to 20-lb. paper as it is a little stiffer and more durable, though it’s largely just personal preference. I wasn’t aware that 32-lb. paper even existed, so I was interested in trying it. It’s good paper and I like it, but the cost is guaranteed to keep me away from buying more.

32-lb. paper is somewhere between regular paper and card stock. It’s heavier and less flimsy which I like, and so far I have had no problem with it in the printer (meaning, so far no jams). On usability, I have no complaints. This is high quality paper, without question.

However, at the price point (just north of $20 for a pack of 250 sheets as I write this), it’s expensive. A pack of good 24-lb. paper costs between $7 and $10 locally, depending on brand. I have a very difficult time justifying spending double or more on a pack of printer paper when it comes to (in my case) a preference.

Now, that said, this is premium paper and there are reasons why you might want to spend the extra. What comes to mind is more business use, printed resumes and in some cases craft work, but not for the average home user. In my mind, it isn’t a practical solution for everyday printing. For the occasion when you want or need a higher quality paper, this is definitely a better choice than the average pack you’d get in most retail stores.

Based on the paper itself, this is an excellent product and it’s easy to recommend. That said, it’s premium paper at a premium price, and it’s a price that is hard to justify for just everyday use.

title: Large Inkjet with Lots of Ink; Best Suited for a Small Office; Pricey
text:
I have worked with a large number of inkjet printers across several manufacturers and almost all of them have failed me in one way or another. I made the move to a color laser printer for generalized printing last year and the printer I chose was a Brother so I have some familiarity with the brand. I was interested in finding out how this printer would work and how it would integrate with my network. So far, I have had no complaints though admittedly I have not had it long.

First off, this is a large printer, the largest inkjet I have ever used. This is not a problem, but it means planning your desk space when finding a place to put this printer. I would recommend using a printer stand just for this printer, where it will not crowd other things on a desk or table. The box in which is ships is huge, and our cats have decided it is a perfect place to sit on top and survey the kingdom...

Setup is not hard and I was able to get it on my wifi network and connected within a few minutes. It does come with the software necessary to set it up, but I would recommend getting the drivers and applications directly from the Brother website to ensure having the latest versions unless there is some reason that connecting to the Internet is not feasible. This is not to say that the drivers on the CD are out of date, but the website is much more likely to have the absolute latest versions.

This is a multi-function printer that handles printing (in duplex), scanning, faxing and copying. I have not used the fax capability yet though I do occasionally have need to fax documents (it's rare but I do have to do it sometimes). The functions that I use regularly – printing, scanning and copying – all work as they should and the printer is fast and efficient.

The most important function is printing, and this printer is very efficient, producing good quality black and color images. The printer is fast and quiet, so much so that I had to check on it when I first printed, thinking that it had not printed anything and had only warmed up. I have not yet tried using photo paper in this printer so I have not yet tested the true potential of this printer's ability to produce color prints from high-resolution pictures, but I will shortly.

This printer comes with a BUNCH of ink, enough for about 2 years according the manufacturer's estimate. For the average household this is a lot, and likely is more than most need. This amount of ink is better suited for an office setting, though I can see it being useful in a small business or even in a college dorm. For home use, getting the MFCJ6535DW model (no XL on the end) may be more economical. The price difference between the two models (as of April 2017) is approximately $250, and that is a savings over buying the printer and ink separately. Consider which is a better fit for your needs and budget.

On the network I have had no issues at all with this printer. Connectivity is good and it seems to respond quickly to print requests. It does go into a sleep mode and when printing to it, it does wake up for printing without requiring intervention (I problem I have seen with some other printers).

So far, I have no complaints with this printer. It works very well and it has been stable and responsive on my network. For the home user it is probably a little heavy-handed on the budget though that depends on the need of the household; the model without all the included ink costs half as much and likely would fit a home's needs better. For a small office, though, this is a good printer with good value.

As I mentioned above, almost every inkjet I have had has failed me along the way. Time will tell if this one holds up better. I will revisit this review after I have used it more and have a better feel for its overall durability, though initial indicators are good.

title: Decent Entry Level B/W Laser Printer
text:
I have a kiddo in college and so far he has had access to a printer when he needs to print assignments so there has been no issue with getting things turned in on time. That said, I have been looking for an inexpensive unit for him, so that should he not otherwise have access he'll have some way to print his assignments when he needs to do so. I was hopeful this unit would be a good fit. It is not a color unit so it is not a perfect fit for the need, but it does work well for my own personal needs. It is a good, entry-level laser printer that handles the basics.

In the past I have had good success with HP printers, though it has been some time since I have used one in my home. This printer is another good one though it is not large and it is not as capable as some others I have seen and used. It does a good job of printing black and white pages, it does a nice job of copying and it is a capable scanner. It is not capable of faxing, which admittedly is not a feature I use often though I do have rare occasion to send faxes and on those rare occasions this unit will not help me.

Build quality is not particularly good and I am a little concerned that a good bump or a very short drop would result in enough damage to keep the printer from working properly anymore. This is the main concern I have. Unlike some other manufacturers, HP does offer some Linux support and the printer does work with Linux after a bit of fiddling with the CUPS system.

This is a surprisingly fast little printer and it works well enough to keep up with my [very] modest printing needs. It is rated to print up to 23 ppm, and so far I have not printed anything more than a dozen pages at a time and it has churned out the pages quickly enough to suit me.

Overall I have few complaints with this printer, beyond the build quality. It works well, it is fast and I can use either Windows or Linux to print. It is not a color laser (the price should be a good clue there) but it is fine for cranking out documents that do not require color at all. Take a look at this printer if you do not need color printing or fax capabilities.

title: Very Good Mechanical Pencil
text:
I have for years preferred mechanical pencils to traditional wood pencils as mechanical pencils typically stay sharper and I can get finer lines with them. My instrument of choice is a Uni-Ball KuruToga which I have been using for almost 4 years now and even bought another for my wife. I was interested in trying this Zebra mechanical pencil and comparing it to my KuruToga. It compares well and is not particularly expensive.

This pencil has a nice hand feel to it and I can hold it and work with it without any more fatigue than when I use any other pencil. The barrel is ridged hard plastic so it is easy to grip, though I personally prefer a pencil that has a softer (rubberized) grip to make it even more comfortable.

The innovation with this pencil is the spring loaded barrel which is designed to absorb excess pressure and prevent the lead from breaking as easily. In use, it seems to work fairly well and I have had fewer breaks than with many other pencils I have used. When you bear down hard, you can actually see the spring in the tip of the pencil compress to absorb some of the pressure. I cannot say with certainty that this is the only reason that the leads break less – the leads themselves may be a contributor.

The main area for improvement with this pencil is the eraser, which is very small and is typical of a lot of the better mechanical pencils I have seen and used. If you plan to use this pencil a lot, plan to keep a larger eraser close by which is easier to use anyway.

The cost of this pencil is quite reasonable. As I write this it sells here for $7, which is not terribly expensive. While disposable mechanical pencils may cost less, they quality is usually not there and in the long run you end up paying a little more than you would for a good quality pencil in the first place.

My wife has confiscated this pencil from me and uses it now. She prefers it to the KuruToga, though I am still debating which I think is better. Regardless, this is a fine pencil and it will serve you well if you need a 0.5mm pencil that will not cost you a fortune.

title: Interesting Concept, but Limited Usefulness
text:
I had never heard of the Justik but it sounded like a fascinating device - an electronic pinboard of sorts. I was curious to see how well it would work and for some things it works very well. For others things, no so much. I would consider it “somewhat useful”.

This is a clipboard-sized device that uses batteries to generate an electrostatic field that can be used to attract paper, CDs and other small items to it. The idea here is that it can work as an organizational tool to keep important items off the desk and out of piles, making them a lot easier to find. The concept is simple and straightforward, and it is in some ways better than an actual clipboard as it does not apply pressure on what it’s holding.

In service, though, it is limited. It cannot hold two sheets of paper that are on top of one another unless the top sheet is offset a bit and touches the Justik surface. Thicker items such as poster board, even when small, do not stick well and are more likely to slide off. It does hold CDs, but ONLY if they are on the label side and they simply slide off if you try to place them recording side down. My guess is that it needs a non-sheer surface, as smooth plastic (even very lightweight) does not stick.

I had trouble getting the battery compartments open to put in the 4 AA batteries. The covers simply slide off, but they are quite tight and are not easy to move until you have done them a couple of times. I suppose this is good in that the batteries will remain secure, but it also means frustration when changing the batteries.

There is some room for improvement with this device, though it does work to some degree. It will hold papers and CDs though the capacity is limited and it is a little fussy with certain materials. I have it in my office where it holds a checklist for me.

title: No FIlling Instructions and Ships with Fine Nib Instead of Medium
text:
I will start by saying that I have not made the same observations as some of the other reviewers have made about this pen, and I will talk to those points in my review. This is not an ideal pen, though, and I found a couple of drawbacks with it that make it less than perfect. It is workable, but it lacks a few details that would make it a better product.

One of the critical comments that has been made about this pen is that it is counterfeit. I disagree. It is marketed as an eBoot pen, and it has the logo stamped right on the cap. That does not make it a genuine article, but this is a $20 pen from a company that makes a lot of different things, not like Cross or Parker that specialize in making fine writing instruments. To counterfeit would be a waste of time.

The pen, and the case, are definitely bamboo. This is easiest to tell by looking inside the case at the groove cut for the pen to fit inside, as well as the rounded tips on either end of the pen. There is definitely rough grain in these spots.

Fountain pens are usually shipped with a medium nib which is suitable for most people. This one does not and instead has a fine nib which is what is typically recommended for women. A fine nib writes thinner, more delicate lines, where a medium is more bold and is what is typically recommended for men. It is unclear why this pen ships with a fine nib and not a medium nib, especially since this is not mentioned in the product description.

The last fountain pen I used took ink cartridges. This one is refillable, but it takes the ink into a built-in ink well in the pen. It’s semi-intuitive when it comes to refilling it, but there are no instructions with the pen at all which is a major shortcoming for this type of pen. There needs to be some kind of instruction on how to fill it up, how to clean it and how to do general maintenance on it.

This pen comes with no ink at all, another minor disappointment. I would have liked to have had at least a small amount of ink come with it.

In writing, this pen works decently. I have been able to get fine, clean lines from it. It have not had problems with globbing or leaking.

This is not a bad pen. It does work well for me and I like the way it writes. There were some shortcuts taken in the final package though, such as not including instructions and including a non-medium nib, that make it less than ideal.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at minimal or no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

title: Results Depend on the Quality of the Negatives
text:
We have a ton of negatives from 35mm and 110 film cameras and I have wanted for some time to convert some of the photos to digital images. We also have all of the negatives from our wedding, and I was especially eager to convert all of these. This slick little device does a nice job of making images from the negatives, but it is not a miracle device - it cannot create great images from poor-quality negatives.

This is a small and unassuming little device, roughly the size of a large pencil cup. It comes with several adapters for feeding in the various negative sizes as well as 8mm film. The device basically takes a negative snapshot of the negative generating a full-color image. It also makes full-color renders of individual sides. This works fine for individual snaps; for film reels it takes individual snaps of individual frames which means a lot of work to convert a film to a video. Keep this is mind if you intend to use it for converting film to video files.

The results that this device generates depends very much on the quality of the negatives. Working with negatives from a good-quality 35mm camera and higher-quality film, the resulting image was good. However, when converting a negative from a lower-quality 110 camera, results were much worse. With a photo editor I was able to improve image quality to a point but it was much more effort than it was worth. In a nutshell - garbage in, garbage out.

The user has the choice of rendering images directly to internal memory or to an SD card. I prefer rendering to an SD card as I can insert the card directly into my system to pull off the images. The internal memory supposedly will hold about 40 digital images which is fine for a start but if you have a lot of images it will fill up quickly.

Overall this is a nice device for converting negatives and slides to digital images. It is definitely cheaper than using a service. How well it works depends on the quality of the original slides but it can make images even of bad slides regardless. Consider this a viable option if you have negatives that you want/need to preserve.

title: Just Ok - Packaging Tape is Cheaper and Does the Same Thing
text:
We have an elaborate filing and storage system in the house and we’re always looking for ways to make the system easier to use and maintain. I looked to these labels as a possible way to improve the labeling, and while it does work as advertised I am not sure it’s really worth the trouble.

The concept here is a lot like putting a piece of tape over a label so that it becomes waterproof and stays in place. I have done that for years on packages I send through the mail so that the ink on an address label does not succumb to dampness during shipping. For this product, once your label is printed it gets “laminated” with the adhesive - just like putting a piece of tape over it.

The one advantage I can see here is that the adhesive strip fits the label and does not need to be cut like a piece (or pieces) of tape.

It’s not a bad product - it’s just not original and it’s not as economical as using a piece of packaging tape and a sharp pair of scissors to do the same thing.

title: Decent Dry Erase Calendar
text:
My wife is the queen of calendars. She has calendars all over the house and every one of them has all manner of notations throughout. I thought this dry erase calendar would be a good choice for her and that she would find it to be useful, and for the most part I was right. There are a couple of negatives, though, that merit mention.

This is not a huge calendar but it’s not tiny either. At 14"x14" it fits on most refrigerator doors or sides though it is suitable for most mounting spots. The boxes for the days are a little on the small side and may represent some minor difficulty if you have a lot to write. There’s a fine balance here - too big and the calendar becomes more cumbersome, too small and it’s useless. I personally am content with the size. The size does mean that you are better off with a fine-tip dry erase marker instead of a chisel-tip marker.

The pen included with this calendar is remarkably useless. The one that came with our calendar does not write well at all and almost seems to be partially dried out. Fortunately, black fine-tip dry erase markers are inexpensive.

The writing surface of this calendar is painted metal and is mounted on a styrofoam backing that makes it light and easy to move. It also makes it easy to dent and my particular calendar had a dented corner coming right out of the shipping box. It’s not damaged to the point of useless but it is noticeable. Wrapped in clear cellophane and dropped in a box with inadequate padding, the possibility to damage is higher than it should be - it would have been nice to put it in a cardboard sleeve for shipping.

Included with the calendar are two colorful round magnets. These are good for marking particularly important dates or marking the actual day of the week, or even for attaching something light (like a paper note) to the calendar. Smaller magnets might work better if you need to mark something on a day where you have something written.

The Quartet Dry Erase Calendar is not a bad product at all. It is a useful tool for tracking things through the month and it is a suitable size for mounting in most places. The price - $12 as I write this - is very reasonable for this kind of product. It does have a couple of negatives - the packaging and the pen being the two main ones - but overall this is a nice product that does a fine job of allowing someone to maintain a monthly calendar.

title: Light-Duty Cutter: If Used With Care, It Works Well
text:
This is a paper cutter suitable for small projects. While it works as intended, I found some limitations that detract from its usefulness. As such, there are a few things to keep in mind when using it that will make it a less frustrating device.

First off, this is a small and portable paper slicer, and this is good for my needs as it can be moved all over the house. It can be used on most flat surfaces so moving from a work table to the kitchen counter is not a problem. It is lightweight and easy to move. Now, because it's a lightweight and light-duty paper slicer, it should be used with care - I don't think it will be hard to break if used like a heavy-duty gadget.

It slices paper by use of a sliding blade that works very well, though I have found that it works best for single sheets of standard weight (20-24 lb.) paper. When I fed a light envelope through it and tried to cut it, it did cut but it required much more effort and it had a tendency to stop the blade from moving without applying some extra force. It was also difficult to hold it straight. For very lightweight paper such as some photo papers, it helps a lot to have some way to hold the edge outside of the slider because the paper tends to bunch and wrinkle instead of slicing properly. It can be worked around but it requires thinking about it BEFORE trying to cut.

This is not a bad paper cutter. It works well and it is priced right. It is a light-duty device, though, and some projects require a little extra effort and thought beforehand, but used properly it should last for a long time and serve well.

title: Good Pens - Even Writing and Hard to Smear
text:
I am very picky about the pens I use and I am always looking for good pens that write well and do not smear. These two features are difficult to find in most disposable pens. The Pilot Acroball pens handle both of these criteria and are among the better pens I have used.

One would think there isn't much that could be said about ink pens, but there's actually several things that can be said about these.

First off, these pens have an interesting rubber grip. Rubber grips serve two functions, providing a better grip on the pen (useful when the hands are either wet or sweaty) and reducing fatigue while writing. The rubber grips on these pens do well on the former but not so much on the latter. The texture is excellent for providing a non-slip grip that makes holding on to the pen a bit easier no matter what. However, it is made of thin, hard rubber that provides almost no cushion at all and as a result they do very little for reducing fatigue. If writing for long periods of time, these pens may not be the most comfortable.

Most important to me is that a pen write smoothly without skipping or globbing. So far I have had no issues with these pens in that regard - ink comes out smooth and even and there are no globs of ink when I start, stop or pause in the middle of writing. I would have to say these are among the most consistent writing pens I have used when it comes to disposable pens. Also, they seem to glide over the writing surface as I write instead of scratching as I go, which is very definitely a good thing in my opinion.

I decided to try a little experiment and set out to smear the ink as I wrote. If I tried really hard, I was able to smear the ink a little bit, but I had to do it very immediately after the ink hit the paper. When I took any time at all, the ink proved almost impossible to smear. I can't stand smudgy pens so I am very pleased with how nicely the ink in these pens stays put on the paper.

Price-wise, these are a little expensive ($11.25 as I write this). That works out to more that $2 per pen.

While I cannot say these are "perfect" pens, they are very good. They write beautifully and the ink does not smear without some effort. They are a little on the expensive side, but if very clean, consistent lines are what you need, then these pens deliver.

title: Excellent Quality, Fast Printing - UPDATED
text:
UPDATE 10/24/2012 :

I originally gave this printer 5 stars and was initially very happy with it, but I discovered a SERIOUS issue that merits some attention. My family and I noticed that the printer started a new behavior - quitting in the middle of a print job and locking up the print queue. After chasing the issue for a month I finally traced it back to the wireless network connection - the printer is unable to keep up with larger print jobs that buffer over the network. I sent a 60-page PDF to it and watched as it buffered 4-6 pages at a time, then finally dropped offline somewhere about half-way through so that it never completely buffered the whole print job. To fix it, we have to delete the print job AND power-cycle the printer before it accepts new print jobs. This is a very repeatable and predictable behavior.

I have a reliable, stable and fast router, and no other devices have had any issues at all with staying connected, even when transferring large amounts of data. I cannot attribute the issue to my network.

I updated the printer with the latest flash and while it seemed to help, it did not resolve the issue.

I will be moving this printer to a USB connection instead, as there is only one computer in the house that is set up to send jobs to it. I have not yet tested the printer under similar conditions when connected via USB but considering the nature of the issue I expect it to behave as expected.

Though a great printer for smaller jobs, it might be a little unreliable when sending larger document to it, particularly when using a wireless connection.

My original review, unchanged, follows.

------

Epson is a standard name when it comes to designing inkjet printers and it is consistently near the top of the class when it comes to print quality and speed (that is especially true as of late - I had some troubles with them in the past). They have made great strides in their printer line, continually creating better and better products. The WorkForce Pro 4020 is a solid performer and is a quality product.

It is important to keep in mind that this is not an all-in-one printer - it is just a printer and nothing more.

The WP-4020 is a boxy printer, approximately 18"x18", plain black and without too much in the way of flashy decoration or fancy user interface. In short, it will win no beauty contests on its looks alone. Fortunately, looking good is not a requirement for being a good printer. The size of the printer, however, must be considered when setting up. This is a bigger printer than I expected and as a result I needed to rearrange my workspace to make room for it. It's not a huge printer, but it's not small either and it's important to consider this when looking at this printer.

Rather than simply put everything together and turn it on, I decided to try something very novel and I followed the directions that came with the printer. The directions are very clear and concise, but I ran into in issue with the initial set-up. The directions state that the printer is to be turned on, the front panel opened and the cartridges inserted, after which the front panel is closed and the printer will start priming the cartridges for use. There is a warning to not power-cycle the printer until priming finishes. That all said, the priming process never started until after I power-cycled the printer. This is a minor complaint but it could prove confusing for some.

Installing the printer to work on the wireless network was simple. The software installer guides you through the process and explains what to do at each step. Where it got very interesting was in connecting to the wireless network - I was never prompted for the security key, yet the printer had no issue with connecting to the network and making itself available immediately. This is very convenient, though a little disturbing.

Once connected, the printer is immediately available and it is eager to please. It cranks out pages very quickly and the quality of print is very good. In the past I have had issues with Epson printers showing banding on color print and uneven lines when printing black and white but the new generation of Epson printers does not seem to have any issues with this - at least, not so far.

The printer monitor driver has a number of settings for manipulating output and printer features. Duplex printing is especially useful and is easily turned on and off through the driver. There are several quick settings for handling various document types (for example, switching between grayscale and photo print) and there is a facility for creating custom fast settings. I have not seen this in the past and find this to be immensely convenient over digging through all of the settings pages and turning on and off individual settings.

According to the documentation, the included ink cartridges should last through approximately 2 reams of paper. That's a huge improvement over smaller ink tanks that come with smaller printers.

The Epson WorkForce Pro 4020 printer is a very solid printer with a great feature set and robust software drivers. It's fast and the print quality is excellent. If you are looking for a printer that concentrates on just printing and doing it well, this is a fine choice and deserves a look.

title: Good Dry Erase Markers
text:
We use dry erase markers often in our house as my wife is a school teacher and she uses a whiteboard for teaching. We have tried a variety of dry-erase markers and these do well.

The packaging suggests that these are low-odor. This is an understatement - these markers have very little odor at all, even when held close to the nose it is difficult to detect any odor from these markers. This is a very good thing as it means that working in an enclosed area will not result in the room smelling of markers.

These markers write well and because of the chiseled tips they can write either thin or wide lines. The fluid comes out smooth and clean and leaves a distinct line on the whiteboard. The blue marker is not very bold and bright though, looking slightly washed out, but the other colors are fine and are vibrant.

The oval shaped caps on the markers are a great idea - no more markers that roll away when put on a table.

I don't like the eraser that comes in this kit. This kind of eraser does fine in the beginning before it gets dirty but once it has been used to a certain point the erasings get caked on and the eraser does little more than smear the board. Cleaning this kind of eraser also has proven somewhat difficult and we usually throw them away.

Compared to Expo markers, these are decent markers and make a fine alternative.

title: Paper vs Plastic
text:
My wife goes through a tremendous amount of school supplies in the course of a school year and these sticky notes are the kind of thing she uses every day. After using these sticky notes, we can say these are a mixed bag.

These particular sticky notes are touted as being see-through which allows for using them with documents without totally obscuring the text underneath. To that end, these are fantastic. We have tried these on papers where we wanted to see the text in spite of the note and we were able to read through the note without too much trouble. For that use, these are great.

As many other reviewers have pointed out, these are more plastic than paper and therein lies the issue with them. Depending on the type of writing utensil being used on these, it is very possible to get an ugly smudge or glob of ink because they do not absorb ink like regular paper. I use gel pens all the time and these do not mix well with gel pens (at least not the ones I use).

For marking pages and when used with the correct type of writing utensil, these are great. When used with the wrong type of pen, though, these sticky notes end up being more unpleasant than traditional paper sticky notes. Decide which is more important - translucence or absorbency - before using this product.

title: A Nice Modernization on a Classic Design
text:
I remember having one of the original style 4-color pens when I was in school. It was a neat pen and I used it quite a bit - until it broke. That pen was not the most durable of writing tools and I was disappointed when it failed me. The new style is quite a bit better and I am mostly happy with it.

This pen works as the original did - 4 colors, spring loaded and switching between them is as simple as pushing down on the color button representing the color ink you want. It writes well and it feels good in the hand. Two things distinguish this pen from the original, the build quality and the rubber grip.

This is a more solid pen than the original design. It feels like it is constructed to last a bit longer under the same conditions and it holds up when when shoved in pants pockets (an easy way to break one of the older pens). One problem I noticed with the older design is that it could be jammed so that the pen would have to be taken apart to get it working again - so far, this has not been a problem with this new pen.

The rubber grip is the other difference that sets this pen apart from its predecessor. This rubber grip is designed to combat the fatigue (aching fingers) that comes with writing for extended lengths of time, but I have found that the rubber is either too thin or too hard to help very much. It does make holding the pen a little nicer but it's not going to prevent cramping if using the pen for a while.

This is a worthwhile redesign of an old classic, and the price point is very reasonable.

title: Very nice entry-level 3-in-one printer
text:
Epson has for years been a leader in the printer market and has delivered good products to consumers. The NX415 is Epson's budget 3-in-one printer, with print, scan and copy capabilities. It is not perfect but it is difficult to overlook the price advantage.

Setting up the NX415 is simple and easy, except that there is no USB cable in the box. This is an aggravation that is easily avoidable. Considering that USB cables cost less than $3 US to wholesalers, there's little reason to not include one in the box. That said, the instructions for configuration and setup are clear and easy and the printer can be ready to go in a matter of just a few minutes.

This is one of the fastest printers I have worked with, though it is a bit noisy when churning out pages. There is a configuration setting that allows the user to print in "quiet mode" but the print speeds are reduced. I recommend using this mode, as the speed difference is not large and the noise difference is very appreciable.

One of the nicest features of this printer is the easy-to-follow display panel. Even though it is small it is very easy to read and the directions for changing settings are very clear. It is also tilt-able which makes reading it easier depending on how it is set.

I like the size footprint of this printer. This is much smaller than my Canon Pixma printer, and that's important to me as there is a premium on desk space. It tucks away neatly into a corner and is still very accessible.

I have not tried printing photos, but I have used it for multiple print tasks, specifically printing charts in black-and-white and in copying forms. It performs these tasks well.

There is one negative that is really worth mentioning - this printer guzzles ink. The printer itself is inexpensive but keep in mind that cartridges add up quickly. For volume printing, this is not a good choice; for light or even moderate print volume this printer is acceptable.

Epson also has an NX515, which is the same as the NX415 but includes wireless networkability. There is a cost difference, of course, and if wireless connectivity for the printer is not needed then the NX415 is a better choice from a price perspective.

Epson's NX415 3-in-one inkjet is a fine printer. It will serve a family or a small office well. It does tend to cost more per page to print as the ink consumption is high, but the speed and quality of output is a good counterbalance. Consider this printer when looking for a good quality budget 3-in-one.

title: Nice aesthetics.
text: This arrived today and it's going to be very useful to keep me organized. Love the leather cover. The only thing I didn't like were the do it yourself sticker tabs for the months. Even though I was very careful, a few are slightly crooked and it's gonna bug me. Overall though, great product.

title: Good choice but could be better
text: This is a wonderful choice and will help anyone wishing to organize their space. My only issue is the side height of each of the Basket shelves. Some items Can easily fall out unless you put them toward the center. The cart glides well across the floor. It is sturdy, spacious, safe and otherwise well designed.

title: Very Poor quality, hard plastic
text: This item is made from a very weak, plastic with almost no flexibility. The unit wobbles and appears to be of poor quality and design. The first drawer we untaped was cracked from the top to the bottom of the left side. Shipping only has one side of each drawer taped for transport. After further examination, cracks are found throughout the drawer.  In all fairness it may work in a spare closet or other light use area. I do not think it will hold up in a hobby, craft or any daily use setting. Bottom line~~~ we will not ever purchase this brand of storage again. We have many items of this type of storage and all with a better feel, quality and durability. Bad purchase

title: Not what I expected
text: I ordered the larger dry erase markers expecting the fluid to flow readily & smoothly. Not the case. I have to apply pressure to get a line & it is quite shadowy. Not the quick-flow, bright color I was expecting. I was surprised that I also have to apply pressure & wipe repeatedly to erase these markers. I am using them on laminated Bingo cards. I will be looking for a better quality set.

title: Sturdy enough to write on in your lap
text:
Love the top spiral. Love the sturdy cardboard back. Easy to write on without a table. Line spacing is just right for longhand.
My only suggestion is to make the perforations a bit deeper. It’s difficult to remove sheets at the perforation line without tearing the paper.

title: Good legroom for an adult
text: Very comfortable leg clearance. Good sized top for laptop or lunch. Legs are easy to open and close. Each leg had 2 flat bottomed stabalizers which keeps it level. I do wish the legs locked in place. I wanted to put this on the floor for my 11mo old grandbaby to use as a little play table but the legs collapse very easily.

title: Beautiful print and color
text:
Love these address stickers. Print and color are great. These work on the back flap of your envelopes. They are too large for front, top left of envelope.
The only reason I am not giving 5 stars is they are delivered on large flat sheets and are not easy to store. Wish they were 1/4 sheets or at the most 1/2 sheets.

title: The pop up is beautifully detailed. Very nicely constructed - stands on it’s ...
text: The pop up is beautifully detailed. Very nicely constructed - stands on it’s own. There is very little space to write on. I would have given 5 stars if it came with a piece of matching note paper to write your message on.

title: Pretty stationary and lovey hard box
text: Pretty stationary and lovey hard box. I should have read the description more carefully - no envelopes included. Not a super big deal, but I would have loved matching envelopes.

title: Nice, thick angles tip made it easy to write ...
text: Moved cross-country and used these markers to label all the boxes. Nice, thick angles tip made it easy to write with.  I was so happy I had them on hand. They didnt last as long as I expected.  I used up all 4 of them for 52 labels.

title: I like the smaller size dispenser
text: I like the smaller size dispenser - easier for me to manage with small hands.  Six pack was a great bargain and the tape is very strong.  I took away 1 star because I found it difficult to get the tape to roll for about the first 3 feet or so. I had to use two hands and tug and twist to get the tape to roll out for the first 3 feet or so of all six rolls.  I think the dispensers are just a bit too small for the size of the full roll.  Once I got the roll going, the dispenser worked fine and I could tape my boxes with one hand.

title: Not Boxes
text: Very disappointed. These are not boxes. They are  pieces of cardboard to put 'around' mirrors or picture frames, which only gives you 3 sides of protection (front, back and bottom). Basically, this is a piece of cardboard with 2 fold creases across the bottom to form a 2" base. I think this is intended to be used instead of bubble wrap???  Of no use to me at all.  The picture in the product description is not accurate. These are NOT boxes

title: Not for me
text:
I dont find the actual stationary to be as pretty as shown on Amazon. Not sure why they look so much nicer on Amazon.
The muted colors are muddy in my opinion and the designs are grainy. The paper quality is lower than expected and extremely thin. The envelopes are very flimsy and I personally will not use them for mailing via USPS. Sorry, for letter writing, this is not for me.

title: but the printed color is great. These cartridges dont last long
text: Expensive, but the printed color is great. These cartridges dont last long, so I opt to print in 'black only' most of the time to prolong the color cartridges.

title: Lightweight and easy to adjust
text:
Soooo easy to adjust and align both side with the 'click-in' position action. The front lip nicely holds your laptop in place when set at a higher angle. Surprisingly light weight and very portable. I can fold this flat and take it with me when I travel, no problem.
The only CON I have is the included fan cord is way too short. It is not long enough to attach to an ASUS Zenbook, so the fan is unusable for me.
It would be great if there were a version of this, without the fan motor, with vent slots.

title: Windows 10 - unable to get this to connect via wifi
text:
Windows 10 - unable to get this to connect via WiFi. I have downloaded the software and been thru the online setup guide and all troubleshooting options. No luck. Since this printer does not come with the squared ended USB cable, I need to order one. (sigh) A bit frustrating. Why not include the $3 cable? I mean, come on........

Update:
Successfully setup and printing via cable on windows 10 Laptop. Print quality is good. Like the 'black only' feature to preserve color ink
Please Note: When using the Scanner, the outer edges are cut off (@ 1/4 inch) if you align the doc to be scanned with the edge of the glass

title: It is 'stiff' and I think it should be much wider so you can position your feet comfortably. Not working for me
text: This hurts my lower back. It is 'stiff' and I think it should be much wider so you can position your feet comfortably. Not working for me......

title: Flimsy
text: Very Poor Quality.

title: Tiny
text: way too tiny I don't know if I can write that small. If you are tinkerbell and 5 inches tall this is perfect for you!

title: NONE OF THE ITEMS WORKED
text: NOT ONE OF THESE WORKED.

title: Pneumatic cylinder broke in under a month
text:
Decent enough chair, seemed fairly sturdy. However, after a few weeks, the pneumatic pump was shot. Now it doesn't lift/lower on its own, and the joint where it's connected to the base doesn't turn as well, making you need to put a lot more force to actually pivot. I'm only 240 lbs, so I sincerely doubt my weight would break a chair rated for 400 lbs.

In terms of comfort, it seems like it's not the best for my specific height, as it doesn't really fit well against my back. My lower back ends up not getting any support due to the contour of the chair, even with the lumbar support thing fully inflated.

Will just endure it, because I can't be bothered to actually get a new chair after buying this expensive hunk of metal. To be frank, I've had worse, but those were much cheaper/free. It supposedly comes with a warranty, but said warranty has a long and extensive list of things that they won't give a warranty if you do, like using the chair wrong, assembling it wrong, negligence, and any number of things which can be twisted into not getting a replacement or fix.

Edit: Under a year later, one of the plastic buttons used to hold up the arm rests popped off, launching a spring out. A bit over a year after buying, the second one also popped off.

title: Avoid these cheaply made pens.
text: These are by far the worst pens I've ever used.Three of them had little to no ink and those that did ran out real fast.  They're cheaply made - the number of the pen on the cap rubs off almost immediately and there is no number on the pen itself.  I would not recommend them and surely would never buy them again.

title: Buyer beware!
text: Once again, 2 of the pens have hardly any ink.  I'm so sick of this.  i was using another brand but the same thing happens.. not all the pens are good.  I will never, ever buy this brand again.

title: One Star
text: Once again, the M pen was all but dry, same with the F.

title: not like the medium in other brands
text: Paper was thin, not like the medium in other brands. I had to order Strathmore.

title: Disappointed
text: Really tiny print

title: Total garbage.  No magnetic hold.
text: I bought this to hold up a styrofoam panel.  I ran a line of magnetic tape around the edge.  The magnet didn’t hold at all.  I then cut off a small piece and stick it to my (metal) garage door and it couldn’t even hold itself up!  Total garbage.  I bought 5 rolls and they’re useless now.

title: Works as expected
text: Not a bad product, works as expected

title: Too big
text: It is too big and too slippery

title: Thick and durable, but needs better adhesive
text:
Love how these envelopes arrived, super cute packaging. Box contains 40 brown envelopes, 7.25 X 5.3.

The envelopes are very thick, and a great size for many uses. They are very durable. And, added bonus, I love how the Mr. Pen logo endorses the inside flap of every envelope, very nice touch.
I used permanent marker to address a few of these, and they are thick enough that the marker doesn’t bleed through.

I absolutely love most everything about these, my only complaint is that the adhesive doesn’t stick. I licked them, and even used a wet towel on the flaps, but on every one, they lifted up. For me, this wasn’t the bigger issue because I was putting monogram stickers on back to seal, but if mailing these, you’d have to either use glue, a sticker/label, or something else. (Oh, and I didn’t get a Mr. Pen mustache sticker!!! 😭)
I received these as a test product.

title: Good price, but not very comfortable
text: Assembly of the chair was pretty simple to follow. The mesh back & headrest are a nice touch, however the chair is pretty uncomfortable. The seat back is reclined too far back, and there isn't much adjustment that can fix it. So for those of us that prefer to sit up straight or sit forward, the chair is not going to work well. The arm rests are also too low for me. It's too bad because it really is a nice chair, just not designed that well.

title: Nice pens, they really do erase
text: These gel pens really do erase! Well, only with the eraser on the pen, but it works. The colors are nice, not quite as nice as my art gel pens, but still a fun touch for cards or for taking notes in class. I probably wouldn't use them to color in one of my adult coloring books. For those, I think I'll stick with my regular gel pens.

title: Good for home use until the dreaded printhead issue- Do not buy!
text:
For the price the Kodak ESP C315 is an acceptable printer for home use. I did have an issue with a paper jam when printing my daughter's book report. Perhaps it's a bit finicky when printing multiple pages at once. My other printer at home is a Canon MG5220. There are things I really like about it, such as the enclosed paper tray for 8 1/2 x 11 paper. I wish Kodak would implement that option, as the open rear paper tray seems to be a major dust & pet hair catcher around here. I like the more efficient ink cartridges in the Kodak printer. Replacing the cartridges in the Canon can be really expensive so this is a definite improvement. All in all, I'd say this is a good printer for using at home.

Update- I'd put the Kodak printer back in the box, and was using my Canon until recently. I brought it back out beginning of September when I needed it for printing my children's homework assignments. Within a couple weeks of use I began to have issues with the printhead. I kept getting errors that "the printhead is missing or installed incorrectly" no matter how many times I removed and put it back in. After looking around online I see that this is a common issue with the Kodak series, that some have had to contact Customer Service and get a new printhead upwards of 6 or more times. This is ridiculous. I printed maybe 20 pages total before the issue began. I was able to get a replacement printhead from Kodak customer support but it took nearly an hour on their Live Help before they'd send me one. They first had me try firmware updates and other pretty useless steps to finally prove to them that the error would not go away. If I get the issue again with the replacement, I'll probably just junk the printer (take it to the recycling center) and go back to using my Canon exclusively. There's very little difference in the ink costs to make this worthwhile and I'm pretty fed up at the moment with Kodak's idea of "support."

title: Scotch does it best!
text: I have tried to save a little money in the past by buying the generic tape, yet I find I always come back to Scotch. Their tape is easily the best value for the cost. Trying to save pennies has ended up with shoddy dispensers or sub par tape. I received the pink floral dispenser. The tape comes off the roll smoothly, and the cutter works great. It works really well for my kids' hands so we've put it in the art box.

title: Junk

title: Would not buy again
text: I am disappointed in this product. I do alot of page turning and this did  not work as I expected. I got a rubber finger tip and it is awesome works great. Don't waste your money on this product.

text: Doesn't work

title: Nope.
text: The adjustable height is great. That’s as far as it goes.  The seat is small and the back is so close to the seat you’re unable to sit comfortably.  The seat is also very hard.  After using it for a week my lower back aches so bad I can hardly walk.  So it’s back to searching for another one.

title: Still holding up
text: I had this product for almost a year now. The colors are still bright. Whenever it gets dirty, I just wash it with dish soap and water. I leave it out to dry. The sides where the keys are look a little frayed.  The lanyard is in great condition!
