title: These are wonderful storage containers for DVDs
text: These are wonderful storage containers for DVDs, only one problem.  They always arrive bent to some degree.  I have purchased 9 over the past month and everyone was bent.  I had to return 2 because the damage was so bad.  They have arrived with package material inside and some just stuck in a box.  Some look like they were damaged before they were shipped because there was no damage to the box.

title: Seriously adorable
text: The only reason this didn't warrant 5 stars were the cheap curtain hooks that came with the curtain. If not for them, this would be the BEST purchase I've made during Covid. The curtain itself is seriously cute. I mean....truly. I can't wait to hear the exclamations of 'Awwww'....if I'm ever allowed to invite anyone over to my house again. The shipping was SUPER fast (thank you Prime!) and it comes with a bag you can reuse if you have the patience to fold it up again at the end of the season. Totally worthwhile purchase!

title: You get what you pay for
text:
I had wanted to get a stylish but inexpensive journal and liked the design of this one. It came today and boy what a crushing example of bait and switch.
It is advertised as soft PU leather. The reality is the cheapest material worse than pleather binding.
They advertise a strong leather strap to keep journal closed. The reality is a very cheap pseudo suede string that will break with very little effort.
I had to actually give 2 stars because the binder type pages are really nice quality. However, the wrapping indicates 'craft fountain pen' which of course isn't included. Makes you wonder why that is on there.
If you don't need this journal to last over time or need a quick 'girl gift' for a Christmas donation it is worth spending the money. If however you want something substantial.....keep looking...nothing to see here.

title: Not as pictured
text: The colors in the actual product are a bit off compared to the pictures.  I wouldn't have purchased if I would have known.  Functionally, I'm sure it will be fine.

title: Don't Waste Your Money
text: It provides moderately more protection than packing paper; not much.  Local moving and storage companies offer a far superior product at a lower price.

title: Very Cute
text: It’s definitely not as vibrant as the product image but still very cute. It should last me for a while which is what is important.

title: Decent colorful envelopes
text: Decent colorful envelopes

title: Very large, quality mailers
text: If you are familiar with the packages that Old Navy/Gap/Athleta uses, these are similar although a bit thicker. They are also very large, they could easily fit 5-6 mens or womens clothing items, or of course you could fold it over as small as you’d like.

title: Sturdy books with decent paper
text: These books look just like the picture. The golden spiral is thick and the pages turn well around it. The individual pages are a decent weight, not overly thick, but definitely not thin. For about $7 per book, they seem like the right quality for the price.

title: Cute but expensive
text: These are definitely cute, and they are a nice quality, but you only get 8 (not 2 sets of 8 like another reviewer stated - they must have been sent two packs by mistake), so they are almost $2 per notebook. Which seems crazy when you can get a full sized, cute patterned notebook from Target for $2.50. Also we have gotten other sets of the same size notebook off Amazon, and even though those had plain colored covers, they were less than 50 cents each. These seem too expensive.

title: Perfect for Star Wars lovers
text: These are pretty standard valentines. They come in a tiny box and there are 18 envelopes included. You fold the cards in half and they are blank on the inside. Perfect for class exchanges.

title: Skip the lightweight, get these heavyweight protectors
text: I’m personally not sure why that many people would want a lightweight option of these, it seems like they would just be flimsier and less durable. In my mind for this product, I am equating heavyweight with quality and lightweight with cheap or value. These heavyweight ones are great, they just seem like a decent quality protector and are not bulky in any means. I’d quickly recommend them (and skipping the lightweight!).

title: Vivid colors and handy to have 2 in 1
text: These work well and are convenient to have the 2 color options on one highlighter! They are thin and for smaller highlighting jobs.

title: Cool idea, a bit hard to use
text: I like the idea of these binders and being able to contain and flip through papers without a 3 ring set up. The outside of the binder feels nice and the colors are bright and fun. When I first tried to open the clamp, I thought I was going to break it and only got it to spring open on the 4th try or so. I’m not sure if the clamp is a little cheap (and will break quickly) or if it is just difficult, but either way, each time I try to open it is not an instant process. Closing it is easy. I still like it, just not as awesome as I was hoping for.

title: Cool idea, somewhat hard to use
text: I like the idea of these binders and being able to contain and flip through papers without a 3 ring set up. The outside of the binder feels nice and the colors are bright and fun. When I first tried to open the clamp, I thought I was going to break it and only got it to spring open on the 4th try or so. I’m not sure if the clamp is a little cheap (and will break quickly) or if it is just difficult, but either way, each time I try to open it is not an instant process. Closing it is easy. I still like it, just not as awesome as I was hoping for.

title: Well made, tiny clips for up to 35 pages
text: These are colorful, well made clips. There are 60 in the pack. They are very small - well suited to hold up to 35 pages.

title: Great but expensive
text: These are great - work well, are vivid, come with a nice case for storage - but I’m not sure why they are $8!  24 Crayola pencils are $3 from Walmart...

title: Comes with a LOT of supplies!
text: This is a huge set that comes with a lot of supplies! You need to have a printer to take full advantage of the labels, but the envelopes and paper are nice quality.

title: Worth $3 Each??
text: These notebooks are nice, but nothing stellar. The cover is on the thinner side and they actually were delivered a bit beat up since they were shipped in a soft mailer. The header of each page is pretty small, just something I noticed that was different than a standard notebook page. Overall I really love the Yoobi brand and am normally super impressed, but these just seem fine. There is nothing wrong with them, but there’s also nothing that screams awesome.

title: Not sure they are worth $0.66 a piece
text: These are fine, but there is nothing at all impressive about them. They aren’t a high quality product, they aren’t super cheap at $0.66 per book, and they aren’t really going to fit much of anything either. The overall dimensions are fine, but there really aren’t many pages per book, the pages are thin and it won’t hold much information.

title: Small and cute, maybe a bit expensive
text: These little guys are small and cute. I got them for my 4 and 5 year old to use in their chapter books, and they are a great size and design for them and their small books. Overall they are cute, but I probably wouldn’t pay $20 for them myself. If they were around $12 that would seem more reasonable to me.

title: Great quality books!
text: These books are a great quality and the perfect size for my kids, 4 and 5, to keep in their bags for spare time. The larger notebook pocket fits pencils nicely. The pocket on the small notebook is a bit too small to hold much of anything, but my daughter put a little notepad in it. They are a great quality and fun, wish the price was a little less too, but overall still worth trying if you love the design.

title: Fine but seem expensive
text: These are bright and fun and sticky, but the whole set seems a little unimpressive for the price. They are pretty small to averaged sized sticky notes, so it feels like you don’t get much. Overall fun but pricey.

title: Write and erase well
text: These presharpened pencils write well and are fun and colorful. They sharpen well and the eraser works nicely too! Good value for a large pack of colorful pencils.

title: Cute and nice size
text: This pencil case is fun and well made. I think I prefer one larger pouch instead of the smaller pouches inside this one. This would probably be most ideal to only carry a few pencils and pens and scissors, not to carry a box of colored pencils or markers. But it’s cute and a nice size!

title: Comfy to hold
text: These pencils are easy to use and comfortable to hold. The grips are slightly cushy. The twistable erasers are nice since they’re bigger than most mechanical pencils erasers. Overall the quality is very nice!

title: Flimsy with faint lines
text: I’m not very impressed with these thin, flimsy cards. The lines are extremely faint as well. I’ll spend the extra quarter on nicer ones.

title: Great for 5 year old
text: These are bright and colorful and durable for my 5 year old at school. The plastic is thick and sturdy.

title: Not overly impressed
text: This dry erase board is fine, and not super expensive, but I wasn’t really impressed with it. The cardboard is really thin, and the border is really cheap plastic. The magnets and accessories are also pretty cheap. It’s fine and works because there isn’t much to fail, but I have had better made ones from Target.

title: Good value set of cards
text: This is a great set of cards to have on hand for various school birthdays that come up! The quality is not top notch (the cards aren’t super thick or sturdy), but the price is right for the quality and quantity. They are fun and cute and perfect for young kids, I’d say between 3 and 10.

title: Colorful and abundant
text: These are colorful and pretty with quality as expected for a large set of cards. They do not open, the “card” is a single panel. Envelopes are included. The quality is nothing impressive yet they do not feel cheap either - it is similar to the pack of 200 American Greetings single panel cards I bought this May for $15 from Amazon.

title: Single panel notes with envelopes
text: These are colorful and pretty with quality as expected for a large set of cards. They do not open, the “card” is a single panel. Envelopes are included. The quality is nothing impressive yet they do not feel cheap either - it is similar to the pack of 200 American Greetings single panel cards I bought this May for $15 from Amazon.

title: Slightly smaller than typical card, but good quality

title: Cute and simple
text: This card is simple but cute. It’s on plain white linen paper and looks nice, but not fancy by any means. Perfect for a good friend.

title: Nice message

title: Mispackaged!

title: I like that I was able to chose a paint of ...

Customer service was easy to get in touch with and they did assist me very well.
I will update in my other 2 cartridges of ink if there is a problem in the future timeline.

title: Fits my standard stapler.

title: Great for small to medium weight items

title: Decent paper

title: What can you say about stamps?
text:
Stamps are stamps.

What can you say about USPS? At least they introduced self adhesive stamps 10 years after other counties did. That is why they call it Snail Mail Service.

title: No frills pens for great price!
text:
A decent pen for a great price. No frills.

Great for someone or a business that loses lots of pens.

title: Nice gel pens but poorly fitting covers
text:
Nice pens with even flowing ink gel.

My only complaint is that the covers don't fit well, they slide off easliy when using the pens. My workaround is to wrap a thin piece of tape around the end of the pen so that the cover says with the pen. I leave the pens open on my desktop and they don't dry out.

title: Nice purse size notebook
text: Only 30 pages, pages are lined.  The list price is $1.50, so not a bargain here.  It is currently on a 4 for 3 deal which helps.  I would say it is worth 50 cents.

title: Velvety Soft but I Found The Elastic Restrictive
text:
I’ll start by saying that I love the mossy green shade of this fabric! It’s velvety soft and has an “enchanted forest” vibe. Each little pillow measures approximately 2.25” wide by 2.75” long, and the elastic bands feel strong and secure. There were some loose white and orange thread ends visible that I had to carefully trim away, and the stitched seams became somewhat apparent when the elastic was stretched, so some of the finished details seemed slightly undone to me. From a functionality standpoint, I feel that this product may only suit a select segment of customers. When I placed these cushions on my wrists, I felt like they restricted my circulation somewhat.

Diminished blood flow to the hands can cause a tingling sensation, so rather than providing strain relief from typing, these actually have the propensity to create a temporarily new problem. I also don’t wear elastic hair bands around my wrists for the same reason, so these simply weren’t a good fit for me personally, but they might be a beneficial accessory for some! I’ll stick with the free-standing, flat-bottom wrist support pads from now on, but these tiny pillows possess conceptual potential.

title: Marbleized Memory Foam Delights! ⌨️🖱
text: First of all, I love the marbleized swirl pattern of this Lycra fabric! It looks like metallic rivers of copper are intermixing with the waters of a luminous blue lagoon. The mouse pad and keyboard wrist support color-match each other perfectly, but the fabric on the *free* coaster is a completely different shade than the other two (more aqua instead of blue). The backs of the two main pieces have a black, rubberized, non-slip coating; the back of the coaster is a slick white plastic. The lumps are indeed filled with memory foam because you can watch them slowly rise back to their original shape once downward pressure has been removed. I do think that this is a quality set that’s been thoughtfully constructed, and the sizing seems efficiently tailored to the average working adult. The ergonomic design offers pleasing shapes with functionality, and these computer accessories help me alleviate some of the ulnar deviation wrist pain that comes from typing every week, so I’m pleased with the results overall. I just wish the coaster matched the others!

title: These Clips Are The Cat’s Meow!
text:
Adore this assortment of brightly colored and metallic cat-shaped paper clips! With a smooth coating, these felines are feeling fine. They come packaged in an adorable tin box that can also be used for storing a variety of other small keepsakes or office supplies.

They grip a single piece of paper without issue, but they could easily accommodate a slightly thicker stack as well. I think any family member or friend would enjoy these utilitarian meows!

I only deducted a star because the listing title and item description indicates a quantity of 60 paper clips, but my package only contained a total of 30 (with an equal distribution of 5 clips for each of the 6 colors available). I admittedly thought “you gotta be kitten me!” Other than the amount discrepancy, I’d highly recommend these cat cuties!

title: Too hard to punch
text: Letters were hard to punch out. Not worth the effort! Thin paper too.

title: My file folders don't fit!
text:
I got this to transfer my records from my accordion file. I filled it with letter size hanging folders and filing folders. The filing folders I bought don't fit, even though the size is standard. When I close it, it's a bit of a struggle. Sometimes when I open the lid, the flimsy file holders fall off. I think I can use an epoxy to glue them into place, since I don't plan on using legal size folders.

I would definitely not suggest getting this. It was a disappointment.

title: Dried up in a month!
text: Dried up in a month!!!

title: Smudges everywhere
text: Heavy smudges all over. Horrible. Will not buy again. I have bought a different knock-off (cheap) brand for my other laser jet and it smudges too, though much less. I don't think I'll ever try knock-off brands again.

title: works with big ergonomic keyboard
text:
As advertised. Solid and strong. The answered questions above were accurate with regard to how much space there is between the underside of the table and the tray...etc.Only 4 stars because it was quite a pain to put together. Had to flip my desk upside down to make sure I could see that all the holes were lined up before I drilled...I'm handy, but it took me many sweaty hours to finish. But worth it because it FITS MY BIG OLD MICROSOFT ERGONOMIC KEYBOARD!
UPDATE:
Out of pity for others who are trying to figure out whether they can really install this thing, I have now added two photos. The first is a basic shot of the keyboard tray underneath my desk, with a focus on the depth of the product. The second is a really quick drawing I made of it, indicating measurements. The numbers (if you can't read them in the photo) are from top to bottom: 11 3/4 inches, 8 3/4 inches, 14 1/8 inches (when closed), and 22 3/4 inches (when fully extended). My tray was mounted so that the edge of the keyboard is flush with the edge of my desk...you need not make it flush, but it might look best if it is flush.
What I had to really pay attention to was where the screws needed to go in!!! I had a gap in the underpaneling of my desk, and I was forced to use a very long screw to secure the deepest brackets. Hard to explain, but trust me--not fun. The point is, the measurement that mattered to me most was NOT 'how deep is the tray' but 'how far apart are the screw brackets'...and that is why I added these photos.
Hope they help someone.
Edit:
I am adding 3 new photos to help someone. The three new photos are all taken with the keyboard tray fully closed (as far as it will slide in). The tape measure reads pretty clearly in the photos I think. The third photo is of the front of the tray. The fifth and last photo is taken from under the desk looking up at the back of the tray. Yes, when fully closed, the glide rails stick out a bit beyond the wood tray--again this in the back. My tape measure reads 2.5 inches there, give or take a millimeter or two.

title: Mouse pad
text: Very nice large

title: HP ink
text: I like shopping online then in store.Better prices.Good value for the money.

title: Ink
text: Always like to order online. No problem. Wait for delivery.

title: Misleading advertising as refill
text: As others mentioned, this doesn’t fit the dispenser and it is being advertised as a refill. Misleading.

title: Don't buy this
text: The clip makes it next to impossible to wear. A complete waste of money

title: Huge
text: These scissors are huge and honestly, they appear clownish. I envisioned that they would be the same size as the standard medical scissors you become accustomed to but they're not. Not worth the effort to send back but if I had known these were so big, I wouldn't have purchased them.

title: Frustrating Disaster
text: Bought one, the ink wells dried, full of ink, refused to work after that.  Bought another one, same thing.  Bought a third, a newer model two months ago, and now it refuses to print because it tells me to "check your ink levels before you print" and my ink wells are full.  I tried to beat it to death today, so I can attest to the fact that the it's casing is pretty much indestructible.  So now, I have three of these that don't work, and a year's supply of ink that won't work on any other brand, evidently.

title: THERE IS NO TAPE DISPENSER FOR THESE GIANT ROLLS!!
text: It's too wide, there is no way to dispense it, since it sticks to itself.  So, I have to use scissors.  I made it through about a third of a roll and gave it up.  It took 5 times as long to seal a box with it as it does with any other tape.  I'll give the rest of it to the movers, maybe they can figure out what to do with it.  MAJOR disappointment

title: Color Assortment
text: Description is that it's a set of 8 binders, but they show twelve different colors, so I have to assume there's no way to know what colors you get.  For that reason, I will not be purchasing this item.

title: it's hard not to get seriously annoyed every time I have to replace a cartridge
text:
It prints well and clearly, but the cartridges CONSTANTLY have to be replaced - and at $58 for the XL 4-pak, where, incidentally ONLY the black is XL, it's hard not to get seriously annoyed every time I have to replace a cartridge. I've just got a little 330 printer and use it for usual home use.
Like the other reviewer said, ink cartridges should cost $2, not $12.

title: Not great for personal use - probably better for offices.
text: I had a stupid idea that instead of having 20 regular size file boxes, I could have ten, i.e. fewer to search through to find what I want.  Problem is, they're so big that if you fill them will files, they are too heavy to carry.  So, I have a dozen of these hanging around the house, taking up a lot of space, waiting for me to find lighter weight items to store in them rather than files.

title: I’m small and these made my chair too tall
text:
I’m petite, only 5 feet tall. Was looking to replace the factory wheels on my new desk chair because they were scratching up the vinyl flooring in my apartment. These wheels are great and I don’t think they would scratch the floor because they are made of a soft rubber-like material (not rubber). They look great on too for those wanting to consider aesthetics and are pretty quiet and smooth. They glide VERY EASILY. Almost too easily, especially since I now cannot reach the floor even at the chairs lowest setting, it’s a little hard to get the chair where I want it and stay there. Overall all I think this would be a great product/solution for those who are average height or taller.

Unfortunately for me though, I’ll need to return them. Also, I may have received a used product. The wheels had minor signs of wear and came in a plain, white box with no paperwork or stickers of any sort. Not a big deal since the installation is pretty self-explanatory but I really think Amazon should disclose when it is a “used” or “refurbished” product. You order and pay for a new product so that is the expectation.

title: Lovely calendar, but the paper quality can be improved.
text:
Very lovely calendar that looks handsome on our wall. The standard American holidays are on there, and there's enough space in each square to write a few short events.

The paper can be different, however. It has a matte feel but the print isn't clean. There's some pixelation, if slight, on the edges of some text. The month's page also curls at the bottom edges, so it can look a bit weird on the wall.

title: Fun, but difficult to fully clean.
text: Great cards that work as expected, save for one issue: difficulty in cleaning. Sure, they're very thin so I'm not expecting thick whiteboard material, but getting them perfectly white requires a few wipes, even with whiteboard-cleaning spray.

title: Lock isn't too bad.
text: Good stash bag to keep in the home. I read other reviews that indicated the lock can be fussy. For my purposes, the lock is fine. I'm the only person who uses it and it's for my stash. The dials can be a bit stiff, but rotate fine. I do think the way the zipper pulls lock can be too precise for some, but, again, it works fine for me. I wish there were 4 dials to keep it more secure, but for such a small pouch 3 is fine.

title: Mostly fine, but wish it were thicker.
text:
Not bad for the price. I journal daily and have other notebooks for various reasons. I carry at least two in my backpack because my thoughts flow more naturally than if I were to type them. Stream of consciousness doesn't mean I have to go back and edit my own work; journaling, for me, is perfect for that.

Anyway, I wanted to get this to better store my notebook and other writing gear I use. Currently, I use a writing mat, blotter, a ruler, and several pens and pencils. I use a laptop sleeve that has an extra compartment for small tech gear; all my stuff fits nicely, but I'd prefer something tailored specifically for my stuff. This portfolio fits my Endless notebook perfectly, but not if the back were tucked into the pad. That extra slip in the inside back of the portfolio lets notebooks with no hardcover be tucked it, which makes it no wonder that my Endless notebook doesn't fit.

Unfortunately, I couldn't make the most of this portfolio. I got it also because it has pen loops. The pen loop slip is removable, but I wanted to keep it there to house my fountain pens. The widest pen I placed in the loop was my Pilot Custom 823 and there was no squeeze. But closing the portfolio showed that I can't keep the pens and notebook inside with the portfolio closed. When I opened it back up, I saw dents in my notebook from the pen clip, which makes me very worried how long-term use will be. The other compartments are tight so only a few slips of paper or a ruler will fit.

title: Great after all these years.
text: I used these notebooks a while back. They were some of my first notebooks to doodle in. I thought it'd be great to get them for my kids. They're always looking for paper for various activities. The covers aren't as rigid as they used to be, but the paper is great (a bit thin, but does the job). Having them spiral-bound is plus so that the notebook can be completely flipped.

title: Timer is awesome. Whiteboard? Not so much.
text:
My family loves TIME TIMERs. We're a family of ADHD'ers (thanks to me), so we have a handful at home, and I have one at work. We use them daily. I thought this whiteboard version would be great for work since I also use whiteboards to help me be on top of tasks.

It's a weird setup. The whiteboard is about the size of a B5 sheet of paper, but, as you can see from the photos, there's a chunk taken out for the timer. Because of the size of the whiteboard, this takes out quite a bit of writing space. In theory, it should work well for things like the pomodoro technique, where you can write a task and set a timer for it. But writing more than that is not possible. Also, as for the actual writing experience, it's quite uncomfortable. There's a nice tray in the back to keep markers and erasers, but it's non-removable. This makes writing on the whiteboard on a flat surface impossible. The angle of the whiteboard makes my wrist cramp.

The materials are top-notch. I wish more whiteboards came as sturdy as this one. Unfortunately, I removed the timer (thank goodness that's removable, at least) and put the whiteboard in my desk.

title: Not the most effective eraser.
text:
On first use, I realized this is not a good eraser. In theory, the reusable wipes are great, and the fact that the replacements go inside the holder is awesome, but the shape of the eraser and the reusable wipes is uneven. The reusable wipes are smaller than the holder, so when I'm erasing something I can't exactly see what I'm erasing. The actual surface area of the wipes is smaller than what I'm holding.

Now, for large areas, that wouldn't be an issue--if it erased well. The eraser needs a lot of force and multiple swipes before anything is erased. And even then the markings are never completely erased. Such a shame, too, because I loved the idea of having an eraser that used reusable wipes and stored the wipes inside the container.

title: A life saver.
text:
As someone diagnosed with ADHD not too long ago (but lived a lifetime of knowing I most likely had it), I've gathered lots of resources and advice to make my organization better. One was utilizing whiteboards. I had my eye on a similar whiteboard to this listing, but this one met my needs better.

For one, it comes with storage that I can make most use of. There's a deep groove at the top to hold a couple writing instruments; I store a couple dry-erase markers in there. And the little circle groove to the right of that holds another marker but only if it's standing. I currently use Pilot Board Master S (ultra fine); they're too narrow for the circle groove, so it tilts a bit, but they're perfect for the longer groove on top.

The board is very easy to clean and indeed glass. In fact, all it is is just clear glass over a white base. I wish I got a non-glass version because the glass creates a small shadow underneath the writing, but it's not that big a deal. I just like the cleaner look of marker on a non-glass whiteboard.

To the right there's a calculator. Admittedly, I put that thing out of site because (1) I already have a few calculators and (2) I wanted to use it for more storage. Thankfully, it's removable, revealing two storage compartments underneath (albeit uncovered without the calculator). I keep a Rubik's cube knock-off and dry eraser there.

Underneath the glass are three more storage compartments: one as wide as the glass and two half-size compartments. The half-size ones have thin, protruding grooves, which are prefect for keeping more markers without them rolling around. In the long one I keep a cleaning cloth that I use when it's time to deep clean the board.

It's been great using this. I write quick notes and it makes my daily tasks more manageable.

title: Perfect for our family.
text:
Got this to write down the weekly schedule for our kids. Since half our family has ADHD, we struggle with timing. I personally must have things written down at work or else it's completely forgotten. I have multiple whiteboards, stickies (which I'll replace with reusable notes), a TIME Timer, and my phone. At home, while we have a command center and another calendar in a different room, I thought the kids having their own schedule on their wall will help.

So far it has. This whiteboard is nicely built and sturdy. The weekly print is bold and I hope it'll last a while. One thing I wish is that it had more lines. The markers it comes with are shockingly good, but the tip is a bit wide, so some schedules run into multiple lines. Still, I appreciate it came with a lot of colors so we can color-coordinate the schedule. We use the magnets to mark days complete. We haven't used the blank side yet, but I'm sure it'll come in handy.

title: Pretty good.
text:
Along with another organizer, this is used to organize my stationery at work. It has enough compartments for me because I can separate the types of pens, pencils, and refills I have. The bottom drawer houses my wooden pencils, and is even long enough for Blackwings.

The metal construction is great. The only wish I have is that the pen trays had a mesh-type bottom rather than slits; because of the slits, sometimes my pens will roll over awkwardly, but this is more of an aesthetic desire rather than utilitarian.

title: Excellent!
text:
I use it to store my notebooks and random paper supplies at work. The top cubby for pens is a super-nice touch; I store taller instruments there, and the shorter ones in the drawers. Note that the drawers aren't the same length; because of that cubby for the taller instruments, the top two drawers are shorter than the bottom most.

It's very sturdy and I have no fear of it breaking here at work.

title: Super clear, seems sturdy, but a bit thin in the fingers.
text:
I used these to sort printed recipes. Sure, recipes are available digitally (and I even have an app that lets me read recipes from my cloud), but sometimes paper is nice to have around. Okay, a lot of times.

So I got a bunch of the printed recipes that had been stacked in a kitchen cabinet. It became so unwieldy that we had no idea how many recipes we had, or which ones. So away I organized.

Most of the pages opened right away; some took a bit more pulling apart. One even seemed to glued shut, but I got it open. When I was inserting the recipes, I felt that the pages were a bit thin. I'm not sure how they'll hold up in the long term, but I guess that's something future me will have to deal with when it happens.

Once everything was in the binder, though, it was awesome. The pages are super clear and, somehow, make some sheets more legible. Weird.

title: Excellent organizer, though I wish it were a bit taller.
text:
Ordered this to replace our old crayon organizer, which was a solid piece made of wood. It certainly was sturdy, but there was very little modularity and the rotating wheel broke off. We opted for this plastic iteration as a replacement.

I was concerned about the "slices" being removable easily, but so far they've stayed in place. My main concern was them staying in place despite constant use, but so far so good. I like that they're removable so that my kids won't have to fight over who gets to have the organizer near them. While this has more room than our previous one, it's a bit short. Colored pencils stay in place, but I wish the organizer was a bit taller anyway.

title: Works great for gaming. Tabletop gaming, that is.
text:
After realizing I needed more space for an LCG I'm playing (Lord of the Rings), I browsed larger play mats. The largest I had was a 24x24 two-player play mat; it fit everything I wanted, but I realized I needed something that was shorter and wider rather than wide in all directions. There are some good play mats dedicated for card games, but the prices can vary. Then I realized I'd have better results when searching mouse pads with the dimensions I wanted.

This is the perfect size for my game. I can fit all the cards I need horizontally, and the shorter vertical height helps with having the enemy deck closer so I can read everything. I don't rotate my cards, but I did try on this mat to find out how it worked. Overall it was fine, but the mat did give some resistance. I don't fault the mouse pad though since it's not meant for my current use. The cushioning also helps me pick up cards more easily since I can dig my fingertips a bit into the mat.

title: Fine for single sheets or small books, but awkward.
text:
I use a plastic book stand at work that I love. It's able to fit nearly any sized book. The page holders even allow for frequent page turning because the arms end in small rollers. But I wanted one for home, so I ordered these.

The metal is nice and it feels sturdy--for the base, that is. The arms are a lot thinner and easy to bend (case in point: my daughter did so in the first five minutes). The stands are fine for smaller books with plenty of text, or single sheets. The angles are okay too. The arms are a disaster. They make page-turning more cumbersome because I have to flip the bottom arm down and finagle with the arms. They move easily when I'm trying to turn a page, so I just put them behind the stand. But there's no way to easily put them back there, so I bend them just a little.

The colors are perfect for spring if you're into that.

title: Comfy!
text:
So far, so good. I use these and another arm rest by the company. Seeing as I have an L-shaped desk, it's important to have my hands and arms as comfortable as possible. The keyboard rest is a bit short for my dual keyboard/num-pad setup, but the rest is made for a TKL anyway.

The mouse rest is nice too. It's a bit short for my liking, but does the job.

The texture on these are nice and supports my wrists comfortably.

title: Makes life more organized.
text:
I've used several label makers at work recently, but the last one I actually owned was from the 90s. You know, the ones that printed the raised, white letters on black (and later, colored) tapes? It's been a while since I labeled things at home, but with current technology I had a strong itch to do so.

This particular model is nearly perfect for home use. It's a bit bulkier than it needs to be, but the bulk does make it comfortable to hold. The screen is as clear as it needs to be, and finding the settings becomes second nature. I've used nearly all the fonts, frames, and sizes, and haven't had a complaint. This is for the actual maker itself.

My gripes come with the tape and dispenser. The tape this maker accepts is on the thin side, so big labels are out of the question. The fonts aren't crisp, so there is some fuzzing around the letters, etc. There is also a LOT of tape wasted because of the distance from the cutter to the ejection border. I feel they could make the cutter closer to save on tape. Even with the margins at the thinnest, the maker wastes more tape than I'd like; it certainly doesn't help that official cartridges are about $15 each.

Still, organizing things around the home is easy. Depending on the tapes you get, the labels are durable and last many washes. My daughters take water bottles to school and they're required to have their names on them. I slap on a label and it lasts about a month's worth of dish-washing.

title: Still don't get how to use these.
text: I've gone through two before, this is my third. This one is more difficult to use, but more comfortable to hold. I use official Scotch packing tape to seal packages. Since the packages vary in length, I thought these dispensers would make taping easier. My experience led me otherwise. The tape is difficult to place onto the box, and it's even more difficult to rip off. I go through two or three times before I get a good seal on the box, which is a waste of tape. I've resorted to using just the standard disposable dispensers.

title: Great if it didn't skip a lot.
text:
I've been into fountain pens for over a decade. My two first pens were a Pilot and a vintage Esterbrook. Since then, I've honed my tastes and know what I like.

Given the opportunity to try a Parker 51, I immediately jumped on the opportunity. Initial impressions were fine. The pen came with a cartridge which I used since, when the ink ran out, I was gonna re-use with a syringe. The cap is metal, while the body is plastic. It's a weird balance when capped or posted, so I leave the cap off. The body leading to the nib is a nice look, but the nib skips a *lot*. Every time I begin writing with this pen, there is some scribbling required to get the pen out, and if I pause for too long I have to rewrite a letter or so to get the ink pouring again.

It's very easy to take apart and clean, but the price isn't justified for the quality.

title: Nice pen, but skips a lot.
text:
Lovely pen that unfortunately skips a lot, and in my opinion is overpriced for what it is. The resin body is polished but scratches easily. The cap is awesome; it's metal and weighted. However, this gives an unbalanced feel when posted. Since the body is composed from a light resin material, there's an awkward dive toward the cap.

The pen skips every time I write with it. I've gone through a refill, and not matter how often I start the pen skips. Once it flows, it flows.

title: Overall good, but skipping can be annoying.
text:
Lovely pen that overall performs as I would expect a pen at this price range. The weight is nice, though a bit lighter than expected. It feels great in my hand. The nib width is pleasant; I opted for a Medium. I know western medium nibs are wider than eastern widths, but I wanted to try a wider than preferred nib this time. I'm not disappointed.

However, the pen does skip every time I start writing with it. Once I get the ink flowing, there's little to no skipping, though always at the beginning.

title: Extremely stiff. Wrinkles upon first opening.
text: The only reason I gave this portfolio an extra star is that it looks nice and has a lot of features. But that's all. It's very stiff and upon first opening there are permanent wrinkles on and near the binding.

title: Fine. A bit small.
text: They work well, but are a bit small. The hook isn't large enough to fit 'round a door handle. Also, some doors move right over them because the gap is too wide.

title: Works.
text: Works well as a door stopper. We have it indoors so we cannot test its outdoor strength, but thus far has withstood its durability against slippers and dust bunnies.

title: See-through.
text: These are very clear. So much so that after using five I stopped using them. I had to use more paper inside to mitigate the silhouette's conspicuousness. The adhesion was fine, but some of the envelopes came with the plastic film coming off, so they tended to stick to other envelopes.

title: Fairly lightweight, difficult to hang
text:
My husband and I found this chalkboard difficult to hang. There also isn't a spot to place chalk or chalkboard markers when not in use. When I tried this out, however, both regular chalk and chalkboard markers worked well. We currently have this hung in our office for our to-do lists for the day.
This is a great addition to a playroom or work space. I would, however, be mindful of how to hang it. This was not an easy task!

title: Fun decorative piece
text: My daughter is just beginning to read and has loved using this! It’s fun to leave little messages for family members. I haven’t attempted to hang this on the wall but it sits nicely on the easel provided. I’m subtracting one star because of the letters. When they arrived they were all attached to one another. It took me forever to take the apart! All of the letters also don’t fit in the baggie provided which is inconvenient.

title: Lovely, but not sure how I'm going to clean this.
text:
Brought this thing to work to see how it would fare in an office environment, and whether it would enhance the sound of my mechanical keyboard. The lighting effect isn't too glaring; thankfully, there's a pulsing mode which makes the light "breath" in and out, so it's not always super bright. It even changes colors in the breathing mode!
The mat comes rolled up in a box with just a micro-USB cable. There are no instructions, but for this you don't really need any. Just plug in the cable and tap the button on the mat controller. The buttons cycle first through colors, then through a strobe mode (not recommended), then to a pulsing mode (which is what I have it on), then completely off. Very simple.
The mat feels really good. A soft, cloth texture on top, but seems pretty durable so as to withstand a long period of time. The keyboard I have it on now is made of solid aluminum, so we'll see how it holds up over time. The bottom is VERY grippy. I tried moving it and had to lift it up completely to do so.

I'm not sure how I'll be able to clean this because of the electronics. I was hoping to toss it in the wash but that doesn't seem possible. The listing states it's very easy to clean, so we'll see once it comes time to do so. If I remember I'll update this review.

A bonus is that, because this if my first cloth mat, the sound of my keyboard is actually a lot better. I have tactile switches which sound more deepened. Nice!

title: Fine. Can't put them on a wall due to the angle.
text:
These are good, basic trays for pens. We use them for our dry-wall boards. We tried to attach them to the wall with 3M velcros, but the mesh walls don't let them stick well, if at all. It may be due to the angle of the container as well, but that lets it to grab and see instruments inside more easily.

Since these come in a pack of three, we use two for pens and erasers, and the other I use to house wooden pencils currently in use at my desk. They don't feel flimsy at all so expect them to last a while.

title: This little printer packs a punch!
text: This little printer packs a punch!  Great image quality when printing photos.  Very easy to connect to your local wifi network and print from your cell phone or tablet.  Don't expect it to be a work horse, but it is great for printing small jobs once in a while.  Wish it was faster.

title: Great product, confusing set up.
text:
Reviewing the Epson Scanner. It was a bit confusing while setting up because the instructions stated that the scanner shouldn’t be connected to the laptop. Then it stated to download the software from the internet. So there was a delay trying to figure out if the scanner needed to be connected directly to the internet and but didn’t know how to do this. After a few minutes I realized the instructions meant the scanner shouldn’t be connected to the laptop via USB cord and the software needed to be downloaded to the laptop being used to set up the scanner.

Once I figured this out I was able to easily and quickly follow the 3 step set-up guide and "viola" I scanned a picture with the Epson DS-770 scanner. Now I have a beautiful picture of my daughter on my computer. It took me 15 minutes to scan the picture but would have taken me less than 10 minutes if the instructions where a bit more clear for those of us that are not as tech-y.

The Epson-DS770 is compact and makes scanning a breeze. Very cool!

title: Super fast printer. A few hiccups, but overall very, very pleased.
text:
The installation process was extremely easy. The touch screen guides you through the process step by step. It starts with a series of questions (date, time, etc). It then prompts you to install the ink cartridges that come with the printer. This is a great deal as these ink cartridges can cost a pretty penny. The cartridge installation takes approximately twenty minutes. While it is installing, you can complete the remaining steps. It then prompts you to place paper in the paper tray. You will need to place paper in the paper tray in order to complete the installation process, so make sure you have some handy.
I did notice that it didn't ask me to calibrate the color settings, etc., as my previous printers did, but there are options to do so once all the initializing has completed.

You are able to install the printer app on your smartphone in order to access information regarding the printer (printing, scanning, capture document, look at printer settings). By the time we arrived at this step, the installation process was about half-way done. We needed to wait another ten minutes or so until we could install the printer on our computers using the CDs that came with the printer, although I'm sure you can download the latest software from HP's website.
We downloaded the software on all our devices, and did our first printing from a phone--coupons. The image came out blurry, though I'm not sure if that's because it was the first print or because it was from a phone. The fine print on the coupon was unreadable, whereas it's easily readable from our previous printers (that cost a third of this!).

That said, we waited a while and did some additional printing from out computer, and the images came out as clear as crystal.
However, we did have some issues with printing from Safari and Chrome; Firefox printed without issue, so I'm not sure what the disconnect is here. May follow up once I've figured it out.

We are using this printer for personal use at home. We will mostly use it for small work projects, school assignments, and, mostly, coupon printing. It is a bit on the bigger side for a personal-use printer, but it is extremely user friendly and efficient. The ink cartridges are expected to last a while which makes their price fairly reasonable, compared to other printers. The look of the printer is extremely sleek and sophisticated. I was worried about the white as most of our previous printers had a glossy finish, but I was extremely pleased when it came and I saw the finish is a nice, textured matte finish. This way any dust and whatnot won't show as easily.

So far we like it, despite the minor gripes mentioned above. We did all the calibrating available, and the prints are super fast. The ink comes out a bit heavy on plain office paper, though there are settings to set the density. (Husband note: I plan on printing custom home video covers, so I'll be ordering special paper for that; I expect the print quality will be better.)

title: Swingline's the way to go.
text:
I've got two staplers at work, both from Swingline. One's the infamous red one, and the other's a silver one with a mirror finish. I love my Swingline staplers, and get upset whenever someone tries to take mine.
They're built to less, and I've had no jams whenever using Swinglines.

This 747 "classic" stapler is pretty much the same thing, constructed in a smooth matte finish, but what I don't like about it is that it has a rectangular head. My other staplers have a smoother finish that makes it look sleeker.
Functionality-wise, there's no difference; it's just personal preference. Some may prefer the flatter top as there's less of a chance of the hand slipping when stapling a heavy stack. I, however, have had no issues with my others, thankfully.

Wow. Can't believe I went that much at length to describe a stapler. Who knew staplers are not built the same, despite having a sole purpose?

title: Works great for our whiteboards.
text:
We use three out of the four markers right now, and will use the other once one of those runs out. We have two whiteboards on our fridge--a calendar and one general notepad--and I have a larger one in my office which I use to take notes for my writing.

I prefer the fine tip because I have tiny handwriting as it is, and it leaves me with far more space to use on the board. The price is right too.
I would make these better by having an eraser on the cap of each marker, but that would probably raise the price.

All in all, a good set of whiteboard markers.

title: Two serious flaws.
text:
While this calendar is a fair size for the price (really, $7 ain't bad), there are two things which really dock this calendar down a few stars. The adhesives it comes with for the magnet backings are 3M, but are not powerful enough to hold the calendar on the fridge. It slides down on its own, so I've managed to keep it in place by buttressing other magnets underneath. Thankfully, it doesn't fall completely off the fridge.

It's nice that it comes with additional magnets, but, since the calendar is quite tiny as it is, there's really no space to put the magnets on if you're going to write all over the calendar, so we've moved them off.

We use this board primarily for meal planning, and my wife and I constantly have to rewrite our plans once we've started them because we forget that the week starts on a Monday in this calendar. It may not seem like a big deal at first, but considering almost every calendar we use starts with Sunday it becomes quite the nuisance after a while. I have no idea why this company decided to start it on a Monday.

So, because this calendar can be stuck onto a regular wall, it's not bad on that part, but like most families we got this dry-erase board to use on the fridge. We still use it daily, but there are far better options, even if they do cost a bit more. The fact that this slides down the fridge and starts the week on a Monday seriously flaw this otherwise budget-friendly planner.

title: Almost Lie Flat
text:
If it's not Post-Its, I'm hesitant to try them. Still, Post-Its are relatively higher priced, so any alternative would do.

These Averies work fine for my purposes. I use them to smack onto the edges of my computer monitor, as well as the wall next to me for work-out routines. They stick on for a few weeks before beginning to peel off.

They come in the standard colors, though the off-yellow is a bit ghastly. If you want true lay-flats, go with the Post-Its that have most of the surface with the adhesive material.

title: Good; could be great.
text:
The shredder works great. As someone who works in an office, we outsource most of our large documents for shredding, but keep little docs here for personal shredding. Now that I can have one at home, it's much more convenient.
I use it to shred package invoices addressed to me, as well as excess papers which I've already scanned and saved digitally. I hate having my name and address on papers that I won't keep, so having a shredder comes in handy. This Amazon Basics seems well built and has lasted me quite a while thus far. I haven't had to clean it yet, though the only issue I have is that it can take less papers than the ones we have in the office. I have to make sure the papers are straightly aligned, and since the shredder's in a corner it can be a wee bit difficult sometimes to make sure all edges are straight.

Otherwise, it's fine. Amazon seems to know what they're doing with their Basics line, so I've no complaints other than the straight edges.

title: Design is superb, but removes functionality.
text:
The perks amongst this dispenser are that 1) it's heavy, and 2) it looks sleek. Unfortunately, the driving factors aren't enough to qualify this purchase.

I have two tape dispensers at work: the bare-essentials Scotch dispenser, and this one. I have already forgotten I own this one. Upon noticing it now, it has attracted a lot of dust, and my area doesn't even get that dusty. Another minus point.

My biggest complaint is that it's sometimes--often, actually--difficult to get the tape out. The way I grab the tape, my fingers seem to hit the little hole the tape protrudes from. Since I like to get even, clean cuts, the dispenser doesn't allow me to do so. Also, the weight of the dispenser is uneven. There's lots of weight, but it always tilts every time I get some tape.

It's nice and all, but I would recommend just going with the cheaper, more basic alternative.

title: Neato idea.
text:
Although it may seem like this product is a waste of paper since you're tearing and leaving the adhesive portion behind, the pad has come quite in handy. Yes, you have to have the "trouble" of disposing of the adhesive part, but for me the papers work well on the fridge and the cabinets at work.

My wife and I used to have a dry erase board on the fridge for memos, but she had to use it for her therapy sessions, so I've been forgetting many things lately. Thankfully, these work just as well (and at times better) since I can just put a sticky on the fridge, write down what needs to (such as a grocery list), and actually take it with me if I so desire. The back pages of the sheets don't have rulings, but that's fine as I don't really use the back. The perforations don't come undone, either, when you're removing a page from the pad, but they remove easily when you need to remove them from their stickied surface.

I also use them at work since I don't have a dry erase board or corkboard, and they work marvelously well for quick notes.

title: Good pens, but a bit light.
text: Bought these for my wife to use on our fridge magnet board.  She uses the board for her therapy sessions, but I've found that these markers are not that prominent with their colors as is the marker that came with the board.  The ink seems to be somewhat sustainable, but the colors could use a bit more juice.

title: They're adequate.
text:
I'm a lit grad student, so I use flags all the time. I'm also very particular about which flags I use, and my favorite are the Post-it Arrow flags, but I had a chance to try these out. They stick a lot stronger than the Post-it brand, and sometimes they tear the page when removing them. They're also very difficult to write on, as I tried making a quick note on the clear part in pencil but it ended up looking glary and soft, almost as if I was writing on magazine paper.

Overall, they're much cheaper than the Post-it brand, and as such a strong alternative.

title: Excellent product, but seems a bit bulky and pricey.
text:
Now, the title is coming from someone new to the world of binding machines. My fiancee is a 4th-grade math teacher, so I thought this would be of great assistance to her. I didn't know what to expect, and was a little dumbfounded when I first set it up, but then I realized just how easy it was.

You can only put 20 sheets of paper at a time to punch the holes in, but it works flawlessly. The actual binding mechanism left me a bit hesitant at first, as I thought it was too easy and there was something I was doing wrong. Once the machine took over, however, my fears were tossed at sea.

So why the one less star? Perhaps it's just me, but it seems a bit heavy and pricey for just what it does. Again, I'm no binding machine expert, and I'm sure the electronic version is far superior to the manual, but $275 is a bit much considering it only punches 20 pages at at time, and 26 pounds seems overwhelming, especially since it's electronic.

The machine is going to stay in the house for years to come, or as long as someone stays a teacher, and has already served its purpose in the short time that we've had it.

title: Simple enough.
text:
I use writing instruments daily, so a pen/cil cup is a near necessity. While I prefer larger cups, this one was so stylish, and looked like it would complement my brown desk well, that I decided to get it. It's a bit small in the end, but it holds all my pencils fine.
The outside of of brown, stitched leather fake?), with a nice pattern, which you can see in the picture (only two sides have this pattern, the other two sides are plain, but stitched on the borders). The inside is a rougher felt, but not so that it scratches or scuffs the shiniest of pens. It seems it was intended to reduce the "plunk" of pens being tossed in.

Overall, it's a nice little cube, and the $4.99 ain't too bad. If it holds up for years to come, I'd say it's a worthwhile purchase if you don't want to use mugs or other cups for pencils.
Again, I prefer larger cups--and meshed so that little scraps of paper and lead won't stay inside, or even dust--but if you want a nice-looking brown, closed-in cup, this is a good one.

title: Good, but some template issues.
text:
The following is my fiancée's review of the labels.

My fiancé and I used these labels for our Save the Date postcards for our wedding. We put all of the addresses in Excel and we were able to easily transfer it to Word for the template for the labels. It was fairly easy to figure out the template for the labels. When they printed out, they looked really good. There was a small problem with some of the labels - they printed out off center. I'm not sure if this is because of the template or because of the printer. I simply moved them over in the document and they printed out okay. About three out of 100 labels were messed up. I recommend these labels. I'm happy that we chose these labels for our Save the Dates. When I put them on the postcards, they looked really good =)

title: Good, but not great.
text:
As many reviewers on here, I too sell a lot o' crap on eBay and Amazon.com, and, quite frankly, I grew tired of using regular paper to print out shipping labels and using office--er, home...tape to seal them onto packages. I thought I'd give these a try to alleviate many issues I had with shipping labels.

Overall, I'm very pleased with Avery's product, and especially the new TrueBlock technology. Since I'm a regular seller on eBay, I grew accustomed to saving old boxes of every size, and most of them have old shipping labels. What I used to do is peel them off, or cut them out with scissors. It grew quite messy, and consumed too much of my time. I then placed an order for these and they make shipping much, much easier. Though I still take out as much as I can of the old shipping labels, I don't have to do so as much since the TrueBlock technology really does work in blocking out the old label when applying the new one on top.
Also, I don't really use receipts as much since I print packing slips and keep track of the finances online, but I'm sure they would come in handy for someone opting for this Avery set.
After ordering this set and Avery's 8127, I found that this one sticks better.

title: Excellent, and the TrueBlock technology's great.
text:
As many reviewers on here, I too sell a lot o' crap on [...] and Amazon.com, and, quite frankly, I grew tired of using regular paper to print out shipping labels and using office--er, home...tape to seal them onto packages. I thought I'd give these a try to alleviate many issues I had with shipping labels.

Overall, I'm very pleased with Avery's product, and especially the new TrueBlock technology. Since I'm a regular seller on eBay, I grew accustomed to saving old boxes of every size, and most of them have old shipping labels. What I used to do is peel them off, or cut them out with scissors. It grew quite messy, and consumed too much of my time. I then placed an order for these and they make shipping much, much easier. Though I still take out as much as I can of the old shipping labels, I don't have to do so as much since the TrueBlock technology really does work in blocking out the old label when applying the new one on top.
Also, I don't really use receipts as much since I print packing slips and keep track of the finances online, but I'm sure they would come in handy for someone opting for this Avery set.

UPDATE 2/23/10: After using these for a while, I find that the adhesive isn't as strong as I'd like. Maybe it's the material I'm using to pack my sold items (i.e., cardboard boxes, bubble wrap, etc.), but sometimes some of the corners of the labels don't always stick. It's not a recurring issue, but it does become bothersome when it happens, and I resort to the old method of sticking labels: Scotch tape.

title: Satisfied but not totally as there are issues.
text:
I've never used chalkboard labels or pens before, so part of my issues might be due to my own lack of experience. I bought these to label a new set of kitchen containers, etc.
My first issue was that I couldn't get the pen to write. I was shaking it and pressing hard to get it started. It finally came out in a sort of white ink explosion. I tried to wipe off the label, but it really doesn't come off all the way, rather leaving a sort of haze. After this first initial bumpy start, it seemed to write well; however, the writing tip is thick, not intended for a very fine line or small space use.
I do like the labels: there are a lot of them in nice large sizes. I did find, however, that contrary to what was stated, they are not so easy to peel up/off and straighten out. I did finally manage to do so, but they do stick pretty tightly, which I suppose, can be seen as a positive as well. My use was on plastic containers. My attempt to remove and adjust was right after initial placement. I'm wondering if trying to peel these off after a few months or years is even possible. I really don't know. In any case, satisfied with these, but not thrilled. Not having ever used other brands of these, I can't really compare the quality.

title: Good ATA
text: The only ATA to support Google Voice that I know of. This is important since I made a Google Voice account my home phone. I have never been able to customize the rules within the ATA (such as using Line 3 to make 411 calls, or dail a number when 311 is dialed). My only regret is buying the 200 series instead of the 202.

title: Product OK. Support - Horrible
text:
I bought this product because ObiHai offered Google Voice integration. While I did manage to set up Google Voice integration easily enough, more advanced features were sent to email, which the only real response from ObiHai's Technical Support was go to the forums. Therefore, if the problem isn't resolved there, it's a big F*** You.

With Google Voice killing XMPP support in May, this ATA will basically become a very light brick. Simply put, I can just get an inactive smart phone to function as a SIP phone, or get an actual SIP phone. However, if the support options of a product I purchased is not going to be worthwhile, there is no point in wasting my money on it.

title: Great, but could be better
text:
The phone is good for the most part, and works nicely. It would sometimes have problems if the other end is not a good connection, and the ear piece sound could be louder.

The phone's software sometimes mysteriously goes inactive, and has to be restarted, but considering this is one of the few phones that works directly with Yahoo Messenger, it maybe an only choice if you are not interested in the competitor.

I also would have expected to customize it better with phone's software, as most phones with a USB port could sync address books, and a number of other things. This only gives you a means to align with Yahoo Messenger. Also with Yahoo Voice Messaging, it is impossible to listen to voice messages without changing the speaker to your PC, restart, and change back to the USB, and restart.

Also, there was one reviewer on here who said that there was no shortcut for the directory —that you had to scroll through the whole list; well that was wrong! If you pull up the directory, then enter the first letter of whoever you’re calling it comes up, so then just press the call button—easy peasy. The rest I’ll figure out as I go along, but suffice to say I like my new phones.

Update—
I’ve had these a month now, and no longer endure the VERY poor sound quality, so I’m using my old phones until I can get some others. Unfortunately, I’ve been sick with the flu, so I missed the return date, and they’ll probably get stored in the garage

title: Nice product for the price
text: I don't really print all that much, so I haven't really "put it through its paces", but can say it was very easy to set up.  I still haven't really got the fax part set up.  The instructions indicate there could be confilcts between the fax function and voice mail, which turned out to be true in my case, and I still haven't wanted to get back to it.  Every all in one I've ever had (HP, Canon Pixma)was a hassle to get phones, faxes and voice mail all on the same page.  My only disappointment was with the cordless telephone that comes with the machine.  I had hoped that having it's own phone might eliminate that problem, but it didn't.  I then ordered two more handsets, thinking the mix of the Brother machine and older Panasonic phones might be the problem.  I never got around to fine-tuning the fax vs. voice mail with the new handsets because they are pretty cheesy and I just didn't like them.  For example, the display is tiny, does not let you know when you've missed a call, and most annoying, you have to do phonebook entries separately on each handset.  That got real old real fast, so I returned the Brother handsets and went back to my old phones.  The other features of the machine, such as the touchscreen menu screen, ease of wireless network set up, Bluetooth, and ease of use, accessibility of the print cartridges et. outweigh that one issue, and I would buy it again.

title: Many coins don't have a good fit
text:
Sadly, I find many coins around 38mm don't have an adequate fit (seller doesn't list 38mm as a foam ring size). Thus leaving you to stretch one size down or floating the coin in the next size up. Both methods result in a coin that moves around inside the capsule. In the picture, I was able to cut an out foam ring in half to keep the coin stationary despite it not looking great. Also, the capsules are a bit loose in closure fit. They slide close, not snap or click closed.

If you want secure plastic encasement protection, look elsewhere. Not sure this set is best for precious metal collections. Just thought for the price this might be better quality. Don't pay more than $20. My $30 was too much. Should return, but I hate the hassle. Will find a use some how. The black outer case is pretty decent. It's the capsules and foam inserts that are the letdown.

title: Ink Is Very Light and PrevaGuard Confuses Me...
text:
I'm a bit disappointed with BIC's PrevaGuard Round 1.0 medium point size pen. The 1.0 size doesn't bother me at all. But the blue ink is light...very light. It reminds me of a pen that is running out of ink and getting lighter and lighter.

PrevaGuard is described as follows, per the info above: "Contains an agent incorporated into the plastic that protects the pen itself by suppressing the growth of bacteria, algae, fungus and mildew."

It then goes on to say:

"These products protect the pens themselves and do not protect users or others from disease causing bacteria, viruses or germs"

I'm not quite understanding this. Prevaguard protects the pen but not people? Why would the pens need protection? Are they saying PrevaGuard protects the pen AND people from bacteria, algae, mildew and fungus but does NOT protect people from disease causing bacteria, viruses and germs??? Maybe its just me but PrevaGuard has me confused.

On a good note, the pens are comfortable to hold. And they outlast the Papermate Ink Joy pen by 90%. The price of a box of Bic's PrevaGuards (12 pens per box) is pretty low, especially for being BIC, outlasting Papermate and the protection from the PrevaGuard agent.

title: Good Pen...(PrevaGuard protects the PEN from germs, NOT People)
text: After reading that BIC prevaguard pens contain an antimicrobial agent molded directly into the pen to help suppress the growth of mold, mildew, bacteria and fungi, I  took it  to mean it helped keep the pen free of germs as a safety measure for people.  Only after  I re-read the info again a number of times did I realize the antimicrobial agent is to protect the PEN, not people.  The protection given by the antimicrobial agent keeps mold, mildew, bacteria and fungi out of the pen while at the same time, keeping the pen fresh, odor free, staining and pen degradation.  The agent lasts for the life of the pen  unless the plastic portion is destroyed/broken.  The box contains 12 pens total and all 12 are 1.0mm medium point which allows the pen to writing smooth and easy. The pen is comfortable to hold and write with and its very thin. (Personally, I'd prefer the pens to be a bit thicker in width, but that's just me) These are clic pens and the clicker works well to open /close the pen. I received blue pens but black is available as well.  The price is reasonable. BIC is known for quality items. Its pretty innovative that they created an agent to prevent the pen from going bad and lasting a long time.  These pens are perfect for pretty much anyone who uses pens.  All in all, a good quality pen and I do recommend it.

title: Awful. No Color Variety, Only Rec'd 7 Pens

I used each of the 7 pens to write my name. Only  2 of the 7 wrote well.  The other 5 look like I used red crayon to write my name.  Two of the clickers on the pens broke as soon as they were pressed down on lightly.  I own a lot of AmazonBasics and Solimo (an Amazon brand) items and have NEVER had an issue with any of them. I don't know if I just got a bad batch of pens but these pens are terrible.

title: Not Perfect but Functional If...
text: Where to start?  I use only brown paper for all my gift wrapping and shipping needs.  I’m always looking to simplify and use space wisely, so putting a dispenser on the wall was a no brainer.  Well, they’re not easy to come by and can be really expensive.  This one is less expensive than average and is sort of “mid weight” as sturdiness goes.  Oddly, there is no way to install it with the paper dispensing “downward” as one expects.  Literally, the paper roll and dowel just fall out.  My husband is a mechanic and COULD NOT make it work in a “right side up” position on the wall.  When flipped such that paper is dispensed “upward,” it works fine.  That said, the cutting edge is a bit on the thick side, for safety I guess, and cuts are inconsistent.  How we made it work:  Have good quality paper!  Light weight paper tears everywhere BUT on the cutting edge.  Mid-heavy weight paper works much better.  Dispense at least 3 feet at a time:  less and it’s likely to tear mid pull.  Upside down, good paper, 3 feet or more and you’ve got yourself a perfect cutter!  (I just didn’t feel like sending it back 🙄)

title: Must have for busy people
text:
I got this so my husband and I can plan our meals for the week. We get so focused on our projects that we will (and have) forget to eat and when the hunger finally hits us it's 10pm. We have alarms on our phones to remind us to start thinking about dinner at 6:30p every day, but then the game of "what's for dinner" begins. This awesome product helps us figure that out ahead of time.

The entire board is magnetic which means it latched onto our fridge and didn't want to let go. It was a little crooked at first and I had to peel it completely off in order to realign it. The board comes with four pens (red, green, blue and black) and the pens have two awesome features: they have dry erasers on their lids - which makes changing the board a breeze; and they are magnetic - this keeps them close at hand and not stuck in a drawer.

The package also includes a larger dry eraser, which is surprisingly magnetic as well. I didn't realize it at first because it wouldn't stick to the fridge but it does stick a little bit.. however, its magnet is not very strong so I'm not sure how well it will stay up when the door is opened and closed.

There are also four smaller decorative magnets included. The images on mine are a sunset, a castle, a dandelion and some odd ensemble of cartoon caricatures.. no clue what or who they are supposed to be. I'll be giving that magnet to one of my grand kids. Perhaps they'll be familiar with the picture.

The only negative is that, despite being shipped in a flat package (very nice touch, by the way), the upper left corner of my board is creased. The magnetic grasp of the board does not seem to be affected (it is not curled up away from the fridge or anything) but it is slightly annoying as it reduces the overall aesthetics of the board.

Overall, I am SO happy with this! My husband and I just finished filling it out for next week. The pens write on it really well and they don't run. If anything the tips are a little thick for the space provided. Let me just tell you now.. you will not be able to write as small and clear as the images included in the listing, at least not with the pens included. I used the blank spaces on the bottom of the board for planned appointments and my upcoming trips (I am a school bus driver and in addition to my regular route every morning and afternoon, I take our various teams to their away games) so my husband is aware of when I won't be home. I highly recommend this set for planning your meals and as a reminder board for everyone else in your house. For everything included, the price is very fair!

title: Colorful
text: These MJIYA Binder Clips Colorful Paper Clamps for Office Supplies (Mixed Color, 1 inch (48pcs)) are good. I got the 1 inch size that came as a pack of 48 clips and they are just what I needed to organize all the paperwork as the secretary of my HOA. The colors are on the pastel side and the clip strength seems to be holding up well for what I've been using them for.

title: Very sturdy and well built stand
text: I got this Acrylic Tilted Computer Keyboard Stand for my wireless desktop keyboard. My new keyboard doesn't have any tilt adjustment and was sitting too flat on my desktop. This stand arrived and is certainly well built and solid.. it doesn't skid across my slick desktop. It is a dust magnet though, and being black you will see every piece of lint and dust molecule it attracts so if you're a neat freak, like me, just beware (this is the reason for my one star reduction). The only thing I don't like about this setup is the stand is solid and doesn't have any tilt adjustments. I knew it wouldn't but I'm finding that I personally need a least a little leeway so I can find my personal sweet spot. I didn't reduce my rating because of this mainly because it isn't a flaw in the product's design.. just personal preference, but I thought I'd mention it.

title: Decent set of punches
text: I got these mini punches to use with my Color Street nail strips. I received 10 different shapes and they are easy to use. The sizes are just a little larger than I expected. They punch through a nail strip and one sheet of paper well.

title: Great for at home filing needs
text: I use this file folder to organize all of my small business receipts to make tax time easier. The folder is sturdy, not flimsy at all, can stand on its own and the closing elastic loop is loose enough to reach around the entire folder but right enough to hold it shut. I haven't had it long so I can't comment on its longevity, but I can say that I don't expect the elastic loop to last long if you're opening and closing it very often. I access it about 1-2 times a week so for my purposes it seems t be holding up for now.

title: A little flimsy
text:
I got this folder to organize my receipts throughout the year for tax purposes. The labels are nice and seem to be adhering fine so far and the outer case is sturdy enough to stand on its own. The cable tie closure works well, though the loop could have been made a smidge but longer to make closing it a little easier.. but this isn't a deal breaker. The inner dividers are very colorful but extremely flimsy. I fear tearing them every time I insert a new receipt.. they're that thin.

Bottom line... The folder is sturdy overall but has flimsy dividers that I'm not sure how long they will last. The included labels are a nice bonus and have good adhesive.

title: These'll Do, Donkey!
text:
I am a direct sales consultant and mail out an average 4-10 packages per week, so I tend to go through a stack of padded envelopes pretty quick. I grabbed these for a number of reasons.. the price, the color (I love attention grabbing, eye-popping colors!) and the size. They arrived in short order and are exactly what I expected. The size is accurately noted in the description (a huge bonus) and the color is just as vibrant as it appeared on the screen. They also have a smidge of stretch which I discovered when prepping a customer's shipment in one of these envelopes today. I do wish they were a tad thicker (you can nearly see through them when held to light) but that is not a deal breaker for me. The price is the best. Currently sold for $8.95 per 25 pack... that works out to $0.36/each. A steal when compared to big box stores.

Bottom line... They are correctly represented in the description, the color is on par with the pictures online and one would be hard pressed to beat the cost. I will not hesitate to replenish my supply as needed!

Husband also likes the included clips as he prefers to keep a pen in his shirt pocket for work. All in all, good pens and reasonably priced for the pair.

title: Good, basic shredder
text: I purchased this unit for an area where I want to shred some mail, envelopes, etc.  It does a fine job with these items.  There is a space in the top (you can see it on the back right side of the illustration) that lets you know how full the bucket is.  It does not do a very good job on credit cards - the first one I tried did not cut through the whole card - I finished it with a scissors.  The strips fill the bucket much quicker that a crosscut shredder - this is not a fault of the shredder, but something to consider if you have a lot of shredding to do.  I have Amazon's crosscut shredder in my office and use that for papers I need destroyed like those blank checks credit card companies send, old financial records, etc.  That one does an excellent job on credit cards and CDs and, the fine cuts enable you to get a lot of shredded paper into the bucket.
