title: Replacement ordered
text:
I ordered this shredder and have requested a replacement due to a slight problem with the basket. It does not align perfectly inside the case.

I have owned several Amazon shredders and like them very much. Unfortunately, my puppy chewed off the cord of my old shredder, so I needed to buy a new shredder.

When this item arrived, I noticed that it was hard to keep the basket inside the casing of the shredder. It was possible but just not as well made as the shredder that I was replacing, which was, I think, about three years old.

I like to use a basket because the mechanism of the shredder is fused inside the lid, so it is heavy and awkward to lift the lid to empty the shredder.

I could have kept the shredder and just taped the basket because the problem was not severe. However, I felt that a new item should be in mint condition at the time of purchase.

title: Flimsy
text: These are not sturdy as advertised here on the webpage.  They are about the weight of a manila folder.  When expanded, the left side -- where the stapled corners of the inserted papers cause a slight bulge --  begins to come apart.

title: Useful notebook but unattractive cover design
text: If the appearance of your office products matters to you, you may be disappointed, as I was, by the design of the covers of these notebooks.  The company, Mead, chose to print a white advertising banner, almost as big as an index card, on the front cover.

title: Don’t stick
text: Great size but they won’t adhere to file folders

title: Cute but TERRIBLE SOUND
text:
The card is adorable but the sound quality is absolutely AWFUL! I've purchased 3 of this design in the past month and they are all bad.

The words from the singing cats is indecipherable - not Hallmark's usual quality. Don't waste your money on this design.

title: Beware - not ALL are cat images
text:
My fault in not thoroughly examining the images before buying. As a devoted CAT parent, I wanted feline-themed Christmas cards but out of this set of 25 cards, only FIFTEEN are cats. One set (5 cards) is of a kitten with a much larger puppy (makes it seem dog-ish) and that image is middle left. The other set of 5 cards appear to be puppies sleeping (bottom left image) -- might be wrong but they surely don't resemble cats ! The reasonable price is diminished by the fact they're not all "cat" themed Christmas cards.

Cards are cute but if you're looking for a set of 100% cats/kittens, this is NOT the holiday card set to buy.

title: PIECE OF JUNK I TOSSED IT OUT IT WASN'T EVEN WORTH THE TROUBLE TO SEND IT BACK
text: EVEN WITH BATTERY PROPERLY INSTALLED THIS CALCULATOR NEVER WORKED.

title: Wish I Liked This More
text:
It just comes across as cheap across the board. Even the gift pen had broken and sharp mirror pieces glued to it. Some of the beading fell off as soon as I used it. It wrote horribly and scratchy.
The journal itself initially appeared to be okay but you can see how the leather was just stamped over and over than then cut out, poorly. Edges are rough, undyed and not finished. The interior isn't well dyed and is rough like poorly produced suede. The strap is the same poor material.
The paper is thick and rough which would be nice if it had a quality feel but it seems like poorly homemade paper badly bound in the cover.
Just not great but could be useful as a D&D journal or even a diary if you're not picky.

title: Loud, Annoying
text: I first tried installing this in my bathroom using the sticky pad adhering the stop to the tile floor and it's metal on metal. You can hear it 15 feet away in my bedroom clacking and clunking as it latches and unlatches. The magnet is pretty strong and after about a week, maybe ten days the adhesive pad started to fail and eventually the post came free leaving the adhesive disk stuck to the floor. That took some scraping to get off the tile completely. I considered putting this in bedroom with the screws and decided I just didn't want to deal with the noise. In a game room, cellar or professional situation this might be okay. I don't recommend the glue pad or using this in an area where you'd want peace and quiet.

title: Requires Strength to Use
text: We're mostly homebound due to disability so coloring is a frequent pastime for us. We go through and sharpen a lot of colored pencils. My initial impression was okay. Decent amount of space for shavings to collect. Good weight and size. But then we tried to use them. First and foremost you have to hold the pencil still while the sharpener works. For a battery operated device these things have a lot of torque! I had trouble holding the pencil still it was impossible for my elderly mother. They put good points on the pencils we tested it with, several brands of colored and a couple standard #2 pencils, but the sharpener never stops. I got distracted once and easily drove a brand new pencil to three quarters of its length in no time. I guess they're okay. If your able enough to use them. I struggled and my mom found it impossible. We'll stick with our older, corded, sharpener that's fully automatic. These were a disappointment.

title: How Do You Get a Pencil SO Wrong?!
text:
Pencils. . . Around 450 years in existence and Bic somehow gets it horribly wrong. How? I like different looking pencils. Standby yellow school pencils are fine but different is. . . fun. I game, D&D, Car Wars, etc. pencils are part and parcel of gaming life. I think it was during first or second grade when I first heard "Take out a #2 pencil." before some test. So, at fifty three years old I know pencils. I saw these with their dark grey barrel and black inner wood and they looked cool. Something fun to break out at the next game night. Then I got them. They're comfortable enough. The barrel actually flexes a little like there's rubber in the mix. They are neat looking and that's where it ends. Again, I've written with a #2 for easily forty five years. I know what a #2 pencil feels like when I write with one. These write nothing like a #2 pencil. It feels. . . waxy, the tip doesn't grip the paper, it slips along. It feels totally wrong. I know what writing from a #2 pencil looks like. What comes out of these pencils (I almost want to put pencil i quotes here) looks, and feels like trying to write on slippery thermal receipt paper. I was using an old Composition notebook that I've had for years. I could barely make out what I wrote no matter how hard I pressed. The words looked waxy or greasy. The writing was faint looking decades old and faded or like what a much harder pencil (#5 - #6) produces, except for that waxy, greasy feel when writing.
TL:DR? These are terrible pencils. I wouldn't recommend them to anyone.

title: Mediocrity
text: I've bought 24 pound paper for my printers for years. I like the weight and feel. This, feels like at best 20 or 18 pound copier paper. It's not worth the trouble and effort of returning so I'll deal with it. Paper is slippery and thin, I didn't expect rag or linen but I had about 30 sheets left from my last ream which was a different manufacturer's 24 pound 96 extra bright paper and it's got a little textural feel, it's stiffer, by a great deal, than this paper from HP. When I buy a brand name I expect quality not paper that lags behind some no-name brand. The other brand had jumped nearly 75% since my last purchase. Had I known how mediocre this HP product was I might have splurged and repurchased it. I won't buy this again.

title: I Wasn't Impressed
text:
I'm not impressed. I really like the Ink Joy pens and how they write but if this is a medium point you could likely do surgery with the fine point version. This write a sharp, hard and thin line unlike any medium point pen and very unlike a typical Ink Joy pen. This unlike most Ink Joy pens had a removable, and easily misplaced or lost cap on the writing end and a large, soft stylus on the other end. Yes, you can cover the stylus with the cap as you write but if you need the stylus for anything it's covered. I think the design is poor. Some means of clicking the pen tip in an out could easily have been designed.
The stylus itself it rather large and I found somewhat clumsy to use on our 7" Fire, my 10" Samsung and my touch-screen laptop. As my mother said, "other than the fingerprints it's no better than using your hand." Plus there's the time needed to find and use the stylus while your hand is right there. Not a great idea.

title: Pretty Colors, Some Problems, Best For Kids And Teens
text: Not super impressed. The colors honestly are very pretty when you're careful and lay them down evenly which isn't as easy as it sounds. You have to be soft, slow and gentle to get large areas covered smoothly, cleanly and completely. They do go down nice if you take care but we found some of the pens were scratchy when coloring with them. Another problem we had, because the pens aren't marked and even though there's Basic, Pastel, Neon, Neon Glitter, Metallic and Colored Glitter. They all seem the same. The 'glitter' pens don't write/color in glitter the glitter as far as I can tell (the glittering being in the barrel of the pen far away from the ink was a big clue) glitter is just decorative part of the pen and not part of the ink. Trying multiple pens from different racks it was really hard to tell there was any real difference in the colors as far as metallic or neon and basic go. I had an easier time than my elderly mother coloring smoothly and with complete coverage but I still think a good set of colored pencils is far better to color with than ball-point pens. I think kids and teens would have more fun than adults with these.

title: Decent Set of Pencils
text:
Personally I prefer round pencils. Standard design 6-sided hextuple pencils tend to dig painfully into my hand and fingers. Granted they don't roll away as easily as round pencils do but I'd still take round over angles any day. My other problem with this set is there's no color guide included or available (confirmed by the seller) with the pencils or any color names on the pencils. The manufacturer's name and a number are embossed on each pencil but nothing to tell you what the color is. My 85 year old mother has a serious problem with the lack of color names or a color chart that corresponds to their numbering system.
That all being said, these do color very nicely and smoothly and you can put down a light color or darken it easily with just a bit more pressure. The tin they come in is two layers, 24 different colors per level and you can put the 1st layer in the lid while working to keep everything in one place. It's a good set of pencils just not a great set. A color chart with color names or having the name of the color on the pencil would easily bring this up to a four star review.
I received this item in exchange for my review.

title: Looks Great, Writes Poorly
text:
The pen itself is beautiful. The blue and chrome are stunning together. This comes with a felt sheath to store the pen in which is a little hard to get the pen into or out of as the clip is very tight. It does fit a shirt pocket, without the felt sheath, nicely even with a pocket protector. The pen has a nice heft, feels very well made and solid. . . and then you get to the bad part. When writing, and it's not just me I've handed this to two other people without a word and asked for their opinion and both of them said the same thing. The roller-ball grabs, scratches and stutters as you write which is too bad because it lays down a nice wet and dark line of ink that dries not quickly but doesn't stay wet all that long. But no matter how attractive a pen is when all is said and done a pen is something you use to write. If all you use it for is signing your name maybe you won't notice but I wrote an entire page as did a friend of mine and the way the pen writes is so distracting neither of us could enjoy using the pen. I even spent ten minutes scribbling constantly with the pen thinking maybe the roller-ball needed to 'break in' but it still did the same hitching, catching and stuttering. A pen that doesn't write well just isn't something to rave about. I was somewhat disappointed in this product.
I received this pen in exchange for my review.

title: They're Nice. . . But
text:
First off I'm just going to say this; I don't mind being asked to review a product and enjoy it at times. What I dislike quite a lot is receiving several notes in the packaging specifically encouraging I write a five star review of the product. On to the product. . .

The labels are a heavy gauge vinyl and stick well to dry surfaces. Removal and reuse was okay, I was able to get about three uses before the edges would stop adhering. The marker design is interesting. You can flip the tip, easily but a bit messily, from a round point to a chisel tip. The liquid chalk writes quite wet and takes a while to dry. Once dry you need to be careful how you handle the labels. Moderate pressure causes the chalk to halo and spread out. The slightest dampness, such as the humid environment in a 'fridge or damp fingers, will cause the chalk to badly smear. Oddly enough I found it almost impossible to completely remove the chalk from a label even using glass cleaner there was a white haze left behind.

Maybe with a more permanent white marker things would be better. I'd rather not be able to reuse the labels for less risk of smearing. The labels are attractive in an old timey way. I'd gladly buy more than mess around with trying to erase and reuse them.

I received this item in exchange for my review.

title: So So Quality Pen
text: These may write in any climate or condition as they claim but they're scratchy and jumpy when writing with them. They also appear larger on the site than they are in person. These are rather thin and we prefer a somewhat thicker pen as well as a smoother writing instrument.  Not worth returning. Guess we'll keep them around.

title: Mediocre Laser Printer from Canon.
text:
The imageCLASS MF8280cw printer is definitely not your average home printer. Unfortunately because the cassette holding only 150 sheets of paper it's not really much of a business printer either.

Make sure you have a friend around to help you move and set up this printer. You're also going to need a sturdy place to put it. At almost 60 pounds and measuring 17" x 19" it's quite a beast and will take up quite a bit of table/desk top real estate.

Print speed, advertized at 14 ppm, is good but not all that fast. Print quality of text is, as are most laser printers, exceptional. Print quality of images on the other hand is poor. I've tried numerous color profiles and settings on board the printer but I haven't been able to achieve color matching that I would even call fair let alone good. Even printing simple pie charts with specific colors (red, green, blue, etc.) set by their decimal numbers the color output was off. Blues are too dark. Yellows are orangeish. Grey areas are blue tinted. I spent an hour or so and used up close to 50 prints trying to get good color output but the best I could get out of the printer was mediocre.

Scan speed is amazingly fast but scan quality of images is only good. Text scanning quality is very good. The highest resolution setting for scanning is 600 DPI which isn't that impressive. It's good for documents and not much else. The biggest annoyance with scanning was every time I wanted to scan something I would have to stop what I was doing, wake the printer up from standby mode, switch to the scan mode and then change the device setting to 'remote scanner' even though the printer is connected to my PC via a USB cable. I found this to be annoying.

Copying is quite fast and accurate. I scanned several invoices and documents and all were square and true with good quality.

I only used the fax feature once but it worked quite well and reasonably quickly.

The ADF tray hold 50 sheets and does a good job of feeding paper. You don't have to sit there and nudge items to get the rollers to grab them.

Wireless setup seems easy and painless although neither of my tablets will see the printer and my PC lacks a wireless card. The printer pulls an IP address from my wireless router but that's as far as I was able to get with testing the wireless capability.

In conclusion... this printer is too large for most home offices and the limited paper capacity makes it cumbersome for all but the smallest of businesses. Currently a replacement set of four toner cartridges for this printer will cost you well over three hundred dollars and with an average of only 1,450 pages per set of cartridges this is rather expensive to run. There are better options out there.

title: Cheap, Mediocre Quality Paper
text: Yes, it's bright white paper and yes, it appears to be 24lb paper but it's also... cheap feeling. I know it's not cotton rag but for over twelve bucks (what I paid in July 2012) a ream I expected something with a little better quality. I don't print much so this ream will probably last the lifetime of my new [[ASIN:B005A09UCY Canon MF3010 Laser Printer]] and beyond. I don't like buying products and then saying "It'll do." but... It'll do. I'm not impressed with this paper and won't buy the brand again.

title: Good Markers But...
text:
We've enjoyed using these markers to color with and decorate/embellish some felt snowmen and snowflakes around the house. They color well with good ink flow. They make a much finer line than your average generic felt-tip markers and the ink dries insanely fast. I've found that even Sharpie brand permanent markers can take a while to dry when labeling DVDs and CDs but the ink from these Bic markers dries almost the instant you write. No more smeared DVD labels!

On the downside; the colors on the barrels of these markers don't really correspond to the colors of their ink. It's more of a suggestion or a hint of the color you'll get when you write or color. They tend to be much darker than the displayed color. Using a test pad is a must until you get familiar with them. Also several of the blues and greens are very similar to each other giving less diversity than it appears. Like all markers they will bleed through all but the heaviest paper.

All in all these are a decent set of markers that could have been better.

title: Cheap, Thin & Flimsy
text:
The title of this review really says it all. This notebook is cheaply made; the pages, cover and back are thin and flimsy...

The pages are so thin that even with a light hand and a smooth gel pen I can easily read what's written on the back from the front of the page and vice versa. For some unknown reason the micro-perforations are nearly a half inch from the spiral/wire binding which seriously cuts into the usable portion of the page. There are page number and date heading box on each page which are particularly useless.

The front cover, while a mildly attractive burgundy marble design is incredibly thin and cheap. The pocket on the back is poorly glued in place. I don't expect either to last very long. The back cover is very poorly made cardboard somewhat thicker than the front but even cheaper in quality. It has almost no rigidity and is easily bent.

I only paid a few dollars for this otherwise I'd be returning it. I'll use it but I'm not at all happy with the quality and will never buy this again.

I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.

title: Moleskine Passions Recipe Journal
text:
The Moleskine Passions Recipe Journal is a well made diary sized (5"x8¼") notebook printed on medium/light weight acid free paper with 240 total pages. It contains sections for most typical areas of cooking; Appetizers, First Course, Main Dishes, Deserts, etc. plus several unlabeled sections for the owner to personalize. In addition there are weight, measure and temperature conversion charts, produce and fruit harvest/ripeness charts, food information charts and sections for notes, event or party planning. The cover is cleverly embossed with kitchen utensils and includes an elastic strap to keep the journal securely closed. Also included are three handy attached bookmarks and an expandable pocket in the back which contains the two sheets of stickers (for personalization) that come with the journal.

The pages for recording your recipes have limited space for writing, you'll need write carefully and small to fit most recipes on a page. The pages are not removable and pages cannot be added or moved around. The print in the book (charts, tables, etc.) is nearly microscopic. I found it very hard to read anything in the journal. As well the current and recent prices listed here on Amazon make this a very expensive and hard to justify choice.

title: A little expensive for the quality...
text:
The front cover is a durable plastic but it is easily creased by sharp bending. The red, which I received to review, was subdued and attractive. The back cover includes Five Star's new Hook N' Go feature which allows you to fold out tabs and attach your notebook to a three-ring binder. This feature also allows you to use both sides of the notebook easily while it is in the binder. Unfortunately the back cover is only thick waxy cardboard and I can't see the Hook N' Go tabs lasting all that long before tearing or ripping.
The notebook includes two handy heavy manilla pockets at the front.
The college ruled pages are perforated allowing clean removal of each sheet from the notebook but you need to be careful as it's easier to rip the pages from the wire than at the perforations. The paper itself is rather thin and flimsy. I write with a moderately heavy hand and I could see the impression of what I'd written fully four sheets down. Also I recommend against using any type of marker as bleed through happened quite easily.

title: It’s ok pretty

title: Misrepresent size

title: Love this pencil, but the build quality disappoints
text:
Pentel has always previously delivered in quality since I've started using them 30+ years ago. I've had two of out of three of these Graphgear pencils break on me within the first year of usage: one at the plastic join near the middle of the barrel and the other at the tip. I really love the design, feel, and performance of this pencil....WHEN IT DOESN'T BREAK. Out of the probably 3-4 dozen Pentels I've owned over the years, these are the first to ever break.

I really want to love this pencil, but the quality disappoints.

title: Junk AT&T has given up
text: ATT always had great telephones. I still have a 530 that works fine. Perhaps outsourcing (to the Philippines), or all the money spent on athletic advertising has taken away from any monies better spent on continuing the tradition of making great telephones. I got a 210 because I needed a basic telephone that was inexpensive and would be dependable (an ATT). Instead I got garbage. One by one features would not work. I needed a longer cord so it went to a hardware store (where the owner use to work for Verizon) and he said the telephone was defective. The cord would not work. Radio Shack said the same thing. I called the service number and got the outsource who asked me to describe a couple of the issues. I was then told it was defective and to send it back. I also said I needed an extension cord and could I get one from them? They said anyone would work. I said I did not feel I should have to spend several dollars to send a $13 telephone back (received through Amazon free shipping and I should risk receiving another defective unit?). They said they could do nothing else. I asked for a supervisor and was given a complaint email address [...] to write to about it and instead of a written reply I get a telephone call and who do you think calls me? The same outsource office. They want me to contact them so they can work something out. I email them that they can certainly send me a prepaid label with a new and working telephone and I would return the defective one in the box the new one comes in. I had not heard from them in months so I called them before the warranty ran out to ask why did you have to speak with me and not respond to my emails. I was told we prefer to speak with our customers personally about their options. OK. What are they? I was told there were two: I could pack up the telephone and all its original contents to send back to them, or I could fill out a form received the next day authorizing a new telephone would be sent to me WITHOUT mailing in the defective one, IF I paid a pre charged $14.99 (the telephone was $12.99) fee. This allows (are they kidding?) me to continue using (I told them it was sitting in its box) the telephone until the replacement arrived. I asked she email me these `options' for my record and she did. Garbage telephone and sad to say, garbage customer support (games and ignoring the consumer does not make for good customer support, or goodwill). Keep spending money on advertising for product that isn't worth the marketing.

title: Not as described and won't fit -EDITED  False advertising!!
text: The ratings have to be false. I purchased from them because of the high ratings. My purchase was  for future use because I had run out before. The cartridges were advertised as replacements for my Canon MG5220 as shown in photo. What they sent don't fit!! They are an inch too long, not shaped to fit and the ink opening does not have a ridge.  I called E-Z Ink and talked to Michelle, She said they have never had this problem before. Look at the one star reviews and they tell you this has been a problem since 2017.  I read her the numbers on the cartridges as asked and she said they were correct.  She was asked me to send photos of the cartridges lined up mine because this is a new problem. I did email the photos I have attached here. I received an email from EZ-Ink. I was told " I " purchased the wrong cartridges and I would have to pay to send them back for a refund. Sure pay I will have to at least half  of the purchase price to send them back because they don't send replacements. They prosper and the customer loses. Any return date should not matter. They have been falsely advertising this product for years per one star reviews.  How many other people have been ripped off that haven't written a review? Buying from E-Z Ink is just giving your money to them. Don't buy because of the 5 star ratings read the true ratings with one star.

title: Never Buy This Scanner Because Of The Software!
text:
UPDATE 2
I spent tens of hours scanning photos. They were saved regularly, and the folders indicates that they were actually there. When I went to start organizing them tonight, they were gone, and WINDOWS cannot find a single one anywhere on mys system. The software was acting strange, and apparently it took out all the photos. That is a big chunk of my life that I will never get back.

Even tonight the sogtware refuses to consistently save test scans.

My original assessment was that this was a bad scanner because of the software, and I stand by it again. If you are scanning in more than a few photos, USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!

UPDATED REVIEW
I had extensive problems getting the scanner to operate and the software to install. I had to download the drivers to three different computers. I was never able to make it work with WIN 7 (old laptops I could place where the photos were) but did make it work with WIN 8 with tech support help. The Web site specifically states that the driver and software will work with WIN 7. Take it with a grain of salt.

Scanning was easy. I ran a calibration first and then scanned several hundred photos over about 8 hours. The results were good EXCEPT the white balance was way off on many photos. They looked sepia-toned.
Software was "not so good". First, they use a white on light blue interface color scheme. For a visually impaired person like myself, it might was well be white-on-white. Second, there seems to be no batch processing of photos. The white balance Quick Fix seemed to work wonders, but I was not going to do each scan individually. My corrections were done in Photoshop instead where I could run a batch process on all the photos.

Positives were that the hardware and software were able to rotate the scanned images to eliminate any feeding errors over 99% of the time. Scans at 600 dpi were fast and consistent. Having the scans start automatically when the photo was dropped into the scanner was a huge plus for this job. While some rotation did occur, there were only three misfeeds that required a rescan because the photo stuck in the scanner feeder.

Negatives for the setup issues and the white balance, but positives for ease of use, consistency, and speed. I will end up saving hundreds of dollars scanning the photos myself instead of using a service bureau.

The first mat cracked after less than 5months. The cheap mat I replaced lasted give times longer. Looks like durability is a lot less than advertised. Better off looking elsewhere IMO.

I am heavy at 245 lbs/112 kg, so it could be more me than it, but I saw compression of the cushion starting about two weeks into using it.  It did largely help with problems with the back of my thighs, but now even that relief is getting less as I compress the cushion.

title: Disappointing unit
text:
This is a very substandard unit for converting slides, in my opinion.

The problems start with the slide tray. It is vertical, so that slides tend to fall. It also is difficult to center and keep centered the slides so that portions are not cut off.

My bigger problem is poor color rendition. I have some very good, colorful slides that have been kept in archival quality holders that are still as pristine as the day that they were developed. The colors in the scans are washed out and can approach black-and-white.

Finally, I have far more noise in the scans than there should be. The unit uses a Zoran camera and a lamp to shoot a picture od the slide. This is about as controlled an shooting environment as you can get. There should be NO noise.

title: Wall Calendar won't hang straight
text:
I am disappointed. I searched and searched to find a wall calendar that was 11 x 8.5 that would hang on the wall, the pages would flip over - not needing to be torn off, that displayed the previous month and upcoming month on the page with the current month. This calendar seemed to fit the bill but was for 16 months (Sept 2012 through Dec 2013). So, I tore off the Sept 2012 through Dec 2012 pages and threw them out, put the calendar in the drawer until today ... Dec 31, 2012. I have worked and worked trying to get this calendar to hang straight on the wall. I've put in new nails, hangers, etc. Then, I finally figured it out. The three holes punched on the (top) 11" side of the calendar are "off-center". This bloody thing tilts to the left and I can't fix it. I can't tape it to the wall because it is taken down regularly to coordinate calendars. I went in to return it to the vendor and was informed that it was past them return date. So ... I scanned all of the wall calendars again - and have ordered a different calendar. The one ordered fortunately had a review from a great customer saying, "I especially like the plastic hanging hook (it is not visible in the display photo) that provides hanging of the calendar." I made my decision based on that review. I don't know if this vendor knows they are selling defective merchandise.

Update: January, 2013. I called Amazon Customer Service in person re: this calendar and they issued a complete refund. I tossed the calendar. Thank you Amazon.

text: Just got this chair yesterday.  Thought, okay, other people are being whiners about the assembly. Not so. I ended up getting our own longer bolts to put the back on with so that I don't have to worry about my kid falling out when the back breaks off.  I had only one part where I was able to get the bolts in without sheer misery, the bottom step of the stool.  Good thing they give you extra bolts - because you end up stripping off half of them.  And I still used several of my own.  I do not mind the stools sliding out rather than the hidge on the old models as I also remember getting pinched on the old ones and how heavy they were.  So, that will not be my complaint.  But, the assembly is too painful to make this thing worth it.  I still have bolts falling off that I just can't get in.  The top step of the stool has one (I think the threads where I am bolting it into are all wrong) and the plastic side rails are IMPOSSIBLE as they are just not quite wide enough for where they are supposed to go, so the bolts are at an angle.  Yes - I even used one of my husbands super clamps to try to get them on by squeezing the legs together.  It took 3 hours of MISERY and like I said, I have a stool, it's still not all assembled.  And, yes, I do know how to assemble products and use a screw driver.

title: Ooma - poor CS and won't let you take your original number with you.
text:
I was a bit hesitant to buy my Ooma due to the cost yet after a co-worker raved about it I did it. I bought my Ooma Telo box from Costco.com- they ran a special whereas you not only got the Ooma box but also the Bluetooth wireless adapter. I saw a few Ooma boxes on sale at my local Meijer store for $139- a steal (of course, no Bluetooth adapter included)!

I've been an Ooma user since June 2011 and have nothing but praise for it! After only 4 days of using it (with the new number Ooma gave me- I now have a second number on the same line- woo hoo!) I decided to get the Premier service- for $119 annually I was able to transfer my old Vonage number (normally cost $39 to transfer a number) and receive invaluable services.

My favorite? The ability to block ANY number. Yes, including those annoying robocalls from political organizations that are exempt from the Do Not Call laws (which includes all charities- if I know I am not going to donate then I love knowing I can prevent them from contacting me). With the upcoming presidential election I was able to block every last robocall- no more hearing from those annoying special interest groups!

The second number is unlisted and gives me more security. I am single and when I give out that second number if it doesn't work out with someone (who will not stop calling) I can simply stop the calls by putting their number on my personal blacklist- another Ooma Premier feature.

Call quality is pretty good- I would rate it better than a Verizon cell phone call (Verizon's call quality is pretty good IMHO). Because this is an internet based phone service (VOIP) I sometimes find if I am surfing the web and talking on the phone the call quality can deteriorate so I now use the service without using my computer too. it is a small sacrifice to pay for such a cheap and awesome service.

Even by buying the Premier service my monthly cost for unlimited calling to the US and Canada is less than $15/month. I haven't found ANY other service which offers so much at a lower cost. If you don't buy the Premier service your only cost after buying the equipment is monthly taxes- currently it is around $4.50 for me.

There is also an app that costs $10 that allows Ooma Premier subscribers to use 450 minutes of talk time on either Wifi or 3G monthly- I have not tried this out due to overwhelmingly negative reviews of the app on the Android app store. Once I see more positive reviews I will get it- this will save me even more on my cell minutes.

I highly recommend Ooma- GREAT service!

UPDATE: June 4th, 2018... Ooma apparently will do everything in their power to prevent you from leaving them and porting your phone number elsewhere. I've tried 10 times to port my original AT&T number from Ooma to a TMobile account... No dice. Ooma will not give out any info to help and everything I've read on the web hasn't worked. Be careful using Ooma.

title: You get what you pay for . . .
text: Recently ended up with several thousand family 35 mm slides and promised my brothers I would scan the slides and create a digital collection for each one of them.  Received the scanner and after a bit of reading, had the slide scanner up and working relatively quickly.  Previously I scanned on an HP Scanjet 5470 and the process was slow and not the best copy quality.  I am finding that of the slides I have scanned so far with the Wolverine scanner, they are all coming out on the dark side and require work to optimize contrast, etc.  Many of the slides that are winter shots are washing out as if the light source in the scanner is not consistent across the surface.  No amount of processing with software has, so far, taken the scanned images to an acceptable image.  If I had to do it over, I would invest in a better scanner.

title: Writes Terribly and It's Uncomfortable to Hold
text:
The website propaganda states: "Commended for ease of use by the Arthritis Foundation." Considering that I learned years ago that the Arthritis Foundation cannot speak for all arthritis sufferers, including me, I should have known better than to order this pen because arthritics have diverse levels of disabilities. I have advanced systemic RA so my hands are in bad shape, but even if they weren't I found the Pilot Dr. Grip pen to be too thick since it has a 5/8" diameter at the middle (widest area) and a 9/16" diameter at the finger depression (too fat for my comfort). To replace a refill on most pens, the pen comes apart at the middle of the pen's barrel (where the silver tone ring is located). You would think that the Pilot Dr. Grip also unscrews in that area, but it doesn't. It comes apart at the tip, below the cushioned grip. A pen tip is not the most comfortable place for an arthritic to grab and twist so what were the manufacturers and the Arthritis Foundation thinking?. This pen is probably good for someone with non-disabled large hands who likes the feel of a wide girth barrel.

As a comparison, I like the thickness and feel of the Bic Velocity pen, which has a diameter of about 7/16". Similar to Dr. Grip, Bic Velocity has a rubberized cushion grip, but I find the Bic a bit thinner and easier to hold and use. The cushioned grip of Dr. Grip, unlike the Bic's rubberized grip, attracts dust like a magnet. For additional comparison, I also like the feel of thinner cushioned inexpensive non-gel pens like the Bic Atlantis and the Paper Mate Profile. So, why did I buy Dr. Grip? I searched for a gel pen with a comfortable hold and Dr. Grip popped up. I have tried other gel pens in the past and I wasn't pleased with the quality and flow of the gel. Dr. Grip also disappoints in that area b/c it skips as it writes. I have since looked for a gel pen under the manufacturer names that I mentioned above and found nothing that I'd like. A customer recommended the Uni-ball Signo 207, which looks stylish, allegedly writes smoothly and boldly, and accepts refills so I'm going to try it. Hopefully, I'll like it. Signo also has a slightly cheaper model (other than the 207) that doesn't take refills (it's disposable).

It measures 7 1/4 inches by 10 5/16 to accommodate the circles that range in size from 1/16th of an inch to 2 1/4.  I would have preferred two smaller templates instead of the single large one.

title: Little Annoyances
text:
UPDATE: The original review appears below
I finally got fed up with this Samsung printer and bought the HP 1102w, which is designed similarly to my old HP 1018. I haven't used the HP yet because I had planned to use up the cartridge on the Samsung before I placed it in storage. Yesterday, I was anxious to print the first sixty pages of my latest project and inserted about three eigths inch of HP paper into the Samsung. That was too much for it to handle, for it chewed up the first page and creased approximately two more sheets. Luckily, there wasn't a paper jam. However, that annoyance was enough to convince me to activate the HP and hold onto this Samsung for acetate printing or other stuff that could be a little rough on the favored HP.

ORIGINAL REVIEW
I have mixed feelings about the Samsung ML-2165W black & white/monochrome laser printer. I wanted to replace my almost six-year-old HP 1018, which still functioned, but needed serious cleaning that involved dismantling, something I can no longer do because of arthritis. HP has a model that is practically identical to the 1018, but I wanted something smaller and lighter. The Samsung ML-2165W fit the bill at under nine pounds, so I truly like the weight and size. I also like the fact that unlike the HP compact models, the Samsung's USB jack isn't recessed into a cavity that is difficult to access with arthritic fingers.

After getting the Samsung out of the box, I discovered that it also has its drawbacks, and I probably would have been better off with an HP compact model, for I have encountered very annoying design problems with the Samsung. Two items on the Samsung were designed backwards.

The first design flaw is with the cartridge. You remove normal laser cartridges by slipping your fingers under a handhold or groove and pulling up, usually at an angle - that works well when you're working against gravity. The Samsung cartridge's groove is on top and you cannot slip your fingers under anything to pull up at the correct angle. The cartridge is preinstalled, and you're advised to remove it, shake it, and reinstall it. I grabbed it as best I could, but each time I pulled, the entire printer lifted off the desk and the cartridge didn't budge. Luckily, I have a set of miniature crowbars, and I used them to dislodge and refit the cartridge at the proper angle.

The second design flaw is the width-graduating lever for the paper tray. That too is backwards, and it wasn't easy for me to adjust the width to the 8 ½ inch setting, which is as far as it should go, but fails to expand to that full size. To increase the width to the maximum setting, you need to squeeze a clip between your thumb and index finger and glide the clip all the way to the right. The problem is that the release lever is on the right, instead of on the left, where it would make the most sense and would permit you to flush the clip against the printer's frame to get the full 8 ½" width and hopefully allow for some play. The location of the lever prevents that from happening because your finger will end up pinned between the lever and the printer's frame. A pair of needle nose pliers may remedy that, but I don't know where mine are. The end result is that 8 ½" X 11" paper fits so snugly within the tray that it's hard to accommodate more than a few sheets at a time due to the lack of play.

Other annoying little things: The printer is only about a week old, and I already notice that the top page can end up smudged while it sits on the feed tray under the pick-up roller. That's an indication that something may not be quite right with the cartridge or other mechanism(s). Secondly, compared to the HP 1018, the Samsung is whiney noisy. I hope I get used to it.

SUMMARY
The attributes: It's light; it's small; prints well, but not great because the grayscale isn't up to par; has easy plug USB and power jacks; it's also wireless; driver Windows and Mac updates are easy to acquire; it arrived within twenty-four hours and cost me only $87.09 after a $50 instant rebate at Staples. You can't get an HP for that price, but an HP LaserJet printer functions nicely.

Negatives: Has two annoying "backward" designs, making it difficult to remove/install the cartridge and paper; it doesn't have a separate feeder tray for envelopes and postcards; grayscale print is disappointing; and it whines.

title: Not as Advertised
text:
I had three main concerns as I studied several luggage carts on line. They were sturdiness, wheel size, and handle design. This Norris cart meets two of the criteria and others that I did not consider. It's a sturdy cart and the wheel base is as it appears in the image, but the handle isn't bent at a ninety degree angle as shown.

I've owned carts with straight handles and they present a problem when the cargo extends above the cart's height. At that point, in order to get a grip, you'll have to squeeze your fingers between the cargo and the handle. The experience can be uncomfortable and/or painful, depending on the weight and design of what you're lugging. So, I wasn't happy when I discovered that the two carts that I ordered each have straight handles. I'm not returning them, however, because sometimes I can't be bothered.

In the picture, you'll notice that midway down from the handle, there's a section that resembles the hypotenuse of a triangle. It extends from that midpoint to the opposite base. I thought that was a metal piece because I've seen something similar on other carts, which helps to secure whatever you're carrying. Well, since the carts that I received don't have that metallic retainer, I surmise that what I see in the picture may be the black bungee cord, which does come with each cart.

In addition to sturdiness and solid large wheels that permit you to pull the cart with ease, the other amenity that I like on this cart is the base. At the base, you can fold down the front metal piece, giving you extra height and equalizing the front of the cart with the wheels' radius. That's a plus in case you have to lift a package from the bottom; you won't have to scrape your fingers on the pavement. At the base, there are also two metal sections that fold out to each side, making it easier to balance the cargo. When you fold those pieces in, they and two other metal rods that extend along the length of the base may help to prevent a small package from slipping through the bottom.

Finally, the cart opens and closes easily. The only downside that I find with luggage carts in general is that once folded, they don't remain upright. Someone should include a pedestal that you can easily pull or kick out in order to keep a folded cart in a standing position when necessary. Overall: It's a good cart.

title: Not approved by Q
text:
This product does more or less what it says it will - obliterates small areas of information on non-glossy paper. Unfortunately, as anti-spy equipment it wouldn't get past Q at MI5.

Pros:
1. Thoroughly obliterates the area it covers.
2. Excellent on porous material

Cons:
1. Covers a very small area, and even some mailing labels need double stamping.
2. The base is just a little tray that the stamp sits on, and can't be attached to the stamp, so it's not something you'd carry around in your briefcase or handbag.
3. Definitely not for glossy paper, or even semi-glossy paper, as it wipes right off these surfaces.
4. The ink pad is not re-inkable, so when the pad it comes with dries up, you'll need to buy a new one (sold separately of course)

Uses:
1. Obscuring mailing labels on porous paper
2. Hiding your address and signature on cancelled cheques
3. Hiding your address and account information on bank and credit card statements.
4. Obscuring potentially damning phone numbers on your printed phone records
5. Deterring casual snoops and nosey parkers.

Recommended for home use such as disposing cancelled cheques after balancing your chequebook, or obliterating your address on porous mailing labels. Otherwise, it's safer to get a shredder.

All you need to know:

If the paper doesn't suck, this stamp does.

Amanda Richards, July 4, 2010

title: HP and the half-cocked printer (sorry JK Rowling)
text:
What I find puzzling is why HP continues to churn out new printers even before the latest models are put on display, making all sorts of changes, but ignoring completely the old problems that are handed down from generation to generation.

Like its predecessors, this fancy-shmancy printer promises much for people who need to create posters, flyers, banners and so on, but as usual fails to deliver the goods.

It works great for the ordinary stuff - printing letter sized documents from e-mail, Word, Excel etc. with all the settings on "normal", and even does pretty well printing high resolution pictures on photographic paper, but when it has to get down to anything more complicated, it shivers, balks and then goes into a blind panic, creating havoc and paper destruction with wild abandon.

Firstly, this one uses completely different ink cartridges to previous printers, and to add insult to injury, these are smaller than the old ones. Even though there's a very helpful feature that tells you how much ink you have left, it only serves to annoy you when you see that you are just two days away from shelling out more money for new cartridges.

Secondly, my previous HP printer allowed me to create a letter-sized document and then enlarge it to 11" x 17" with a couple of clicks. If this one has that feature it's too well hidden for me to find it, and I gave up trying. If you need a flyer done, and were thinking of blowing it up to make a matching poster - the least irritating way is to change the paper size settings and just enlarge everything manually. If you only need a poster, make sure you set the size first. On the subject of size, this printer assumes you know the dimensions of paper with the codes A3, A4 and so on, and only by "Googling" did I confirm that 11 x 17 goes by the alias "tabloid".

If you need to print a bundle of flyers, and planned to print them in the economy fast mode, don't even consider setting it to 25 and going for coffee. Even if you fan the paper until your co-workers complain about the chill, the printer will work itself up into a frenzy, and begin printing your document in random pieces on multiple sheets of paper, and spitting the results at you with almost religious fervor. You also have to remember to indicate that you don't need the two-sided printing, or you'll get a bunch of blank pages in the middle of the pile of 150 sheets it used to print your 25 flyers, most of which look like bits of a jigsaw puzzle.

The "Cancel Print" button still doesn't work properly, and you'll have a lot of wasted paper if you need to stop a print job. The control buttons have now been moved from the right hand side like every other printer I've ever owned, and are now on the left hand side, so that I have to do yoga stretches over the desk to get to them.

On the good side, it prints regular documents quickly and with good quality, and once you have your paper sizes set up correctly, it prints 11 x 17 and 13 x 19 posters. Time will tell whether the rollers have been improved on this model, as the last one refused to pick up cardboard or large paper sizes after a few months.

I'm beginning to think that the printer's devil has split its soul into multiple parts, and is using HP printers as horcruxes. Only by destroying them all will we be saved. Can anyone spare a trustworthy Defense against the Dark Arts printer designer?

Amanda Richards, August 6, 2005

title: An update on my previous review
text:
Frustration has driven me to write another review, this time based solely on the "special" features of this printer.
As I said before, it still works fine on the regular stuff - letters, e-mail, documents, even envelopes, other than the problem with having to press the "resume" button to print them. That's what the 2 star rating is about. If you look beyond the mundane - it's a ZERO star rating or less.
Printing anything out of the ordinary has become a major pain, which seems to be getting worse as the printer gets older.
Any paper that is even slightly glossy is now slipping on the rollers - not all the time, but enough to drive you mad, especially when you need to print something in a hurry. The printer also gets quite upset when you try to cancel the print, even when you use the button designed for this purpose.
The paper wastage is tremendous after a job is spoilt due to the slippage, because not only do you lose the special paper you put in, but also a ton of regular paper, as the machine continues to spew out reams of gibberish in protest. Having to reboot the machine to solve a print error is totally ridiculous. This is a recurring problem with HP printers in my experience.
If you do most of your printing on cardboard, glossy paper, transparencies or other special paper, think twice before buying this printer, as it can send you stark staring crazy in a very short time.

title: Extremely difficult to open

title: Hydraulics don't even support less than 400lbs. Disappointed.
text: I bought this chair twice because of comfort but the hydraulics don't hold well. The first chair lasted a year but the most recent, not even 30 days until it started to slowly drop down. I'm under 400lbs so there is no reason it should adequately support my weight when the product description states it supports up to 500lb. Disappointed and won't buy for a 3rd time because it is obviously defective.

title: Poor design
text: The sound is gravelly for the first minute. Sometimes when I try to answer, it only rings once. The menu doesn't have enough options to make phone efficient. I have to be very careful hanging up receiver or it won't charge. I wish I hadn't  ought it. Waste of money.

title: adequate
text: It works and I enjoy the ability to have my hands free to accomplish other things but to be honest, it is OK for calls but seems to be made with the most frugal requirements.  I am not trying to be mean. I guess it is true that you get what you paid for.

title: Don't buy these
text: Will not work on the printer as the printer will not recognize these cartridges. I had to throw them out after I opened and installed them. They did not work at all and leaked. I would give zero stars if I could.

title: My printer isnt detecting the black ink cartridge
text: I hate giving low ratings. Unfortunately, my printer had a problem detecting one of the ink cartridges (black). As a result, I have been unable to print anything. I was trying to save a little cash and now i will end up spending even more cash.

title: Broken rings
text: The rings in the binder broke pretty quickly, I was sent another one but one of the rings was already broken on the brand new one :(

title: Poorly packaged
text:
This is the actual state of the shipping packaging. It came wrapped in thin plastic like you would find it on the shelf in a store with a shipping label slapped on. As you can see I my picture, the rubber band did all the work.
Pretty sure the usps was gentle with it as very few pages were abused.

Paper is exactly as expected. Nice smooth newsprint. It isn’t fuzzy at all and will work perfectly for my littles to practice their writing.

title: Great concept, not effectively applied
text: The concept is very good, but the depth of the indentations are insufficient to hold the pen in the patterned groove. It was bought for use by a 4 year old and it was not able to be done effectively. It was very disappointing.

title: Kind of works
text: The blue handle one worked well to pull nails for carpet.  The red handle one was too thick and didn't work at all.

title: Not 90lb card stock
text: This is very thin and not card stock as stated. This is very disappointing since I really have no use for this thin paper.

title: NOISY AND LIMITED!
text:
This is disappointing - very noisy and startling when it staples. And unfortunately the throat depth cannot be adjusted, so it only staples in one position. The staples do not go in flat, so I have to press them down with a metal object so they are not protruding. The sensor is not very good and you have to twist the paper back and forth to get it stapled. I probably would get used to the noise, but not being able to adjust how far in the staple is place the edge of the paper I cannot work with.

the Suction cups are very good and it doesn't move.

title: Problems!
text:
I purchased 3 of these inks for my HP 8610 printer. I did not need to use them before now since I had one already in use, however now that I need to replace the cartridge I am getting a message saying that these inks are incompatible. I tried another of the batch and the same message.

I cannot understand why this has happened since the information on Amazon and the box indicates that the ink is for the printer. I ordered from amazon previously same inks and they worked. They were sold directly by Amazon so I will try to contact them to see if they will replace them.

title: Not marble!
text: These checks are good,  however they are marble style which is what I ordered and is stated on the novice. They are a weave pattern and the right shade  green , but  I really needed marble style -so it gets a 3,  otherwise I would rate as a five star.

title: poor quality tray
text: The  pan was actually what I needed, the size and inner tray,  however the inner tray is of very cheap material.  I ordered two and both of the inner trays were broken in more than one place.  Its a pity that the pan itself is very sturdy but the trays are so poor.  The actual layout of the tray is ideal with 4 slots for bills and some for coins.  I am so disappointed and will not recommend unless you really don't need the inner tray.

title: Awful. Drops WiFi.not good for wireless printing
text: Terrible all in one. Had it for 4 days and finally returned it.  The printer would go to sleep, then had to reload modem and password, would then print 1 or 2 pages and stop working.  Called Canon support about 6 times and the recording said to hold for next operator, then I would be disconnected.  WiFi connection constantly dropped.  The printer would say the print job was printing then go away from the printer queue, but nothing printed.  The touch screen is weak, the directions of setup are awful. I have purchased dozens of printer and never had a problem connecting immediately to a printer.  Returned this printer .  I have a MacBook and a Netgear modem.  I really wanted this to work because was a monochromatic laser printer - was hoping to save on ink costs.  But, it did not work out and was the most frustrating experience I have ever had with a printer.  And, I am an IT person by trade.

title: Didn’t work
text: I got them the use in the basement and they didn’t stop the door

title: PICTURES MISLEADING, works so far, but not what I expected
text:
This is NOT the brand name, THIS IS AN OFF-BRAND PRODUCT, and IS NOT THE PICTURE as shown, PICTURE MISLEADING!

I hesitated to use this product because it wasn't the brand name i was used to, and did not want to ruin my printer. Used it because I was in a rush with something, and it works just fine. HOWEVER, I find it's advertising misleading, and I will not be buying agin.

title: Better price than retail.
text: Ink is crazy expensive. This is exactly what I need for my printer, but it's pricey.

title: Horrible!
text: Broke after two days.  Leg broke off.  Very hard to push the buttons on side to adjust table and legs.  I liked that it was lightweight and it can slide over the top of the bed with the legs adjusted peoperly.  The mouse pad table does not stay fixed so the mouse falls of as soon as you let go of it and falls off.  This was a true waste of money.  It cannot be fixed because the legs are plastic.

title: used it one time put it away went to use glued shut no more open

title: can't hold up a 2 pound item indoors for longer then 2 hours pathetic
text: can't hold up a 2 pound item indoors for longer then 2 hours pathetic

title: Colors are  "off"
text:
I have used other generic ink cartridges for my TR4720 with zero problems over the years. This set fits and my printer recognized them easily. The black prints totally normally.

However, the colors seem off to me. Everything is sort of muted and not as crisp or bright as normal. Just dull. I don't print a ton of stuff in full color, so I can live with it awhile. These cartridges are not a significant savings over the OEM ink though.

title: Not great with drywall & a heavy door
text:
This is probably fine for something like a screen door or even a swing window of some sort. However, for a heavy entry door, this is not great. The included hardware like the wall anchors is flimsy and thin - I actually had to buy better anchors because one these simply broke.

My problem is the magnet is so strong with a heavy door, that you have to actually pull hard to separate the door from the stop. Unfortunately, that causes the anchor to shift and wobble just a bit in the wall. Which leads to drywall damage. Over time, the entire doorstop will come loose or out of the wall entirely leaving a damaged area.

title: Useless as a magnet,  useless as tape
text: Grrrr. I wanted to attach this to a fridge in an RV so we could display our magnets from different locations.  Nope. This is just straight up garbage. The adhesive is weak and does not hold on any surface. We tried it on wood, plastic and metal.  Every piece fell off within 3 hours. Absolutely useless. Just for fun, i tried to attach stuff to the magnetic side - it holds the church key bottle opener,  but nothing else.  I just threw the rest of the roll away.

title: interesting and sometimes very funny
text: Some of these are pretty darn funny and some are ridiculous and some just emphasize the differences between the coasts and the rest of the nation. It's an interesting way to start the day off. There is no room for notes on these pages, so it's definitely a look at only type of thing.

title: Not leather. Decent size journal
text:
I absolutely hate when these companies use the word leather in the product name when it is NOT leather. This is some chemically made plastic and while it is soft, it is not actually leather and looks like plastic. The very use of the word leather is deliberately misleading.

The book itself is fine - lots of blank pages and plenty of room to write on each one. The lock is flimsy, but it does work fine and they included complete instructions on changing the code. The moon design is cute without being childish. I always carry a journal when we travel and this should work for me.

title: Very small cards and ugly logo on the envelopes
text: Sigh. This doesn't feel like Hallmark to me. These are much smaller than traditional Christmas cards - they make me think of the little Valentine's Day cards kids passed out in 3rd grade. The envelopes are flimsy and have a big Ink Studio logo on the back. It's tasteless and cheap looking.

title: Frozen ink slots, menu loops incessantly with one error message. Unusable
text:
I have a Bluetooth HP printer that works like a charm after two years, but it doesn't scan. I thought I would use this one as an upgrade of sorts, despite having had trouble with two previous Canon Pixma printers in the past.

Unfortunately, this printer is a failure for me. Just as persnickety and error prone as the other two I had trouble with before. I had it out of the box in five minutes and the packing materials removed and plugged it in. It immediately flashed an error code saying the paper cartridge was not installed properly. I followed the directions and for fifteen minutes the screen looped from the error code to the menu and back to the error code. Meanwhile, the ink slots are frozen and the belt won't move to allow me to even try to install the ink containers. It's simply unusable at this point.

The frozen ink holder problem is the same one I had with my first Pixma a few years ago - at least that printer waited a few months to act up. This will be the last Canon printer for me, I'll stick to the little HP printer.

title: Thirsty card just sounds like highschool puppy love
text:
I love cards and buy them for random reasons throughout the year. There's just something lovely about getting a sweet card in the mail unexpectedly and I try to pass that feeling on to our friends.

(Review of the Mahogany Thirsty Card)

This, however, just struck me as off. It's not unattractive per se, but it feels unbalanced and the decorations are just sort of scattered all over it. The message has a distinct immaturity as well. My first impression wasn't of love or adoration, but some poor, acne plagued, 14 year old boy trying to convince his first girlfriend of his undying love.

I asked my husband to read it without sharing my impressions. He laughed and said "are we in highschool?" So it's not just me. I won't be passing this one on to him for our anniversary.

title: Meh. Old fashioned and a little dull. Sturdy though.
text: This is a nice enough birthday card, but I don't love it. It's kind of old fashioned and not in that retro cool way. The card itself is sturdy and stands up nicely so it could be displayed on a desk or shelf easily. The message is sweet and lovely - I don't think there's anything odd about it at all, perfectly suitable for someone you truly care about. There's just an overall impression of boring and meh when I look at this card. It's not one I would every pay for in a store or mail to a friend.

title: Some kind of Sticky Mess on box
text: This box arrived with a sticky mess on the outside of the box.  It was just gross.  The toner cartridge was fine, but I can't tell you how many times I washed my hands after touching this box.  I would have returned it had I not been desperate for toner.

title: Box was open when received
text: Box had been opened and taped back shut when I received this item.  Even the inner plastic packaging was broken open.  Didn't seem used, but was definitely opened at some point.

title: THIN
text: This chair cushion is thin.  It's also not as big as my chair seat, so it either gets pushed way back to where the front of my legs are not touching the cushion or it gets pushed to the front and if I sit way back in the chair, my rear is off the cushion.  Very frustrating for the price.

title: Waste of $

title: Not as colorful as pictured.
text: Paper arrived wadded  & wrinkled, so Amazon is issuing a refund. Nevertheless,  the colors are muddied & one side of each sheet has "lines" on it. Not at ALL like the bright paper shown on the website.

title: Doesn't  cut straight

I will now have to get a new printer and hopefully it will have an easier cartridge installment.

text: Thank You People! I almost brought this White Out.

text: It showed up like this....hopefully it works, I'll try it out, and if not I'm going to need a return slip.

title: Counterproductive
text: There's no place to on the sheets allotted for bills or rent, two integral parts of a budgeting. Also, there's no place for 'beginning balance' or 'balance at beginning of the day' or ' balance after money spent'. This would have been helpful, too. Overall, NOT IMPRESSED.

title: The metal clasps do not line up
text: Have to keep lining up the metal rings, or the paper does not slide. Pain in the neck
