title: Could not get comfortable.
text: Did not work for me. Could not get comfortable.

title: Read the cleaning instructions for the cover very carefully.
text: More comfortable than a regular foot stool, quite portable. Nice to rest my feet on while knitting. Read the cleaning instructions for the cover very carefully. Would be nice to have more color choices.

title: Too expensive
text: These actually cost more than the pens to replace. It is cheaper to keep buying the pens although they do run out of ink very quickly.

title: I love these pens
text: I love these pens and keep ordering them. Love the bold smooth effect in my writing. Only gave three stars because they run out of ink so quickly. Also the refill cost more than the pens.

title: Not heavy duty at all. Command strips worked better for me
text: Hung a light canvas painting & it fell off the wall the next day. Would work better for posters & plain paper. Total waste of money. Ended up buying Command strips which actually worked.

title: 1/4 cube enough to pack 1 wine glass sans the stem
text: I wish I paid attention to how much comes in 1/4 of a cube. It's a really small box amount and you can't really protect more than 1 tiny item.

title: One Star
text: Could not get this to install properly on my laptop or desktop. It did work on 2 occasions.

title: No monthly photos, just a cover pic
text:
When I got this, I had thought there would be artwork on every page, but that is not the case. It is spiral bound, so you can easily flip to the next month.

There is plenty of space to write things for most people. It also comes with two sheets of occasion stickers to mark birthdays, appointments, etc.

You can choose to hang this up as the entire length of the calendar, or use the hanging wire to only show the current month.

Overall, I would not buy this calendar again. I prefer the option to see a nice picture, but it is only on the cover of this one.

title: I don't see this one working very well
text:
Well, I am not sure how this is going to be 100% fireproof.

It is nice and thick, like an oily neoprene. It has a sturdy zipper as well. It looks to have enough room for most important papers.

However, I just don't see how this bag is anything but maybe fire retardant, not fireproof. There is a small opening at the end of the zipper. Fire wouldn't just stop because it should...it looks to me like it could pass right on into the bag at the zipper opening.

If you have super important papers, they should be in a safety deposit box at your bank, not in a cheapie bag at your home.

This is just my opinion on this bag. I am not going to set a fire to test it, so you'll have to draw your own conclusions as to whether you want to trust this bag or not. For me, it's a no.

title: Very runny, I don't trust them
text:
[[VIDEOID:647f30f7d16bdd37c5edf76b8b928338]] I don't know about others, but I don't buy home printers very often. I buy the best I can afford, and use them until they are worn out.

A couple years ago, I bought a very expensive Canon home inkjet printer. I use it to print patterns, as well as correspondence or shipping labels. It is no secret that ink costs a fortune. Most cartridges have dense sponges in them, which helps control the release of the ink so it does not spot on your printing project.

When I saw generic cartridges for my printer, I thought I'd see what the quality was like. I have to say, I was disappointed. While the sizing looks to be spot-on, there is only a tiny piece of sponge in these, and mostly liquid with the viscosity of water. It looks like water with food coloring in it. Yuck.

If you have a very old printer that you don't care about, these will probably work ok for that. With newer printers, you can actually void your warranty by using off-brand ink cartridges in them. Mine is likely out of the warranty period. I am choosing to NOT put these in my machine, as I can't afford to replace a printer right now. I truly do not trust what looks to be colored water not just running throughout the printer. Sorry, I can't recommend these.

title: HARD PASS on these cheap envelopes
text:
Wow.
I use poly envelopes often. They are great for keeping paperwork organized. I decided to try this set.

Well, I can say HARD PASS on these.
The first and biggest reason is that these are shipped folded up into thirds instead of just laying flat like normal envelopes! Yup, they were packaged by the manufacturer all folded into thirds width-wise. Crazy! They don't look like they'll take much pressure of a lot of papers either. These are apparently the cheapest of the cheap. But I am just amazed that the company decided folding these up in thirds instead of putting them flat in a envelope to ship flat. Grrrrrr. (A month later, and none have uncurled. It is crazy.)

So, you get a lot of poly envelopes for the price, but every single one is bent in two places. I have no words for how annoying this is. I recommend you shop elsewhere and avoid these.

title: Cheaply made, way too thin, no give
text:
Nope.
Hard pass.

I thought this looked sturdy enough to put files into. Nope. This was so disappointing.
It has the approximate thickness of the cardboard of a cereal box. It has a strange, fuzzy texture to it that wasn't pleasant.

It also has NO give at all, so if you try to put too much into it, it will just rip.

This one looks much nicer than it actually is. I really can't think of hardly anything this would be truly useful for, and cannot recommend it.

title: Cheaply made, ok for rare use, not ok for lots of use
text:
I bought two of these, because we will be moving soon, and I didn't want to put my tape dispenser around. I thought these would be easy to work with and save time.

I was wrong.
We've spent a LOT of time re-aligning the tape, as it shifts and moved every time you use it. The little metal guide that is supposed to hold the tape in place does very little.

We thought at first it was the cheapie roll of tape that comes with it. But nope...same results with the more expensive box tape as well.

If you have a lot of boxes to tape, save yourself a headache and get a more heavy-duty tape gun. If you only rarely need box tape, then this might suit your purposes.

But for now, we are muttering aloud every time we use these. The tape twists, gets stuck to itself or the dispenser, and is generally annoying to use.

title: Not new colors, just repackaged already-available colors
text:
I love Sharpies and have more of them than normal folks would have! LOL
But, these were pretty much a waste. No actual new colors - they are just repackaged
in a way to look like they belong together.

Meh.

title: Reasonable price for a reasonable quantity of a reasonable product - go ahead and order it!
text:
There isn't a whole lot to be said about a box.
However, that hasn't stopped me yet.

As boxes go, these arrived quickly and sealed so they were not sliding all over the place.
They were nicely packaged as a community of boxes, living well together. No shreds, tears or
ruined boxes.

The only mild complaint I had about these was that when they are put together, the corners are
slightly open. In other words, if you had put a flashlight in the on position in the box, you'll see light
coming through everywhere the corners meet. Since I ship things with fabric in them, that meant I need
to put an extra piece of tape on each little corner to keep as much of the outside out as possible.

I also found out that I could have gone down 1" to ship what I make, but that's just something that you don't know
until you try it. The price was fair, shipment was quick, and I didn't have to order enough to open a box store.
In other words, it totally fits the bill for those who need a few boxes, not a case.

title: Great idea, but the plastic is too weak for the width
text:
This is a really good idea, in theory.
Sterlite makes great storage containers, and most of us have at least one in our homes.
I purchased this one at a chain store, not here online.

We were pinched for space, so I thought this would be great to hold crafting supplies
that would still be within easy reach. It sort of worked!
I had all the drawers with something in them - I tried a variety of things.
Fabric ended up being way too heavy, even though that is what I hoped to use it for.

The thing is - this is a fairly wide drawer to pull out. When there is much of any weight
in them, they don't want to pull out! Mine did not seem to be warped, yet that is how it
acted. The drawers became almost impossible to pull out if there was actually stuff in them.
I ended up using it to hold bubble wrap, which was a real waste of the "real estate" this thing
takes up. It worked okay for bubble wrap, but I was needing more storage for other things.

So, it is back to the drawing board for Sterlite on this design - it's too wide for the thin
plastic that is used for this one. If they'd thicken it up a bit on the drawers, it would be
really good. My little 12" wide Sterlite 3-drawer bin on rollers has thicker drawers than
this big one does!

So, I'd have to advise taking a "pass" on this one until they beef up the plastic drawers.
Otherwise, if you only have really lightweight things, like hosiery, scarfs, socks, etc, it
MIGHT work for you, but I wouldn't count on it.

title: This was my LAST HP printer!!
text:
Well, I've been a faithful HP customer since the late 1980's.
I've had 3 HP printers, but this one is my LAST!!

I bought this model to use in my home office - basic stuff like
scanning papers or photos, printing shipping or address labels.
Not exactly new technology we're talking about here.

This printer is THE WORST!
For some reason, HP decided I was no longer smart enough to know how to check my
ink levels or align my printer, and wanted to do it for me. Well, okay, but here's the
kicker - EACH AND EVERY TIME YOU CHANGE EVEN ONE INK CARTRIDGE, this printer will print out
an "alignment page" that uses quite a bit of black ink, and also a little color ink.
EACH TIME. Also EACH TIME, I have to scan the stupid printout to make sure it is still "aligned".

You know, I used to be able to decide for myself if the printer was a little off, or the quality
wasn't what I was looking for. Those days are gone, and in their place is this ridiculous system
that not only forces a scan each time (and they are pretty slow), but wastes way too much ink.
HP ink is NOT cheap, and they are making sure you need it more often by these ridiculous alignment pages.
So far tonight, I changed the black ink cartridge, and it has printed out the alignment sheet TWICE,
despite my doing the scan. It didn't "take" somehow. So now I have two of these asinine sheets using
up my ink and still can't print a recipe yet.

Then let's touch base on the scanner. It does just fine for photos and flat papers.
If you have something that is 3D, then you are out of luck! I used to scan beads for selling
craft supplies online. My old HP scanner did a fantastic job on the scans, and I had better pictures of
the items than I could get with a digital camera. Then came the upgrades. I was forced to change to Vista
when my old HP computer bit the dust. I bought a new HP Pavilion with Vista preinstalled. I tried to hook up
my old scanner, and could not! The scanner wasn't that old and still worked great, but XP was the last supported program
for it, and HP would not put out an updated driver for it. (Grrrrr! Stop shaking me down to buy more equipment!)

Well, I had to have something, so I bought this all-in-one. I REALLY regret it now.
The scanner CANNOT do 3D items - you only get shadows on the edges, and only the parts actually touching
the glass will show up clearly. Resolution doesn't matter, because it just can't read 3D.

Then this irritating alignment sheet thing is the final deal breaker.
HP, you are wasting my time and my ink. I can get any printer to print, so why pay so much more
for your brand printer and high-cost ink? I'm done with you - the love affair of over a decade
is done.

It is very sad how HP quality continues to decline (was it because they merged with Compaq, or did they stop
caring about the quality of the products?). After having owned 4 Pavilion computers, 4 HP digital cameras,
3 printers and 1 scanner, I can say that I am no longer a loyal HP customer. They just don't care about the
product OR the customer any more, so it is time to be reciprocal in the lack of love. (And yes, I wrote to
customer service about it, and never received anything but the form email saying they got my email - never a
response, never an answer.)

Bye bye HP - it's time we broke up, and you take this piece of junk printer with you.

title: Dang it - these are not the greatest pens.
text:
Well, first off, I have to say that I ordered the wrong pens. I wanted the Bic Ultimates.
I'd done a search here at Amazon, and it came up with a couple listings,
one for an individual pack and one for 12 packs of them. I clicked on the individual one
and ordered it. Didn't give it a second thought until I got the order today.

I got these nasty Shimmer pens instead. I don't like anything about them but the barrel color.
It was my mistake for not reading about the pen I was ordering more carefully before clicking.
Silly me - I thought the search engine would only pull in the things with all of the words I included.
It doesn't! I really didn't need a dozen packs of them, so went with the single pack.

I was willing to pay the cost for my favorite Ultimates, but these are DEFINITELY not worth the money! : (

So, not sure what I'll do, but either buy these at WalMart, or find another pen.
They write, but not nearly as nicely as so many others that are available.

Moral of the story? Never shop online without your glasses!

title: Expired
text: These are old and dry. Not even one marker I got worked as supposed to.

title: Horrible constant jamming!!
text: This is by far the worst paper I have ever purchased. This paper does nothing but jam my printer. I have purchased a variety of printer paper brands off of Amazon, so much that I decided to buy this in bulk to save on so much ordering. This paper had great reviews, including ones about 0 jamming (a problem I’ve only encountered with shiny card stock until I bought this paper). It’s not thick it’s just so thin and cheap that my printer must be thrown off when it takes a sheet off of the stack. Horrible don’t waste your money. I have a HP printer with copier. The first jamming encounter I thought it was a fluke and I must have put too much in but nope 10 minutes later another jam. We are on three jams in 25 minutes. Worthless paper, do not buy!

title: An excellent labeler which goes throuight batteries at an alarming rate.
text: Basically the title tells it all.  This requires 9 AAA batteries and flashes a warning that is something like "low battery charge" after a very short time.  I bought a labeler that runs on AC current and tossed this one.

title: A little bit of everything ...
text:
I'm an avid papercrafter -- I've been making handcrafted greeting cards for several years, and own a lot of similar products. I also use a lot of Teresa Collins papers in my work (I just finished a set of cards using her "Sweet Afternoon" papers [[ASIN:B007Y7Q2JU Teresa Collins Designs Sweet Afternoon 6 by 6-Inch Pad]] ). So I was happy to check out this adhesive kit.

It contains the most commonly used adhesives for paper crafting: clear liquid adhesive, foam squares, double-sided tape, tape runner, and sticker maker, along with a sponge you can use to "clean up" any stray bits of adhesive, all packaged in a nice pink box.

The products are fine -- they're decent quality, they do what they're supposed to do. The clear adhesive works well to stick buttons, fabric flowers, etc. to paper; it also works nicely to add gloss accents. I use a lot of double-sided tape when I make my folders to hold packs of cards, and the double-sided tape included here works fine, although you don't get a lot of it. The tape runner is also nice quality, similar to others on the market.

But I do have a few quibbles. The foam squares are way too thick for most card-making uses. I usually use 1/32"-thick squares so that I can have multiple layers; using these, I can only use a single layer; otherwise, the card is too thick for mailing in a "regular" envelope. Also, the Xyron sticker maker allows you to make stickers only 1" wide, which is rather narrow. It's great for sticking ribbon, but not so good for creating stick-on flowers (for example) or other shapes.

If you just want to try out some of these items, this might be a decent way to get all of them together. But I'm not sure the usefulness outweighs the cost. 3 stars: it's OK, but nothing to write home about.

title: Sturdy, functional, nice size ... but don't expect a long life ...
text:
UPDATE: Feb 14. 2016
Mine bit the dust this week. The weld that holds the desktop to the middle support bar failed. It actually started splitting about 4 months ago, and I tried several options (various glues) to stabilize it, but nothing worked, and this past week it finally reached a point where it was just too "wobbly" to be usable.

This was used daily to hold my MacBook Air 13" (so not a lot of weight) plus a coffee cup or bottle of iced tea. Occasionally I used it for crafts projects (mostly coloring stamped images to use on handmade greeting cards, so we're talking a clipboard and some colored pencils). I was careful to move it by holding the middle support, not the desktop.

So ... bottom line, it performed nicely for about 2.5 years, but daily use (not anything heavy) caused a critical weld to split. I would have expected a little more -- 5 years, perhaps. (I've replaced it with a slightly less attractive but probably more practical stand ... )

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I purchased this to use in the living room for my laptop and crafts projects.

I'm no spring chicken, and I'm sometimes a bit "hardware challenged," but I was able to assemble this by myself in less than 15 minutes. The instructions are fairly clear, and as long as you're careful to get things turned the right way, it will go together smoothly. All tools are included in the parts packet, so you don't even need a screwdriver.

The size of the "table" is impressive for a stand/cart of this price. It's more than large enough to hold my MacBook Pro 15" plus my Akai LPK25 keyboard that I use for composing music. This gets me out of my office (where I have an 88-key Alesis keyboard for composition), and into the living room which has a lovely view of the garden.

I also use it for some of my crafts work -- assembling handcrafted greeting cards, preparing and coloring stamped images, making bows and trims, etc. Again, the size gives me a lot of real estate to play with. I can spread out a lot of "stuff."

It feels sturdy, too -- no wobble, nothing "flimsy" about it at all. I wish it had a "tilt" function for the table, but I can get a tilt just by turning the top 180 degrees (hard to explain, but it works).

Also, the platform with the wheels is a bit too high to fit under my sofa, so I've had to raise my sofa about 2" so that it will clear. Small price to pay for the convenience.

Anyway, the bottom line for me is: does it work for my uses? and does it look like I won't have to replace it soon? And the answer to both of those questions is a resounding "YES!"

title: Good idea, maybe needs a little tweaking ...
text:
I think this is a brilliant idea -- I've used post-its for years, and often thought a removable label would be perfect. These are pretty good, but not quite perfect yet.

They stick to glass just fine. I use them to label the jars of different coffees I have on hand. I reuse quart jars to hold individual varieties of both ground and whole bean coffees in my pantry. This allows me to change up my collection and change labels without worrying about leaving sticky residue. They're colorful, too -- and look nice.

Sticking to plastic was a problem. I found that they stick to some disposable plastic containers (Rubbermaid Take-Alongs, for example), but NOT to the more durable reusable plastic containers. This will be an issue for a lot of folks, I'm sure.

Getting an individual label off the pad can be an issue, too. Some days I could extract a single label with no problem; other days, it was a struggle. I'm not sure what the problem was -- humidity, maybe?

Anyway, I'll keep using these in my pantry, but I'm not sure I'll use them for anything else.

title: UPDATE one month later - Had to "pick" to open
text:
SEPTEMBER 16, 2020-- I finally got around to setting up this Masterlock 5420D lock box. If followed the directions in the .pdf instructions sheet, set the combination to the last four of my social security number, and closed the box as directed. I couldn't open it using my combination, and thought I had essentially lost use of the contents --a mini garage door opener and a spare key. I shortly found that there are Youtube videos demonstrating how to pick this lockbox. I was able to get it open that way; it now seems to be working, but I wonder how common the knowledge is that it is so easily picked. CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS ITEM.

AUGUST 11, 2020 - I have no cons for this item, but will share a personal observation. I'm getting older and live alone; somehow, recently managed to lock myself out of my duplex without a key or a garage door opener. I purchased this lock box based on the listed interior dimensions because I was hoping to include both a key and a spare garage door opener in it to hang on an exterior doorknob for emergencies like that. Alas, the "larger" interior is still not adequate for inserting a standard garage door opener because the locking mechanism inside protrudes so deeply into the interior space. Hoping I can find a dependable "mini" opener for this purpose. But the quality of the 5420D is excellent.

title: Great while it lasted
text:
I've had this unit for nine months, almost to the day. I have been very pleased with the software and the hardware; it had even been accepting recycled ink cartridges (which are still expensive!) without a fuss. The only thing I haven't liked about it is that, if any one of the FIVE ink cartridges is empty, the unit stops printing altogether. No black and white, no nothing.

This morning I replaced the Yellow cartridge and when the ink tank carrier moved back into place it started grinding like a car's manual transmission gears being stripped. I managed to get it to print again, but the prints are now banded, off color, grainy and otherwise unusable. After several diagnostic procedures there is no change.

It was at this point that I found the Canon support website to be pretty useless, presenting me with nothing but a non-working link to press like a hopeful capuchin monkey after entering my unit's serial number and date of purchase. I'm not too happy about the idea of spending the money to ship a 30-lb. hunk of electronics somewhere with the unlikely prospect that it would work when I got it back after a 2- to 5-week wait. (I was once a Denon technical support CSR; I know how these things too often go.)

I've used the Pixma MP560 for my home office only, and only rarely for color printing. Sometimes a week or ten days go by before I even turn my printer on, so I haven't exactly overworked the thing.

If nine months of light use seems like a short lifespan to you, as it does to me, I'd try something else. As for me, my next printer is going to be strictly black and white, with as few expensive ink cartridges and moving parts as possible, even if I have to hand-feed the bloody thing. I'm really tired of throwing good money after bad on consumer electronics. Pretty disappointed with Canon.

title: For Turo Hosts....My Experience
text:
Well.....we bought this lockbox as Turo hosts. When it arrived, the space was much smaller than anticipated. If you dont lay the fob in the right way, the case wint close. There goes the privacy pouch that prevents the connection to start the car.

We tossed the privacy pouch because we thought about all the times we were guests on Turo. Everyone just left the key in the car and we were probably doing too much after warching Youtube videos. Fine. We set the combo, dripped the car and provided the code to the guest.

When the guest returned the car, he somehow changed the code. I was not happy with the driver. I mean really? wtf? Then i thought about that ridiculius little lever to move to the b pisition to lock. I can of course see someone changing the code inadvertantly. $200 later, The locksmith got it off without scratching the car but needless to say, this is not a lock for Turo hosts. Expensive lesson.....I didnt even get 1 use out of this lockbox. Hope this helps.

I assumed it had one when I ordered it and found out months later that it doesn't - the family member I bought it for is far away and doesn't use a digital camera that often, but was used to having the card reader in the old printer.  A trip to Walmart and $15 for a standalone card reader solved this problem, but the printer really should have a card reader.

After installing studio yet again I was able to activate the business edition. I am not overly impressed with the software but it is sufficient for my purposes.

title: Don't buy this printer
text:
I purchased this printer on recommendation for specialty printing.

I have been a Network Administrator for over 20 years and have never had a network enabled printer this difficult to set up. You need to read the manual on-line while trying to set up the network. I finally resorted to USB connection!

All liquid ink printers must be charged before use this usually uses five to twenty percent (5% ~ 20%) of the starter cartridges, this is understandable. With that said, this printer it took eighty percent (80%) of the special jeljet cartridges (Sawgrass) that I purchased for this printer, a cost of nearly $200.00.

If you do not need to purchase this printer I would recommend that you look elsewhere for a better tool for your job, stear this one a wide birth.

The biggest problem with these markers is the actual color of the marker itself doesn't adequately reflect the color it draws. For example there's 2 greens and while the color they draw is obviously different the outside color of the markers themselves is almost identical, making it hard to tell what color you're actually using.

Unfortunately the paper is too thin, writing and highlighting shows through on the opposite side. That's not ok as it makes the reverse side sloppy looking and hard to read. Deal breaker for me so I'm returning it. Such a shame because otherwise it's great.

Just be aware also that it's HUGE. Much bigger than I expected. Not it's fault, I didn't read the dimensions carefully and I'd still have happily used it if the paper quality were better. Very disappointed such a great planner has such a fatal flaw. I mean for this kind of price you expect good quality paper. It's not cheaply priced, shouldn't be cheaply made. Boo.

It really is only a card holder, as the zippered area is so tight that it's hard to even get dollar bills in and out of it (and cards don't fit in it at all).  If you have just a few cards (no more than 4), like an ID and a couple of bank cards, then this is okay for you, but don't expect to get cash or change in it as well.  I wish it was more substantial and held more, but it's just good for a few cards.

title: have patience- takes long time to prime, bold colors, might leave haze when wiped off
text:
[[VIDEOID:d41afc4a49454093909a0ace01a3ab07]] They take awhile to prime. Shake shake shake, shake some more, then press press press, maybe shake a few more times. Eventually the liquid chalk works its way down to the pen tip. Tip can be turned around--- one side rounded, one side slanted.

Once it is fully primed, the richness of most colors are nice. Some colors are better than others (primary), some could be more robust (metallic).

The case is nice, HOWEVER, it is not designed the same as shown in the product pictures. The pictures show that the pens are situated on both sides of the case. Mine are situated directly in the center. SEE MY PICS.
Zips fully open. Easy to open, easy to close.

Be mindful of the surface you use these on. It may leave a haze of color. I was able to get out remaining color with use of a bleach cleaner. I will stick to chalkboard use only.

I selected these because I wanted more colorful chalk than what I have. I have the typical dry dull looking sticks. Why does it matter? Because I have fun doodling on a wall hung chalkboard situated at our main house door. It was here well before we moved in (20+ years) ago, and with just two adults in the house, it really serves no purpose. So I took to making terribad art on it. I make some quick doodles every once in awhile for the sheer fun of it. Adding in more color allows me to more options. I enjoy the process of creating a images with chalk.

Overall, I like the colors, I dont like how long it takes to prime each one, and I have to do this nearly every time. Maybe thats the norm? Can leave haze on some surfaces, case wasn't as expected. I give them 3 stars because I think they (and my overall experience) have been"OK".

title: Nice But
text:
It is sometimes hard to do reviews that are negative but I have to be honest. I have another eco tank printer that I am comparing this too. That printer was HALF the price of this one.

Pros:
Easy to set up
Instant wifi connection
Easy to install driver
Looks nice
BIG ink tanks
Auto double side printing is good
Worth it for someone that does a lot of standard printing.
Easy to read display

Cons:
No legal side document tray (for 900 dollars this should be standard.)
No full bleed printing. This is the BIGGEST con. I have printers that are half this price that not only have a legal paper tray but also do full bleed printing.

If you are a crafter, paper artist, print maker, sticker maker, etc. this printer is NOT for you. Without the full bleed option it is useless for anyone that wants to do pictures, etc. I thought that I was doing something wrong but when I tweeted the company they confirmed that it did not have a full bleed option.

I honestly do not feel this printer is worth anywhere near this price at all. You can get a nicer printer cheaper. If I hadn't received it for free I would have returned it.

title: 2022 book was better
text:
This is a pricy faux leather planner. I loved the 2022 book so much that I paid for this higher priced 2023 planner. I won't be back for 2024 at the current rate of increase.

The inside of the binder is the same as last year. I could use more pages for notes but it wasn't a deal breaker. However, the cost of the planner increased while the value of the cover drastically decreased.

The 2022 planner's bookcover was flawless. The faux leather looked and felt nearly real. The cover was perfectly adhered to the cardboard hardback. My very well used planner looks to be in perfect condition a year later. It was a professionally done book that looks and feels professional in my hand. Last year, I bought the gray.

Unfortunately, this 2023 binder lacks the same quality binding. The cover feels very cheap and thin. It's not adhered to the cardboard hardback at all; so, you see ripples in the cover when it's open and closed. I'm highly disappointed with the extreme lack of quality and professionalism. This 40 dollar binder is dollar general quality. It's a bait and switch. Now that they have all the great reviews, they didn't feel compelled to maintain or improve the quality with the higher price.

Next year, I'll just go into a store to make sure I get everything I'm paying for. This should've been 1/3 the cost or less. I'm very disappointing to say the least. Note, if you are solely concerned with what's inside the planner, you should be fine. But, I need the entire planner to reflect its cost and the very thing you see 1st is annoyingly sub par and I don't have confidence in its durability as a result. I no longer have faith in the company and won't be returning for a 2024 planner.

title: A bit overkill
text:
The planner is a solid book with a comfortable weight and strong cover/binding. The pages were thick and some of the planning options were helpful for me. However, I think the cost is too high for the monotony of this 6 mos calendar. What I have figured out is that I really only need Monthly and daily pages and the additional weekly pages did not serve me well. I also learned that I prefer a 12 month option. The book helped me learned about how I prefer to stay organized; so, it wasn't a total waste. It's not for me but you might enjoy the structure of this planer.

Good luck

title: Very nifty little printer that doesn't take up too much space...
text:
[[VIDEOID:2224c3c8a3671b727e953c0bc8b3003a]] FEB 5, 2022 UPDATE:
-------------------------
The AR feature in which I described as magic in my review below worked for one day. LOL! What you do is you select a video clip from your phone in the HeyPhoto app, you trim a 15 second clip of your video, then you choose a still image from that video to print. Then when you use the HeyPhoto app to scan that photo, it'll play the clip. It's pretty cool, just as the advertised. But for whatever reason, this app has stopped working. We uninstalled and reinstalled app too, so now I think we lost the effects for the previous photos we printed. Still does not work. This product has given so much headache from day 1. It's still good just to print regular photos. I'm downgrading to 2-Stars.

JAN 26, 2022 UPDATE:
---------------------------
Okay, so just as suspected, my issues in my original review were all due to a faulty ribbon cassette. I've since gotten a replacement ribbon, and the printer is working fine. I still believe they should go back to the drawing board and re-write their manual to include troubleshooting tips. I've uploaded a video to show you the printing process. It lays down a single color film with each passage. The picture comes out quite impressive, but of course it's a little dull compared to how it shows on your phone. So I suggest you only print pictures that are bright and colorful on your phone. Those will show up best when printed out. The AR feature is also very neat. It's like a magic trick. I think with the invention of the smartphone, we are printing less and less. We just look at photos on our phones. So I think a product like this makes a lot of sense. It's for printing occasionally, and for something that won't be used often, it's nice that it won't take up much desktop space. I'm bumping this up to 4-Stars.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
-----------------------
Well, this has been a disaster so far. I got this printer because I really liked their little 3x2 zink printer. Now this 4x6 printer requires a ribbon. This is the year 2022, I don't think I'm the only one who is in the dark about ribbon technology. Not that I'm a young buck, but the last time I dealt with ribbons was in the 80's and 90's. What I'm getting at is there should be some introduction in the manual explaining how this ribbon prints on their paper, and a section on troubleshooting issues. None of this is in the manual. On my first print, the printer made all sorts of sounds, then the button started blinking red, I knew I was in trouble. The ribbon got all wrinkled and crumpled up inside. A troubleshooting section on how to remove a ribbon jam would have been nice.

This is a vine review, but I paid for their ribbon/paper package in order to test this out and write this review. I consider myself pretty good with tech, and I'm 99.99% sure this wasn't user error. When I removed the ribbon from its package, it seemed a little loose to me, but what can I do? Should I adjust it, should I tighten it, how do I do that? There doesn't seem to be any moving parts on the ribbon. Nothing can be adjusted. Troubleshooting tips didn't come with the ribbon package either. So I gave their product the benefit of the doubt, that nothing's wrong. I pushed the ribbon into the printer and I heard a click, so all is well. On the first print, everything got jammed up with no troubleshooting manual to turn to.

Bottom line, documentation needs to be better. They need to think in advance and anticipate these issues like every printer on the market does. This is 1-Star so far until I get this sorted out.

title: Good for stapling thicker stacks, bad for stapling a few sheets...
text:
[[VIDEOID:9661a95f6fb5ce8d0b2cb685d50b8fbf]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* My daughter loves pink, so this stapler goes with her desk decor.
* Cordless, rechargeable.
* Uses standard 24/6 staples, 1000 included.
* Built in stapler remover.
* Easy push button to eject staple tray.

THE BAD:
------------
* Sensor is terrible when you're not stapling a lot of papers. If you need to staple 2 or 3 sheets, you may have problems. Watch my video.

It's a terrific stapler if you're stapling a thick bunch, but not a good stapler for just a few sheets. Too bad, I would have rated this 5-Stars, but I'll have to deduct 2 stars. Got this for my 1st grader, but we may have to keep looking.

title: 18 rolls, but they are only 60 yards per roll, not getting any bargain here...
text: The value proposition here isn't impressive. The market is flooded with either 55 yard or 110 yard rolls. You are getting a 60 yard version, which might even be the 55 and they're just rounding up. These are also only 2 mil, which is pretty standard and thin for low end sealing tapes. If you take your time and do your research, you can get 18/110 yard rolls for around the same price, which is technically 36 of these rolls. These are overpriced run of the mil sealing tape. 3-Stars.

title: Good paper, absolutely no bang for your buck...
text: I got this without doing any research in the average cost of wide-ruled paper, and boy was I shocked! The paper is fine. You get 3 packs of 100 each, so 300 sheets total. But will you feel or experience something that will make you say, "Wow, this paper is 10x better than the ones I buy at Wal or Tar!" No, you won't have that epiphany, so why pay 10x to 15x more? The same wide ruled paper can be purchased at 500 a pack for a tenth of this price. I have to give this listing 1 star for being uncompetitive in pricing.

title: 492 per roll, absolutely annoying...
text:
September 21, 2021 UPDATE:
-----------------------------------
It gets worse... I just got a roll that had 520 labels on it, then this last roll ran out at 477. These rolls are way off! I always keep count because when you run out of labels, you have no clue how many it actually printed, or how many you're short on. So you then you have to manually count the labels by hands to know where you're at. It is time consuming and tedious. That is why I always keep count. So I don't print more than I have. I would avoid this listing. You are not getting 500 per roll.

How can you trust that I'm not the one that's losing count? Because it's happened over and over. I'm not this bad at math. LOL! I print using photoshop. I keep a tally. For example, my latest work required printing three unique skus at 300, 150, 100 a piece. I started with a fresh roll. 300 printed no problem. Then the 150, no problem. So that's 450 used. I should have 50 left, but many of these rolls have been ending at 492. So for the last 100, I set it to 42. I'll then print the rest, 58, in the next fresh roll. I didn't even get 42, I got the "OUT OF PAPER" alert. Opened up my Dymo, freed the label, and started manually counting... 27. So that's 477 labels. These batches are bad.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
----------------------
If you're not counting, then you wouldn't be the wiser, and you'd be happy. But if you actually need to keep count of the skus you print, you will be annoyed. I don't like to print more labels than I have because the printer will say, "OUT OF PAPER," and then you have to count by hand how many it printed, so you would know how many more you need to print. I avoid that situation by keeping count always. For several days, I keep messing up, I thought I was the one who was losing count. But it was very clear to me on my latest batches that the problem was the rolls, not me. I started with a fresh roll. I needed to print three different skus at 121, 200, 174, that's 495 labels. I ran out of paper at 492. This explains why I've been pulling my hair for several days. To be fair, this is my second order from them. I did not have this problem on the first order. This might be just a random issue. But it messed up my flow of work for several days. Very annoying.

title: Light duty cart, I wouldn't use it for a computer tower...

3-Stars.

title: No frills pencil sharpener...
text: I didn't give this sharpener much thought until I received it. I just figured we needed another one in the house, but when I got it, I was surprised that a pencil sharpener we've had in the house since the 1980's was still better. It was made by Panasonic and it had a light indicator & auto stop that still works to this day. Because I'm used to this light, I thought all electric sharpeners in 2020 would have it, but to my surprise, the AFMAT has no light, no auto stop. It is beaten in features by sharpener from the 80's. LOL! Also, you know how sometimes the wood on one side of the pencil just won't go away? I always thought that's due to my Panasonic being old and no longer sharp, but to my surprise, the pencils I couldn't sharpen with my Panasonic, well I couldn't sharpen it either with the AFMAT. So it's not about the sharpener, it's more about the wood in the pencils. At the end of the day, I didn't get a new and improved pencil sharpener in 2020 that I anticipated. My 1980's Panasonic is still better!

The pens come in a box. The good thing about the pens is that they were individually wrapped. The instructions say, "shake the pen with the cap on". I did that. I wrote my name and thought maybe I didn't shake it long enough. I put the cap back on and started shaking it vigorously, but the color was just not as bright as it was in the beginning. I will not be recommending these Acrylic Paint Marker Pens to family and friends.
