title: Mixed bag
text:
I liked this chair when I first got it, but there is one massive issue that is causing me to re-evaluate my opinion. The lumbar support is too aggressive, not very customizable (only up/down, not back/forth aggressiveness), and impossible to remove without damaging the chair (which I did anyway).

I have back issues from a previous injury and have been having much more pain in the past year. I finally realized that this pain was correlated to days spent sitting in this chair specifically. I wasn't a fan of the lumbar support already but decided to remove it. Unfortunately the Phillips head screws that secure the lumbar support to the back of the chair air pointed toward the netting, making them difficult to access without special tooling (a ratchet screwdriver for instance).

The seat is also incredibly squeaky after a year of mixed use. My Zoom chats will highlight my video because my mic picks it up.

Otherwise it's a great height, decent padding, and decent quality.

title: Not a good choice
text:
We loved the cannon pixma we had previously and used without issues for many years.
When it finally died we could not find any printers with comparable scanning capabilities. This was the closest so we went with it even though it's twice the price.
We have had nothing but problems with this printer even though we don't really use it that much.
It was difficult to install and get up and running. I constantly get error messages. When it does print it takes it a good five minutes to actually start printing what we send from the computer. When you finally get the print it usually has streaks and is unreadable so you have to print everything twice. I know how to clean the heads and do the maintenance, but that has not helped.
I ditched HP years ago because of all the trouble i had with their printers but after this canon i may have to go crawling back to them lol
For over $300 this was not a good value.

title: DON'T USE WRIST RESTS!
text:
This is true of all wrist rest pads. Don't use them!

ANY pressure applied to the bottom of your wrist will only make carpal tunnel syndrome worse.

Use NO pad. Keep wrist just barely elevated above tabletop. It should not touch anything. If you let the Carpal tunnel area rest on the pads, all you're doing is compressing the muscles and tendons in that area, making it even more likely to get swollen and sore. So stay away ftom these devices. The only time to use them is momentarily when you're not typing.
Yes it might feel good for a minute but then it'll get worse and you'll need the wrist rest pad more and more, until eventually you need surgery. So stay away and you'll never need surgery!

title: I'm a fan of Snoopy but.....

title: Not for regular people!
text: I don't know who it is for... I bought this printer after shopping around and I have NEVER been so thoroughly disappointed with an HP product.  I have worked with computers, printers, laptops, iPads, and Chrome books for my entire career and never found a piece of hardware that i couldn't operate until now. This is not my first HP laser printer, nor my first print from the device printer.  I want to return it, but it weighs a TON and I can't get it back into the box by myself.  I have spent over 20 hours working, reading, YouTubing and even got my daughter to help and it still won't connect.  I got it near the end of last year(2018) and have tried 4 separate times myself to get it to work.  Every time I had time off, S{ring break and now summer recess. I hate it!  I wish you had it back.  This was a significant investment for a Public School teacher to make and I feel like I wasted my money for this heavy brick.

title: Looks better digitally
text: Had I seen this card in a store, it would not have made a good impression. The paper of which the card is constructed -- not a very good quality, despite being sustainably sourced and made in the USA, lends itself to bending where your don't want it to bend. The face of the card does not make as good an impression as does a digital photo image, and because of the less than stellar paper fibers, I am using ballpoint pen rather than gel ink or a fountain pen.

title: Weak, flimsy magnetic cards better for crafts than business
text:
For craft purposes, these Avery magnetic business cards are fine, but I would not hand these to my customers in the hopes of making a favorable impression. My initial thought was that it was due to the matte paper, however after printing a sheet, I believe it is the entire package. The finished card is flimsy and does not lay flat against a metallic surface, but is rather bumpy. I printed using a great ink jet printer that has been a workhorse with other Avery products, yet despite the ease with which the sheet was fed through, the outcome was not impressive at all. As with most cards I print, I ran a test sheet of paper prior to printing on the Avery stock, then lined it up to assure it looks as I intend. Unfortunately, the final product just looks like a cheap, unprofessional card.

With the remaining two sheets in my packet, I am going to print words in a small font in assorted colors on the cards, then cut them into individual words. These will be added to an existing kit which we use on a metallic surface for writing sentences. In small pieces, the product tends to adhere better to a surface. Not wanting to waste a thing, I also draw on the sheet margins with colored sharpies, cut them in small sections, and then have little magnetic pieces.

title: Remove the interior pockets and they would be excellent
text:
Having received three of these Avery Durable clear cover binders over the past few weeks, I can no longer remain silent. Each one has a pocket inside the cover and each one has a pocket which has split. The exterior looks good, particularly when personalized sheets of paper have been inserted into the cover sleeves, each one has perfectly functioning slant rings, each one holds the tabbed dividers perfectly, but the interior pockets look as though they were sliced with a knife. These are very fine for home purposes, but I would not consider them for distribution of materials requiring more than occasional use and would hesitate before using them for student purposes which require daily use.

The hardware is excellent in these binders and they are attached well into the rear of the binder so the sturdiness is increased, I just do not like the flimsy plastic parts of the pockets which are terrible.

title: Not impressed
text: Time is valuable and using the [[ASIN:B00JFMMVBU Avery 3.25 x 2.25 Inches Printable Self-Laminating ID Labels, Pack of 10, White (00761)]] is not worth the time investment.  The labels are no thicker than any other Avery label made in Mexico and the self laminating sheet is very much thinner than I was anticipating.  Were I to use these, it would be by either stamping or freehand with a sharpie.  I would not bother printing these because I will use them as individuals and not a set requiring formatting.  These are absolutely not worth the price of around a dollar each.

title: Nib dries in minutes of non-use
text: The [[ASIN:B004MTDFHA Parker IM Black Gold Trim Fountain Pen, Medium Nib - 1760800]] is  a nice looking Parker pen which arrives in a soft box containing a single cartridge and warranty.  If there's a problem with the pen,  Parker requires a copy of your sales order because Amazon does not stamp the date of purchase on the warranty.  With this pen, use of the warranty is likely.  I'd read reviews abound with complaints regarding the faulty ink flow to the nib and the one I received is awful.  I'd also purchased an ink converter, so I know it's not the cartridge, as I've tried about a half dozen different inks.  With each, even if I leave the pen for an hour, it dries and I must either prime the converter or dip the nib into water or ink.  I was embarrassed at a meeting when the pen would not write and  I needed to sign a document.  Visually, this pen is five star.  In the hand, it's also five star.  If it worked properly, it would be a total five star value.  Unfortunately, a pen that doesn't write is worthless unless you've purchased it for another purpose.  I purchase pens to use as a tool for transporting ink to paper, so this one is a great disappointment.  I'd had a very old Parker fountain pen stolen inside of a bag and really wanted another, but this one will not replace the great pen I'd had for about forty years.  I cannot recommend this pen, particularly since there are so many really good fountain pens available currently.

title: Small & does not stay in place
text: Save your money. This moves around too much to be very useful. It slides off the keyboard tray. The two strips that are supposed to keep it in place need to be 3-4 times the size.

title: Very poor quality
text: This item is poorly made, it wouldn't snap in properly into its slot in the printer, I had to to tape it to the other inks and once it was pushed down, I was able to print, the plastic part toward the front broke off immediately. title: Looks good, doesn't hold up
text:
I ordered this before beginning my first job as a teacher. I finished grad school in December and was hired for a mid-year opening when another teacher decided to move during the break. My first day was January 8, and I had five classes (high school). I used this book for attendance and for grades. I liked that the cover was not just a solid color, and I liked that the blocks were slightly larger. And you couldn't beat the cost.
But like most things, you get what you pay for, it seems. I took this out of my rolling briefcase each morning and put it back at the end of the day. If I was grading papers at home in the evening, it came out and was replaced before I went to bed. Within three weeks, I was running into my local office supply store hoping to find one of those generic record books with the solid cover because the cover to this was falling off at the plastic coil, and several of the pages were also beginning to separate from the coil. Before I made the complete transfer of data, I had ended up removing the coil altogether and holding the pages together with a trio of small binder clips down the edge where the coil should have been.

title: stops turing on
text: I ordered a Palm Z22 in April. I was not overly impressed but it did suit my needs.  Barely a month of owning it, it quit working.  I could not get it to turn on.  Someone else that had one said she had a similar problem in that it stopped working (coming on) as well.  She left her palm on her dresser for a few months.  One day while she was cleaning up she came across her Z22.  She was about to throw it out but decided to try it one more time and it came on. She finally gave up on it when it did it again a month or so later.  So I tried that --- it still does not work.  I would not recommend this product to anyone.  That was $95 down the drain.

title: Dissapointing for the price
text:
I had high hopes for this, imagining that the monthly white boards would be solid affairs on smooth runners that could simply be shuffled in order easily. In fact, this is a bog standard 3'x2' white board with a shelf that also has three small flimsy 1'x2' card inserts for the 3 months that you have to manually pull out a reorganize (they have a plasticized covering to make them wipeable). As a final disappointment it comes with a pack of large tip dry erase markers -- how on earth is anyone supposed to use a large tip dry erase marker on this when each day of the month only has a 1.8"x2.9" area?
(this was ordered from work which is why I'm not a verified purchaser)

title: Only hold 65 pencils comfortably, not 72
text: This pencil wrap supposedly holds 72 pencils. I got this for my set of 72 Derwent Inktense pencils so it would be easier to use and travel with.  I was so excited to start using this and immediately started putting all of my pencils in here except I couldn't fit them all in.  The pockets only hold 5 pencils comfortably and since there are 13 pockets, I could only fit 65 pencils in this wrap case.  I tried putting 6 pencils in some of the pouches but they don't lay flat if you do that and it is not as easy to see the colors when are layered upon one another.  Also the little leather thing at the end of the cord immediately fell off when I opened my package and I didn't even notice it until later when my son found it lying on the floor.  This might be a decent pencil wrap case if you have 65 pencils or less but if you have more than that, they will not comfortably fit in here. I almost ordered 3 of these to hold my set of Derwents and my 132 set of Prismacolor pencils but thought I'd try one first to see how I like it.  So glad I only ordered one to try out.  I will keep the Prismacolors in the tin box they came in for now until I find a better solution.

title: Terribly expensive ink cost.
text:
We have owned both the Epson Artisan 800 and the artisan 835. Both printers has terrible paper handling and uses lots ink even when not printing. The average cost per page is over $3, since the ink so so expensive and the machine is useless after a couple of years, when the ink pads are full, which shuts down the machine entirely and none of the other functions work. Epson's rather shabby customer service solution is to buy another printer.

Nice looking printer, which prints CD's which is a big plus for us, however I would NOT recommend this printer, due to the extremely high cost of printing.

text: With only one review of 5 stars I thought it would be a good way to file and organize my papers. Wrong! The folder itself is like an accordion but it does not stay open to get the papers out and in. The inner file folders in various colors is a good thing except that they are extremely thin. I tried it to see if I could make it usable but there’s no way I could get more than a few papers in one slot. The description says it’s a ‘large capacity’ organizer but it isn’t. It’s also said that it can be used with ‘legal’ size papers - this is something I can’t imagine unless you actually fold the document in half. I only received it yesterday and it’s going right back - there are much better ones to choose from and that have a decent price as well.

title: Run away from Uniden Corporation!
text: RUN AWAY FROM UNIDEN CORP!  They have the WORST customer dis-service of any corporation I've recently dealt with.  If you email them, you will get an automatic message that your model, even if brand new, has been discontinued, with no email address to reply to.  If you phone them, chances are high you will get cut off.  I recently replaced my Uniden cordless with this model, purchased locally.  The phone is okay, but for something this huge should have better features such as a flashing red light when a call comes in and a rechargeable battery - both of which were standard feature on my much smaller cordless version.  So I have no idea if you lose all your data when your 4 AA batteries go, and that's why I was trying to speak with someone at Uniden.  I have no idea how long this phone will last, but it will for sure be a throw away when it breaks down, even if that's before the warranty period expires.  Anyway, there are plenty of other options out there.  Life is too short to spend it dealing with companies who behave as if they're doing you a favor to take your money.

title: Disappointing

But that's about the only positive thing I can say about them.  1) only the silver and gold look metallic; 2) after one use, the blue one completely ran dry; 3) surface absorption was poor resulting in the ink coming off on my hands even 30 minutes after application, so I had to use a coat of varnish to seal them.  I can't recommend them.

title: Good dual-monoculars, no 3-D
text: This is relatively comfortable, and the magnifications seem about as advertised, but no amount of adjustment, including bending the bridge slightly with the aid of boiling water, would allow me to focus both eyes through two lenses pointed at the same, necessarily small, area, hence my title. In practical terms, for many uses I found it easier anyway to select my target area with an unaided left eye and then use my right to look at it closely, switching after the right got tired. If I could give it  2.5 stars, I would.

title: A good notebook with some notable issues.
text:
So, I bought a Grandmaster set, comes with a Monolith and an Origin. Both books had warped covers - as soon as they were out of the packaging, the covers and some of the pages started to lift up. Pressing them with weight didn't fix the issue.

I contacted customer service, and they said that this issue is not up to spec and would send me new notebooks as a replacement.

The new notebooks, as soon as they were out of the box, had covers that began to warp.

Now, the binding of the notebooks, the paper quality - all seem fine. And I would give this a much higher rating if it were not for those covers. At this price, you should be getting a better notebook.

title: Not for me, but may be for you.

I shouldn't have to "research" a product before purchasing on Amazon. I count on you for that...that's why I have Amazon Prime!

title: A Fun Filled Family Project, or a Struggle for Domination?
text:
Worked great until it didn't. My Xyron came new in the box with no User's Guide, so I was forced to turn to the good folks on YouTube to learn my way around what is probably the easiest-to-use paper crafting product ever developed.
What has come to be referred to in hushed tones at our house, "The Great Adhesive Rebellion," is the night we tried to troubleshoot a defective replacement cartridge. Those things are brutal and unforgiving. Marketed as "a simple, one-step, drop-in process," that simple self-contained cartridge goes rogue, adhering to everything within a thirty foot radius except the targeted item nestled in the input tray. The handle stops turning. Sticker paper clings to the machine's interior. The mysterious roll of cellophane shivers and quivers and tries to wrap itself around everything at once. It's like some passive-aggressive squid wandered into our living room and engaged us in some fairly innocuous, though highly complex duel to the death. No matter what we youtube'd or researched or attempted, the maliciously wound cartridge blocked our every effort to restore function to my Xyron. As he dragged himself away from our project to scrub up in a tubful of fingernail polish remover (even the whorls of his fingerprints were cemented together), he proclaimed over his shoulder: "Waste. Of. Money." He does not appreciate the challenges posed by paper crafting, apparently.

title: not a good printer.
text: I can't say I like this printer. I had a Samsung ML whatever printer before this that was stolen. I paid 100 bucks for it new 10 years ago. None of the new printers match up to it. And the ad said this thing had ethernet and it didn't and then they changed the ad.  I'm very upset I didn't get my ethernet port. I do not want wireless printing... But meh, It works... But I miss my old cheap samsung. Why can't they still make/sell good cheap models like that. And I could get past all of this, but here's the killer, this printer surges past 1500 watts at startup!!!  It literally trips my APC 900 watt UPS... even when plugged into the surge only ports, I have to plug this damn thing directly into the wall or it will trip what it's plugged into. I find that to be BS!  Not happy with this purchase. It does print well though. which is what really matters. But I find myself consciously making sure it's off all the time because I'm so concerned about the power it might be using. All be it, I'm pretty sure it only happens during startup and wake from sleep. but that's crazy, My old samsung could run off a car outlet ac inverter, which is like 150 watts or less. so that means its startup surge was less than 150. I don't understand why this thing needs such a huge startup surge. Like I just can't get over it. I could bring my samsung with me traveling, not this guy, because of the power...  That's just stupid. Is it suppose to be that bad or did I get a bad one? One of the reasons I bought this is because this was the closest match to my old samsung printer. but not having and ethernet port really blows to. I'm torn between a 1 and 2 star, but I will go with a 2. I rated sleep mode a 1, and tech support a 1. just nonsense on this printer. I know a lot about tech and this thing sucks.

title: 💯 in Spanish.
text:
Okay, I should have admittedly looked at the picture better before buying these for my young child. 🤦🏻‍♀️

Pros:
💕 Prismacolor is a high quality colored pencil and language barriers do not change that fact.
💕 $10 for 24 pencils of this brand is a good deal.
💕 They arrived quickly.
💕 The toucan on the box is Kawaii.

Cons:
👎🏻 I bought these for my young child’s art class. She does not speak Spanish and the pencils only state the color names in Spanish. Unlike say, Crayola who puts both English and Spanish on most crayons. She is already going to be learning French and ASL so I wasn’t planning to teach her Spanish ATM.
👎🏻 I was not warned in the discription that these pencils have NO English on the packaging or on the pencils.
👎🏻The package is trash and not something they can be stored in for long -like the metal case typically found with Prismacolor (to be fair I assume this is a major reason they were cheaper.)

👩🏻‍🦱 Overall: I am left feeling pretty angry about the lack of English on the pencils. I really wish they had BOTH languages. If this were the case I would be accepting with no other English on the box (even though there was no warning in the description.)
However, since I do not know what the colors are called without Googling (and there are 3 brown shades for example so the names are helpful) I find the price to not be as great as I had originally thought. My time is vauluable and Googling the translation for each of the 24 penscils and then making English labels AND labeling them will take a bit of time.

⭐️If they were say $4.99 and not $9.99 (and they warned me in advance I’d need to translate for my child), I’d be willing to buy again.

⭐️At the set price of $9.99 with no explanation- I would opt to find a better seller and even pay MORE for an honest discription of what I’m getting.

🤓Just a note, I order things for my kids from 🇫🇷 France, Japan 🇯🇵, and Germany 🇩🇪 and have never had a product not contain information in more than one language. 🙄

🤓Edited- after mild research, these are not even the Scholar pencils I thought I was buying. I’m also most certain that the seller changed the photo from the one that was up when I made my purchase. 🤨

title: EDIT:  I ordered this in 2017 and again in Feb 2022 - WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW
text:
EDIT: I ordered one of these in 2017. I think it was on sale, I got it for exactly $7 less, or it could just have gone up in price.

PROS AND CONS between the FIRST one and the one I JUST got this week.

PROS re FIRST ONE:

It was really great. Made a big difference and I have bad discs in my back.

It came in a box, NOT ROLLED up like a roll of paper towels and was good to go out of the box.

Foam was perfectly balanced and cover fit really well.

CONS:

Well, not sure I can really call this a con re the first one, after over four and a half years, it wasn't as thick. Still offered some comfort, but wanted to get another EXACTLY like it.

NOW for the one I JUST got.

PROS:

THICKER (AFTER letting it sit and fluff for two and a half days) AND that's where pros end.

CONS:

PACKAGING - This should NOT be rolled up and expected to expand evenly. Even after two and a half days of just letting it sit, I could run my hand over it and feel rippling. It did NOT expand evenly. Cover sagged a bit in places.

COMFORT - IF you had never had the one I had first, you might find this comfortable. Within minutes, not even hours, of sitting on this, I feel it's thicker in some places than others. Right side expanded more than the left. Yeah, not ideal.

I'm not that heavy, so I can't imagine someone very large finding this super comfy for long.

BOTTOMLINE: IF you get one that is NOT ROLLED UP tight, if you get it good to go, you will likely like it more OR maybe some came from a different factory. ALL I know is for seven dollars less, the one I got in 2017 was more comfy up until I got this one in Feb 2022, than this new one is NOW.

CAVEAT EMPTOR.
I DID read a LOT of the reviews, both positive and negative, to see what I might expect.

I didn't want a cushion with grooves in it, either too soft that would flatten fast or too hard. I am in my sixties and just wanted more cushion especially for my hip and backs of my legs (I put my feet up on an ottoman).

Got the cushion yesterday, unwrapped, and yes, did notice an odor, but not surprising, reviews had prepared me.

I couldn't hang it outside, so put on a hanger with clips by it's tags and hung in a room I don't use much. This morning, most of the odor seemed gone and decided to try it out. And oh, it didn't have creases and did seem to have expanded well.

I have on a few layers of clothing between me and the cushion. I noted a few people mentioning the mesh fabric not the most comfy.

PROS:
FITS my armless computer chair perfectly and cushions the backs of my legs near my knees, which I wanted. SO GLAD I GOT THIS LARGE size!

VERY COMFORTABLE - granted, I have only been sitting on it a couple hours (and I get up and down, so usually no more than an hour goes by before I am up doing something), but it is JUST what I wanted - MORE CUSHION for my bones and legs!

DOESN'T SLIDE - I do have it on a nice fabric computer chair, not a slick chair, but I just tried moving back and forth and the cushion stays put.

ABILITY TO EASILY CARRY AROUND - I got for this chair, but good to know I can move it to another easily.

CONS:
THE COVER AND TAKING IT OFF - It doesn't seem easy to just take off and clean. I have thought of taking a piece of fabric and adding a bit of velcro on the ends to just attach to the sides of the cushion, so I could easily just wash that. It might make it more comfortable if I were wearing shorts to cushion against the mesh cover.

THAT'S IT FOR NOW. I will post again after I have used this for about a month, whether I still notice the positives or any negatives.

GLAD I GOT IT and at the price I paid.

title: Thuesday & Thurthday stink
text:
Well, what can you say about a calendar the has Thuesday & Thurthday? Yep, that how the two days are spelled on the calendar.

While it rips my OCD apart my wife thinks it's hilarious.

Not to be too picky but I expect the week days to be spelled correctly on something that is a calendar and I pay for.

It works, I guess. Is what you would expect.

title: Flimsy and thin tabs, difficult to write on
text:
I thought these were going to be the quality of tabs I have purchased in the past. Wrong. These were the flimsiest tabs I have ever seen (no exaggeration), and all inks I have tried have smeared or have been illegible (too light to read, and poor coverage with ink, despite my having tried at least 5 brands of permanent markers.
If you know before ordering that these are inferior, purchase at your own risk.
I am going back to the name brands I have used for decades.

title: Sharpening challenge
text:
I have purchased several of these sharpeners in the past, and always found them to be easy to use and effective at sharpening my colored pencils. However, this one appears to have been manufactured incorrectly, as I am unable to pull out the sharpener insert to empty out the pencil shavings.
I have tried to take photos of it to show exactly where it broke when I was trying to empty out the shavings (this has never happened to me before, so I know it was somehow not assembled or glued together correctly.
I would greatly appreciate a replacement of another sharpener. They can't be all bad, you know. My previous ones did not break. Something went wrong with this one. If you want it back so you can see what happened, I would be glad to return it. I am keeping it so that I can return it to you. It is really unusable.
Thank you.

title: Where is the rest of Jan and February?
text:
[[VIDEOID:86860104479d18aa20e80dd4e6e1065]] So this planner is BEAUTIFUL. I got the Jan 2022-June 2023 version. I could not wait to start writing in it…
I get to January and it only goes to Jan 7th … I go to February and the first day available is the 7th…

I’m bummed but I don’t have time to get a new planner at this point. I’m also too busy to waste time on returning it. See I tried to contact the company but they have been MIA. If they see this review, they should reach out to me and fix this issue so I can fix this review.
It’s a beautiful planner and so fun but the seller got sloppy with putting this product together and it shows sadly.

title: First batch was amazing, new batch? Not so much...
text:
This is a reorder from a batch I got last year, and that batch was pretty awesome. This new batch though, the paper feels incredibly thing, and overall envelope feels flimsy, and I'm kinda worried these won't hold up to rough mailing times.

The original batch was awesome, but this new batch has me worried. I'm sending some stuff out internationally and I'm just hoping it makes it there. I'm adding a strip of tape to reinforce the top.

Also, dunno if this matters to anyone else, but the package mine came in, the tops were all bent'folded/squished in weird ways to fit into the shipping envelope. The glue also seems to be somewhat subpar (hence the tape).

As soon as I start getting some feedback from people receiving the packages, I'll update the review or add a comment.

title: Pass on these pens!
text:
UPDATE: I'm on my third pen and am slowly losing any praise I had for them. First, it is impossible, once you erase a line, to write over it with the same pen. In fact, if you try, the pen skips and sometimes just refuses to write. That negates the effect of having an erasable pen. No thank you. Add onto that, there appears to be not much gel in these pens, or the gel goes faster than ink would in the same size pen. I'm on my third and won't be using these again. I know there are erasable pens out there, and I'm going to search out some with ink instead of gel, because I think that is what is causing this problem. Don't waste your money on these if you actually think you're going to be erasing and writing over anything, because you'll have the same problem I've had.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: The last time I tried erasable pens and ink, I was totally disappointed so these were a nice surprise. I do most of my writing on a desk pad when I'm on the phone and it is nice to be able to erase something if it isn't correct. These erase cleaning (as long as you don't have a really heavy hand when writing, then they'll erase the ink but the impression will be left on the page). The first one out of the box doesn't skip and the blue is a bluer blue than most blue ink any more, which I appreciate too, especially when I have to put my wet signature on something and can't use a black pen.

title: Penny wise and pound foolish
text:
I thought I would save a few bucks over the brand names like Quartet and or UBoards. Those boards run about $130ish so I was looking at a solid 25% savings. I figured why not, its just a piece of tempered glass with some thin gauge sheet metal on the back, how much different can it be? Well I guess I will never know because the hardware that came with this board is completely useless. I wouldn't mount a 11" x 14" picture frame with that trash let alone a huge piece that weighs more than 20 lbs. I really wanted this to work so I ordered some third part offset mounts from Amazon and it was slightly too big. I am so disappointed. this thing took forever to arrive and then I waited another week to get the new hardware. All for nothing. I am still surrounded by 100's of sticky notes. Lesson learned. You get what you pay for. I am returning it and will be buying one of the brand name boards.
Dear Manufacturer,
This COULD have been a great product but you decided to save a few pennies on mounting hardware. I realize you sourced this from some factory in China (says so on the box) but is anyone managing your brand and the quality of the products you attach it to? I mean quality hardware would have cost you less than a couple of dollars. These small details are what make the difference when sourcing something. How did you not have specific specifications on your mounting hardware. Did anyone even bother to check the hardware shipping with this board? A little attention to detail would have gone a long way.

title: Costume furniture worth no more than $19.99. Please think twice.
text:
This is the kind of furniture a set designer for a high school play would make. It looks fine in the picture, but when I got it, everything but the frame was thin plastic.

It looks like something I wanted, and I eagerly waited in anticipation for this to arrive. First of all, the drawers are made of plastic that is not much thicker than a plastic gallon of milk. The bolts that look shiny in the picture are silver plastic. They've managed to take these phony bolts and make them the handle with which you open the black milk jug drawers.

The wheels- oy. I have hardwood floors in my place, I would not use them on these floors. They don't slide anymore than a plastic box would slide. I can already see this product gathering dust in my storage, or (better) in the garbage bin in my office park.

This product is what reviews are made for. Please learn from my mistake. It's one of those things that would be such a hassle to disassemble and return, especially in a pandemic. This is junk.

title: Can't recommend

title: Kind of a let down.....
text: I was looking for a nice, rustic, handmade, organic feeling journal to give to my daughter. She's going through some things right now. I thought it would be a good thing for her to write down her thoughts and feelings. I thought that this journal would be good for her. I didn't expect this journal to be a kind of slap-together daily planner. It has two sections of blank paper, that don't look at all like it was handmade, with a section of GRAPH PAPER between them. Really? Graph paper? Who uses graph paper in a personal journal? And, there's a zip lock pocket in one end and a business card holder in the other. Very much like a planner. Not at all like a journal. The leather cover is nice. But, the white stitching throws it off. It should have been brown, gray, black, any color to indicate that it was 'organic'. The worst part is how it was assembled with elastic cords tied in knots. That really cheapened it up, a LOT. The only reason it got two stars is that it is still usable as a journal. Really, if it was so bad that it wouldn't serve that purpose, it would have gotten one star.

title: Tape okay, annoyed by dispenser.
text:
The tape works just fine. Not great, but fine. It's not the stickiest, but it also doesn't tear things if you accidentally touch paper to it or glue your fingers together.

But the dispensers are useless. The edge isn't sharp enough to cut the tape, and the entire mechanism just falls apart and stops working almost immediately. The attached photos are of the second roll in the pack of 3 almost immediately after opening, the second time I used that roll (which had been sitting safely in an enclosed cabinet waiting its turn while I used up half of and then temporarily misplaced the first roll).

While a tape dispenser is a nice thing to have, you should not *have* to have one in order to use tape, especially relatively expensive tape, and you should especially be able to at least use the disposable dispenser one time before it simply falls apart.

The first time I used the roll was even more frustrating because I couldn't get the tape started since it serrated edge wouldn't cut it and I had to use scissors. I have a lot of pain and stiffness in my hands from a medical condition, and get more frustrated than I should when little things don't work, especially when I am already tired and in a lot of pain-- this product definitely did not make my life any easier and I'm disappointed in the quality.

title: Skipping is an issue initially... and it doesn't go away. Frustrating.
text:
Gorgeous, but I didn't want this pen to just look at it. I expected it to lay down ink when I wrote with it, and that hasn't been the case. Skips, and kind of inexplicable skips. Hard to get the ink flowing again after just a few seconds. Sometimes the flow would stop in mid-stroke. I did not anticipate being disappointed with this pen.

Nicely balanced, fits in the hand (I could stand a slightly larger pen). The cartridge was very easy to install, and once I got it to write things were going well for a short time. I set the pen down for a moment and returned to find it dry. So I tried various tricks to get the ink flowing again, mostly involving saliva and swearing in alternating yet equal amounts. I tried various kinds of paper I had on hand, from very nice smooth sketch book paper to printer paper to junk mail envelopes. The. Pen. Skips.

Hours later: I've picked up the pen and written with it several times over the past few hours, and stored it point-down for a while. Given it a couple of shakes hoping that would get the ink flowing between the cartridge and the nib. Less skipping. I ran across a web page and suggests using the edge of a piece of paper and fitting it between the blades on the nib. Haven't gone that far yet. Now the pen seems as happy as a clam in mud at high tide. Maybe it just requires some breaking in?

I'll keep evaluating the pen. If it writes, I'm happy. If it skips, there's a problem. Especially if you considering giving this pen as a gift. You'd want it to write when the recipient went to use it.

---

OK, after many attempts to somehow charm some performance out of this pen, lately priming its tip with a single drop of water and then trying to get it to draw a line longer than 3" without skipping and I'm out. Enough. It doesn't work. Lovely pen, but I'll be darned if I can get it to write so much as my signature without skipping. Frustrating. Look elsewhere for a fountain pen, this one just doesn't work.

title: Beauty Is Only Skin-Deep.  Don't Waste Your Money.
text:
I'm notorious for having bad luck with phones: VTech, Uniden, and now Panasonic are on my "Never Buy Again" List. However, I simply couldn't resist the appeal of the new Uniden 5.8Ghz; so against my better judgment, I bought the Uniden's Latest and Greatest Effort two days ago. It only took about a dozen calls for me to decide that this phone is going back!
First of all, I have to say that this phone is very attractive. With a striking appearance and features such as speakerphones on each handset, and distinctive rings, it's just, plain cool! But...FOR THE PRICE, I strongly feel that the negative outweighs the positive. The range on this phone is SUPPOSED to be more than TWICE that of a 2.4Gz phone. NOT AT ALL! Not only isn't it BETTER than my 2.4Ghz Panasonic, but it's actually MUCH WORSE! I can take my Panasonic to a neighbor's house a few doors down the stret. The Uniden crackles the second I step foot in the backyard! And not only is it static-y, but people I'm talking to actually miss chunks of what I'm saying. My 900Mhz BellSouth LITERALLY has better reception in my yard than this piece of junk!
There's more, too. Something I was willing to overlook to have the best was the fact that you cannot expand this "expandable" system beyond two handsets. I've also discovered that (like Sony's expandable) you cannot use more than one handset (or base unit) at once, so if two people want to talk to Grandma on Christmas, you'd better have a backup phone available. Additionally, (like AT&T's expandable) when you enter information into one handset, it does not automatically transfer to the other one, so you must enter your phonebook in TWICE!
Folks, I know that this is a great looking, and very tempting buy....especially for all you techy, gadget-loving people (like me). However, my recommendation would be to stick with a 2.4Ghz model until the 5.8Ghz technology has been perfected and prices come down. I wanted VERY much to love this phone, but there's simply too many negative points to overlook. I have NO PROBLEM spending [$$$]on a phone that works well. However, this phone is does not deliver on the performance end, and in my opinion, in not worth the money.
PROS:
Great, Sleek appearance
Unique, soft-red backlight
Speakerphone in each handset (though of questionable quality)
Good sound quality close to base unit
One-touch auto-dial
Buttons have nice feel
Ease of operation
CONS:
Extremely poor range - especially for what it's SUPPOSED to have
Only expandable to two handsets
Cannot use more than one handset (or base unit) at one time
Cheek hits "Talk" button when resting on shoulder
Hand covers speaker when talking
(Speculation, but looks/feels like the paint will wear-off easily)
Price

You get what you pay for. If you use your printer a lot and wouldn't let it sit, these might be ok. But for somebody who can do their printing at work or goes a month in between printing stuff, go ahead and get the more expensive cartridges so you don't ruin your printer.
